alphabetical letter v v
The fourth letter of the alphabet: called vaA='N and vaA [respecting which latter see the letter b]: the pl. [of the former] is vaA='aAtN; and [of the latter,] A^avowaA='N and A^avoyaA='N. (TA in bAb AlAlf All~ynp.) It is one of the letters termed mahomuwsap [or non-vocal, i. e. pronounced with the breath only, without the voice], and of those termed livawiy~ap [or gingival], which are v and * and Z. (TA at the commencement of f.) ― -b2- It is sometimes substituted for f as in the instance of HuvaAlapN and HufaAlapN; and for s as in the instance of juvomaAnN and jusomaAnN; and for other letters. (TA in the latter place.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Five hundred.]

vaA vA vA'
vaA and vaA='N: see the letter v, and arts. vwA^ and vY.

R. Q. 1 vaA^ovaA^a *
R. Q. 1. vaA^ovaA^a He watered camels to their satisfaction: (S, M, K; but in some copies of the S, the verb is made trans. by means of bi:) or he watered them (T, M) so as to quench their thirst, (T,) but not so as to satisfy them. (T, M.) ― -b2- Also, contr., He kept camels thirsty; i. e. he did not water them at all; or he watered them little, so that they were not satisfied. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He extinguished fire. (Sgh, K.) ― -b4- He stilled another's anger. (TA.) And vaA^ovaA^a Eanohu gaDabahu He quenched his anger. (M.) [Or this may be rendered He dispelled from him his anger: agreeably with what follows.] ― -b5- He removed (IDrd, M, K) a thing (M) from its place. (IDrd, M, K.) ― -b6- vaA^ovaA^a Eani Alqawomi He repelled from, or defended, the people, or company of men, (As, S, K,) and rendered them reciprocal aid. (As, TA.) ― -b7- vaA^ovaA^a, (T, M, K,) inf. n. vaA^ovaA^apN, (T,) also signifies He restrained, or withheld, (T, M, K,) a man (T, M,) from (Eano) another man, (T,) or from (Eano) a thing, or an affair. (M.) ＝ -A2- vaA^ovaA^ati AlA_ibilu The camels drank to their satisfaction: (M, K:) or drank, but not so as to satisfy themselves. (M.) ― -b2- And, contr., The camels thirsted. (K.) ― -b3- And vaA^ovaA^a It became stilled; (K;) said of anger. (TA.) ― -b4- See also R. Q. 2. ＝ -A3- vaA^otaA^a biAlt~ayosi, (AA, AZ, M, K,) inf. n. vaA^ovaA='N, (K,) like taA^otaA='N, (TA,) He called the he-goat (AA, AZ, M, K) to copulate. (AA, K.)

R. Q. 2 tavaA^ovaA^a *
R. Q. 2. tavaA^ovaA^a He deemed it right that he should abide, or remain, where he was, (AZ, T, K,) and abstain, (AZ, TA,) after he had desired to make a journey (AZ, T, K) to a country, or land. (AZ, TA.) And tvA^ Eani AlA^amori, (M,) or Eani vA^vA^↓ Al$~aYo'i, (TA,) He deemed it right that he should abstain from the affair, or thing, (M, TA,) or that he should pause at it, (M,) after he had desired it. (M, TA.) ― -b2- laqiytu fulaAnFA fatavaA^ovaA^otu minohu I met such a one, and feared him. (As, S, K. *)

1 vuy^iba *
1. vuy^iba, ('Eyn, T, M, K,) like EuniYa, (K,) and vay^iba, (IKoot, L, and so in a copy of the A,) inf. n. vaA^obN, (K,) or vaA^abN, (M,) He became relaxed and sluggish; said of a man: (A:) or he became affected with sluggishness and languor; (M;) as also tvA='b↓: (M, A:) or he became affected with sluggishness and languor like the languor of drowsiness; as also tvA='b↓ and tvA^~b↓; (K;) which last is approved by IDrd and Thábit Es-Sara- kustee, who disallow tvA='b↓, though this is the form commonly known and approved, and is the most chaste form: (TA:) or he became affected with languor like the heaviness of drowsiness, in consequence of something that he had eaten or drunk, without becoming insensible; (T;) as also tvA='b↓: (L:) or ↓this last signifies he yawned, or opened his mouth, (Mgh, Msb,) by reason, (Mgh,) or on the occasion, (Msb,) of languor (Mgh, Msb,) like the heaviness of drowsiness; (Mgh;) or he yawned, or opened his mouth, and stretched himself, on being affected by sluggishness or drowsiness or anxiety; (MF, TA, on the authority of IDrst;) or he yawned, or opened his mouth, and emitted wind from his stomach, by reason of some affection thereof: (TA on the authority of EtTedmuree:) Alt~avaAw^ubu is from Alv~uw^abaA='u; (AZ, T, S, Mgh;) and is on the occasion of one's stretching himself, and being languid: (Lth, T:) one should not say tavaAwaba; (AZ, T, S, O, Mgh;) [for] this is vulgar. (Msb.) Hence, A^aHadukumo faloyugaT~i A_i*aA tavaA^a'aba↓ faAhu [When any one of you yawns, he should cover his mouth with the back of his left hand; for it is believed that the devil leaps into the uncovered yawning mouth]. (Mgh.)

5 tavaA~a^a
5: see 1.

6 tavaA~a^a
6: see 1, in six places.

vuw^abaA='u *
vuw^abaA='u, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) as also vuw^obaA=', accord. to Ibn-Mis-hal, but this is strange, (TA,) is a subst. derived from Alt~avaAw^ubu, like muTuwaA='u from Alt~amaT~iY; (T;) or from vay^iba; and means A state of relaxation and sluggishness: (A:) or sluggishness and languor (M, K) like the languor of drowsiness: (K:) or languor like the heaviness of drowsiness, in consequence of something that one has eaten or drunk, not attended by insensibility: (T, L:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, by reason of languor like the heaviness of drowsiness: (Mgh:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, and stretching oneself, on being affected by sluggishness or drowsiness or anxiety: (IDrst, MF, TA:) or a yawning, or opening the mouth, and emitting wind from the stomach, by reason of some affection thereof. (Et-Tedmuree, TA.) Hence the prov., A^aEodaY mina Alv~uw^abaA='i, (S, A, TA,) and [Alv~uwabaA='i,] without ', as some say; (MF;) or the pronunciation without ' is vulgar, (IDrst, TA,) or erroneous; (TA;) [More catching than yawning;] for when a man yawns ( A*A tvA'b ) in the presence of others, they become affected as he is. (TA.)

mavow^uwbN *
mavow^uwbN Affected with sluggishness and languor like the languor of drowsiness: from vuy^iba, q. v. (K.)

1 vaA^arahu *
1. vaA^arahu, (T, S, Msb,) and vaA^ara bihi, (T, S, M, Msb, K) aor.
vaAa^a
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. vaA^orN and vuw^orapN, (S,) or the latter is a simple subst., as is also vuw^uwrapN, (Lh, M, K,) He revenged, or avenged, his blood, by retaliating his slaughter; he slew his slayer. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) [Hence, vuy^ira maqotuwluhu and bimaqotuwlihi The blood of his slain relation was revenged, or avenged, by retaliation of his slaughter: see 10.] ― -b2- [Hence also,] laA vaA^arato fulaAnFA yadaAhu, (K,) or EalaY fulaAnK, (A,) (tropical:) May his arms, or hands, not profit such a one. (A, K.) ― -b3- Also vaA^arahu, and vaA^ara bihi, (M, K,) and vaA^ara Alqawoma, inf. n. vaA^orN, (T,) He sought to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, (T, M, K,) his blood, (M, K,) and the blood of the people, or party. (T.) It is said in a prov., laA yanaAmu mano vaA^ara [He will not sleep who seeks to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood]: in the Kámil of Mbr, [and in some copies of Meyd,] mani A@v~aA^ari↓ [which seems to signify the same]. (TA.) ― -b4- [And vaA^arahu and vaA^ara bihi signify also He slew him in blood-revenge, or in retaliation of the blood of a relation: see mavow^uwrN.] ― -b5- vaA^arotuka bika*aA I have obtained my bloodrevenge, or retaliation, of thee by such [a deed, or person]. (S, K.)

4 A^avoAa^a
4: see 8.

8 Aiv~aA^ara *
8. Aiv~aA^ara originally AivotaA^ara He obtained his bloodrevenge, or retaliation; syn. A^adorak vaA^orahu; (T, S, M, K;) minohu from him; (T, S;) as also A^avoA^ara↓: (M, K:) and Aiv~aA^ara minohu he slew the slayer of his relation. (T.) Lebeed says,
waAln~iybu A_ino taEoru min~iY rim~apF xalaqFA *
baEoda AlmamaAti faA_in~iY kunotu A^av~ay^iru *
[And the old she-camels, if they seek to obtain benefit from a worn rotten bone of me after death, I used to retaliate upon them by anticipation]: (T, S:) i. e., I used to slaughter [some of] them for guests, and so I have retaliated upon them during my life for their nibbling my rotten bones
after my death: for when camels do not find herbage of the kind called HamoD, they eat the bones of dead men and of camels instead thereof. (T.) ― -b2- See also 1.

10 AstvA^r *
10. AstvA^r He (a relation of a slain man, A) sought, or asked, aid, in order that the blood of his slain [relation] might be revenged, or avenged, by retaliation of his slaughter (luyivoA^ara bimaqotuwlihi), (AZ, S, K,) or in order that he might take, or seek, revenge, or vengeance, for his slain [relation]. (A.)

vaA^orN *
vaA^orN, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) which may be also pronounced vaArN, i. e., with the ' suppressed, (Msb,) and vaA^orapN↓, (A,) and vuw^orapN↓, (S,) which last is a subst. [from vaA^ara], as also vuw^uwrapN↓, (Lh, M, K,) Blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide: or a seeking to revenge, or avenge, or retaliate, blood: [see 1, of which vaA^orN is an inf. n.:] or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: or retention of enmity in the heart, with watchfulness for an opportunity to indulge it: syn. *aHolN: (S, A, Msb:) or Talaba biAld~ami: (M, K:) or HiqodN: (Mgh:) or (so accord. to the M; but accord. to the K, “ and ”) blood (M, K) itself: (M:) pl. A^avoA=rN and A=vaArN; the latter formed by transposition. (Yaakoob, M.) You say, A^adoraka vaA^orahu (S, Mgh, K) and vuw^oratahu↓ (As, T, S) [He obtained, or attained, or took, his bloodrevenge, or retaliation: or] he attained the object of his pursuit [for blood-revenge, or retaliation]; from vaA^arahu: (As, T:) or he slew the slayer of his relation. (Mgh.) And Talaba bivaA^orihi He sought to obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation; syn. Talaba bi*aHolihi. (S and Msb in art. *Hl.) And A^anaA A^aTolubu vaA^oriY Einodahu I seek my blood-revenge of him; syn. *aHoliY. (A.) And vaA^oriY Einoda fulaAnK My blood-revenge is a debt owed to me by such a one; syn. *aHoliY: meaning such a one is the slayer of my relation. (A.) ＝ -A2- vaA^orN also signifies, (A,) or vaAy^irN↓, (T,) One who seeks blood-revenge, or retaliation of the slaughter of his relation: and one of whom is sought blood-revenge, or retaliation of the slaughter of a relation: (T, A:) the latter primarily signifies a slayer; and hence, a slayer of a person's relation in vengeance, or retribution: (Ham p. 637:) and the former, one who is sought, or pursued, for blood-revenge; an inf. n. used as a subst.: (Ham p. 87:) the slayer of a person's relation; (S, M, A, K;) as also vaAy^irN↓: (A:) pl. of the former A^avoA=rN and A=vaArN [as above] (K) and vaA^oraAtN: (S, A, K:) the first of which three is [also] pl. of vaAy^irN. (T.) You say, huwa vaA^oruhu He is the slayer of his relation. (S.) And yaA vaA^oraAti fulaAnK O slayers of such a one. (T, S, K.) yaA vaA^oraAti EuvomaAna, occurring in a trad., which is also related with the substitution of taAraAt for vA^rAt, may be explained in the same manner; or it may mean O ye seekers of the blood-revenge of 'Othmán, aid me to obtain it; the prefixed noun TaAlibiY, or A^ahol, being understood. (Nh, TA. [See also taArapN in art. twr.]) vaA^orN muniymN [A slayer of one's relation who causes his slayer to sleep,] means one with whom the seeker [of blood-revenge or retaliation] is contented, if he find him [and slay him], so that he sleeps after; (S, K;) one who, if slain, causes the pursuer of blood-revenge to cease from the pursuit: (Ham p. 87:) or a person who is an equivalent for the blood of one's relation [and who therefore, by his being slain in retaliation, makes the avenger to sleep]: (T:) or a person of rank, or note, in whom [i. e. by the slaughter of whom] one has his full desire accomplished. (A.) In a trad. of Mohammad Ibn-Selemeh, relating to the day of Kheyber, occur the words, A^anaA lahu yaA rasuwlu A@ll~`hi Almawotuwru lilv~aAy^iri↓, meaning [I am for him, i. e. I am he who should slay him, O Apostle of God:] the seeker of blood-revenge [is for him of whom blood-revenge is sought]. (L. [The explanation there given is clearly shown to relate to Almwtwr.]) ― -b2- vaA^orN signifies also An enemy: pl. A^avoA=rN: so explained as occurring in the following words of a trad.; laA tugomiduwA suyuwfakumo Eano A^aHodaAvikumo fatuwtiruwA A^avoA=rakumo Do not sheathe your swords from your young ones, [neglecting to teach them the use thereof,] and so make your enemies to attain their desire of blood-revenge. (TA.)

vaA^orapN *
vaA^orapN: see vaA^orN.

vuw^orapN *
vuw^orapN; said in the S to be an inf. n. of 1: see vaA^orN, in two places.

vuw^uwrapN *
vuw^uwrapN: see vaA^orN.

vaAy^irN *
vaAy^irN: see vaA^orN, in three places. ― -b2- Also One who does not pity anything (laA yuboqiY EalaY $aYo'K) so that he may obtain his blood-revenge, or retaliation. (S, K.)

mavow^uwrN *
mavow^uwrN and mavow^uwrN bihi [Revenged, or avenged, by the retaliation of his slaughter; by the slaughter of his slayer: and also slain in blood-revenge, or in retaliation for the blood of a relation of the slayer]: these two expressions [thus] apply to one's enemy as well as to one's relation. (A.) ― -b2- Also, the latter, [simply,] Slain. (T, and Ham p. 87. [But retaliation is generally meant to be understood.])

Q. Q. 1 vuw^olila *
Q. Q. 1. vuw^olila He (a man, M, Mgh) had vaA=liyl [i. e. warts] come forth upon him. (M, Mgh, K.)

Q. Q. 2 tavaA^olala jasaduhu *
Q. Q. 2. tavaA^olala jasaduhu (T, M, K) biAlv~aA=liyli (T, TA) His person had vaA=liyl [or warts] come forth upon it. (T, M, K.)

vuw^oluwlN *
vuw^oluwlN, (T, S, M, &c.,) which may also be pronounced with the ' suppressed, [vuwluwlN,] (Msb,) [A wart; thus called in the present day;] a certain excrescence (M, Mgh, K) on the person of a man, (Mgh,) small, (K,) hard, and round, (Mgh, K,) and of various forms; one description being inverted; another, cracked and scabrous; another, pendent; another, nail-shaped, large in the head and slender at the root; another, long, and bent backward; another, opened; all arising from a thick, tough humour, phlegmatic, or bilious, or a compound of both these kinds: (K, TA:) pl. vaA=liylu. (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, (as being likened to the excrescence above mentioned, TA,) The nipple of the breast. (Kr, M, K.)

1 vabata vAb vbt vbtt
1. vabata, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
vabuta
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. vubuwtN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and vabaAtN, (S, M, Mgh, K,) or this latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) [unexplained in the S and M and A and K, as being well known,] It (a thing, S, M, Msb) continued, subsisted, lasted, endured, remained, remained fixed or stationary, stood, or rested; it was, or became, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: it obtained, or held: syn. daAma: (Mgh, Msb:) and Aisotaqar~a: (Msb:) [it stood, as a fact or truth; it stood, or held, good; it was, or became, a fact or truth, or a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] it was, or became, or proved, sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper; syn. SaH~a. (Msb.) ― -b2- vabata biAlmakaAni, inf. n. vuburtN, He continued, remained, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (T.) ― -b3- vabata AljaraAdu, and v~bt↓, and Avbt↓, The locusts stuck their tails into the ground to lay their eggs. (T.) ― -b4- vabat~u EalaY AlA^amori [I kept constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, to the affair]. (K in art. zmE.) ― -b5- vabata liboduka (tropical:) May thy case, or state, or condition, be permanent. (A, TA.) ― -b6- [vabata Einodahu ka*aA Such a thing was, or became, a settled, or an established, fact, or truth, with him, or in his opinion; it became established, substantiated, made good, or verified, in his opinion or estimation: like SaH~a. And vabata Ealayohi It was, or became, established against him. Hence, vabata lahu Ealayohi ka*aA Such a thing became established, or verified, as due to him from him: like SaH~a. And hence,] vabata is also syn. with wajaba [as meaning It was, or became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due: and it was, or became, necessitated, necessary, or requisite: so that vabata Ealayohi means also it was, or became, or proved to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on him; or it rested, or lay, on him; as a debt, or a duty: and it (a sentence &c.) became necessitated to take effect upon him: and vabata lahu it was, or became, or proved to be, due to him, or owing to him]. (Telweeh, TA in art. wjb.) ― -b7- [vabata lahu also signifies It belonged, or appertained, as an attribute, or a quality, or a property, to him, or it; it was affirmable, or predicable, of him, or it.] ＝ -A2- vabuta, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
vabuta
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. vabaAtapN (M, A, K) and vubuwtapN, (M, K,) He was, or became, firm in intellect, understanding, or mind: (S:) or firm, or steady, in fight, or in speech, or discourse: (M:) or intelligent, and possessing self-restraint: or seldom erring or making a mistake or committing a fault: (A:) or firm of heart in war: (Msb:) or courageous as a horseman, (K, TA,) earnest in the charge. (TA.)

2 vab~ata AljaraAdu vbt AljrAd
2. vab~ata AljaraAdu: see 1. ＝ -A2- vb~thu: see 4, in two
places. ― -b2- vb~thu Eani AlA^amori i. q. vab~aTahu [He hindered him, withheld him, or prevented him, &c., from doing the affair, or thing]. (M.)

3 muvaAbatapN mvAbp mvAbth mvAbtp
3. muvaAbatapN i. q. mumaAwatapN [meaning The vying with another in firmness, or steadiness, or the like]. (TA in art. mwt.) ― -b2- See also 4.

4 Avbt AljaraAdu Avbt AljrAd
4. Avbt AljaraAdu: see 1. ＝ -A2- Avbthu trans. of vabata, as also vb~thu↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) signifying He made it to continue, subsist, last, endure, remain, remain fixed or stationary, stand, or rest; to be, or become, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: he made it to obtain, or hold: [he made it to stand, as a fact or truth; to stand, or hold, good; to be or become, a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] he made it, or rendered it, sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper. (Msb.) ― -b2- TaEanahu faA^avobata fiyhi Alr~umoHi He thrust him, and made the spear to penetrate into him so that the extremity protruded while part remained within him; syn. A^anofa*ahu (M.) ― -b3- Avbthu biwivaAqK [He made him fast with a bond, or ligature]. (TA.) ― -b4- liyuvobituwka, (S, Mgh, K,) or liyuvab~ituwka↓, (CK,) in the Kur [viii. 30], means (tropical:) That they might inflict upon thee a wound by reason of which thou shouldst not be able to rise: (S, Mgh, K, TA:) or that they might confine thee [to thy place]. (K, TA.) You say, TaEanotuhu faA^avobat~uhu (tropical:) I thrust him, or pierced him, and confined him to his place, so that he could not quit it. (TA from a trad.) And Darabuwhu Hat~aY A^avobatuwhu (tropical:) They smote him, or beat him, so that they enervated him [and rendered him motionless]. (A, TA.) And A^avobata AljariyHa (assumed tropical:) He weakened the wounded man so that he was unable to move. (Mgh.) And A^avobatatohu jiraAHapN (tropical:) A wound rendered him unable to move: (T, * A:) and in like manner one says of a malady. (A.) And A^uvobita (assumed tropical:) His malady became violent, or a wound affected him, so that he did not [or could not] move. (T, TA.) ― -b5- Avbt HuH~atahu He established his evidence, or proof, and made it clear, plain, or manifest. (M.) ― -b6- Avbthu, (M, K,) inf. n. A_ivobaAtN, (TA,) also signifies (tropical:) He knew him, or it, certainly, or assuredly; and so vAbthu↓, (M, K, TA,) inf. n. muvaAbatapN. (TA.) And you say, naZarotu A_ilayohi famaA A^avobat~uhu bibaSariY (tropical:) [I looked at him, or it, but I did not know him, or it, surely with my eye]. (A, TA.) And Avbt Al$~aYo'a maEorifapF (tropical:) [He knew the thing certainly, completely, or thoroughly]. (A. [Explained in a copy of that work, followed in the TA, by qabilahu; but this is undoubtedly a mistranscription for qatalahu, q. v.]) ― -b7- Also, (i. e. Avbthu alone,) He verified it. (Har p. 175.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) He wrote it, [set it down, registered it, or recorded it,] i. e., a man's name, (A, Msb, TA,) fiY Ald~iywaAni [in the register of soldiers or pensioners or accounts]. (A, TA.) ― -b9- [And i. q. A^awojabahu as meaning He made it, or declared it to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, (Ealayohi on him,) or due (lahu to him): and, said of a sentence &c., as meaning he necessitated it to take effect, or necessitated its taking effect, Ealayohi upon him: see Haq~ahu. ― -b10- And He affirmed it; he averred it; i. q. A^awojabahu as contr. of nafaAhu. And hence, Avbthu lahu signifies also He made it, or declared it, or asserted it, to belong, or appertain, as an attribute, or a quality, or a property, to him, or it; he affirmed it, or predicated it, of him, or it. ― -b11- And He authorized it; namely a word, a signification, &c.] ― -b12- Avbt fulaAnFA He kept, clave, or held fast, to such a one; scarcely, or never, quitting him. (Msb.) And Avbthu Als~aqamu, i. e. [The malady clave to him;] did not quit him. (S.)

5 tvb~t fiY AlA^amori *
5. tvb~t fiY AlA^amori, (T, S, M, A, TA,) and Alr~aA^oYi; (T, TA;) and Astvbt↓; (S, M, A, K, TA;) He acted, or proceeded, [firmly, steadily,] deliberately, or leisurely, (T, M, A, K, TA,) in the affair, (T, M, A, TA,) and the opinion, judgment, or counsel; (T, TA;) not hastily: (T, M, TA:) both signify the same: (S:) [or] fiY A^amorihi Astvbt↓ he consulted respecting his affair, and sought for information respecting it, or investigated it. (T, TA.) [In the KL, tavab~utN is explained by the words drnG krdn w bhjAY A=wrdn, perhaps meaning The delaying in an affair and (then) executing or performing.]

10 Astvbt A^stvbt Astvbt {stvAb {stvbt {stvbtt
10. Astvbt: see 5, in two places. ― -b2- [Also He sought, or desired, or demanded, confirmation, evidence, proof, demonstration, verification, assurance, or positive or certain information, Eanohu respecting him, or it. ― -b3- And He desired, or meant, an affirmation: see a remark on a verse cited voce bayoda.] ＝ -A2- Astvbthu He found it to be sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper: (Har p. 175:) and he assured, or certified, himself of the true state of his case. (Idem, p. 426.) You say, Sag~ara Eayonahu liyasotavobita Aln~aZara (assumed tropical:) [He contracted his eye in order to assure himself of the correctness of the view; i. e., to obtain a sure view]. (M in art. wS.) ― -b2- It is also said to mean He made him, or asserted him to be, firm of heart: but Er-Rázee says, I have not met with this verb used as one that is immediately transitive. (Har p. 426.)

vabotN vAb vbt vbtt
vabotN: see vaAbitN. ― -b2- Also A man firm, or steady, of heart; (S;) and so vabotu AljanaAni; (A, Msb, TA;) pl. vubotN: (TA:) or a man who acts, or proceeds, [firmly, steadily,] deliberately, or leisurely, (A, Msb,) in his affairs: (Msb:) and a courageous horseman, (M, K, TA,) earnest in the charge; (TA;) as also vabiytN↓: (M, K, TA:) both of which signify also intelligent, and possessing self-restraint; or seldom erring or making a mistake or committing a fault. (A, TA.) And vabotu AlmaqaAmi A man who does not quit his station, or abode. (M.) And vabotu Alqadami [Firm-footed;] one who makes no slip in contention, or in fight. (A, TA.) And vabotu Algadari A man firm, or steady, in fight, or in speech, or discourse: (M, L, TA:) or whose tongue makes no slip in contentions. (S, TA.) ― -b3- See also vabatN: ― -b4- and vabiytN.

vabatN vAb vbt vbtt
vabatN Firmness of heart in war. (Msb, TA.) You say, lahu vabatN Einoda AlHamolapi He has firmness, or steadiness, on the occasion of the charge, or assault. (S, A.) And lahu vabatN Einoda AlHimaAmi He has firmness on the occasion of death. (L.) [See also vabaAtN.] ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) A proof, and evidence, or a voucher. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) You say, laA A^aHokumu bika*aA A_il~aA bivabatK I will not decide so unless on the ground of proof, or evidence. (S.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the day of doubt, [i. e. the day of which one doubts whether it be the last of Shaabán or the first of Ramadán,] vum~a jaA='a Alv~abatu A^an~ahu mino ramaDaAna Then came the proof, or evidence, or voucher, that it was of Ramadán. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (Mgh,) applied to a man, (A, Mgh, [in which latter it is said to be tropical when thus applied, but not so in the A,]) and sometimes written vabotN↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) One who is an authoritative evidence, or voucher, by reason of his trustworthiness in that which he relates: (A, TA:) or (tropical:) one who is trustworthy (Mgh, K *) in that which he relates: (Mgh: [in the K, only the pl. is mentioned:]) or (assumed tropical:) one who is just, or equitable, [in that which he relates,] and exact, or honest: (Msb:) pl. A^avobaAtN. (A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) An index, or a table of contents, in which a relater of traditions collects a list of what he has related from others, and of his sheykhs [who are his authorities]: said by some to be a conventional term of the relaters of traditions: perhaps tropical. (TA.)

vabaAtN vbAt
vabaAtN, a subst. from vabata, [or an inf. n., like vubuwtN↓, used as a simple subst.,] Continuance, subsistency, lastingness, permanence, endurance, remanence, remanence in a fixed or stationary state, a state of standing or resting, constancy, firmness, steadiness, steadfastness, stableness or stability, fixedness, fastness, settledness, establishment or a state of being established: &c.: and soundness, validness or validity, substantiality or substantialness, reality, sureness, certainty, trueness or truth, &c. (Msb.) [See also vabatN.]

vubaAtN vbAt
vubaAtN, (A,) or daA='N vubaAtN, (K, TA,) (tropical:) A disease that renders one unable to move. (A, * K, TA.)

vibaAtN vbAt
vibaAtN The two threads or strings, or each of the two threads or strings, of [the kind of face-veil called] a buroquE by which the woman [draws and] binds [the two upper corners of] it to the back of her head. (K.) ― -b2- And A strap, or thong, with which a camel's saddle (raHol) is bound: (M, K:) pl. A^avobitapN. (M.)

vubuwtN vbwt
vubuwtN: see vabaAtN.

vabiytN vbyt
vabiytN: see vaAbitN. ― -b2- Also Firm in intellect, understanding, or mind: (S, K, TA:) and firm in strength and intellect: (TA:) or firm of heart in war: (Msb:) see also vabotN. ― -b3- And, applied to a horse, Sharp, and light, or active, in his running; (M, K;) as also vabotN↓. (TA.)

vaAbitN vAb vAbt
vaAbitN part. n. of vabata; (M, A, Msb, K;) as also vabotN↓ (M, A, K) and vabiytN↓; (K;) Continuing, subsisting, lasting, enduring, remaining, remaining fixed or stationary, standing, or resting, permanent, constant, firm, steady, steadfast, stable, fixed, fast, settled, or established: obtaining, or holding: [standing, as a fact or truth; standing, or holding, good; having the quality of a
fact or truth, or a settled, or an established, fact or truth:] sound, valid, substantial, real, sure, certain, true, right, correct, just, or proper: (Msb: see 1:) dim., when it is used as an epithet, vuwayobitN; but when it is a proper name, its dim. is vubayotN. (T.) ― -b2- vaAbitN bimakaAnK Continuing, remaining, dwelling, or abiding, in a place. (TA.) ― -b3- AlkawaAkibu Alv~aAbitapu [and Alv~awaAbitu] The fixed stars. (Kzw &c.) ― -b4- sinuwna vaAbitapN Years lasting long. (TA in art. qEs.) ― -b5- qawolN vaAbitN A sound, valid, true, right, correct, just, or proper, saying. (M.) biAlqawoli Alv~aAbiti in the Kur xiv. 32 means By the assertion of the unity of God. (Jel.)

muvobtN mvbt
muvobtN Bound with the strap, or thong, called vibaAt; applied to a camel's saddle (raHol). (M, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Motionless by reason of disease (T, K, TA) that has become violent, or by reason of a wound: (T, TA:) or the same, (M,) or in this sense muvobitN↓, (K, TA,) (tropical:) heavy (M, K, TA) by reason of old age or some other cause, (TA,) and not quitting the bed. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- [kalaAmN muvobatN lit. An affirmed sentence; i. q. muwjabN as contr. of manofiY~N; virtually the same as kalaAmu muvobitN↓ an affirming, or affirmative, sentence.]

muvobitN mvbt
muvobitN: see muvobatN, in two places.

1 vabaja vbj
1. vabaja, (S, K,) aor.
vabija
, (K,) inf. n. vubuwjN, (S,) He sat with his but tocks against his heels, resting upon the extremities of his feet, (S, K,) as one does in performing the act termed AisotinojaA='N. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [vabija: see the next paragraph.]

2 vb~j biAlEaSaA vbj bAlESA
2. vb~j biAlEaSaA, (S,) inf. n. tavobiyjN; (S, K;) and bihaA tvb~j↓; (A, K;) He (a pastor, S, A) put the staff, or stick, upon, or against, his back, and put his arms, or hands, behind it: (S, A, K:) thus he does when he is fatigued. (TA.) ＝ -A2- vb~jhu, (S, A, TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He made it obscure; (K;) he did not make it distinct, or plain; (S, A, K;) namely, writing, (S,) [i. e.] handwriting; (A, K;) and speech, or language: (S:) he did not express it in the proper mode, or manner, namely, speech, or language. (A.) And vub~ija, inf. n. as above; [and app. vabija↓, aor.
vabaja
, inf. n. vabajN, q. v. infrà;] said of writing; [and of speech, or language;] It was, or was made, confused [&c.]. (Lth, TA.)

5 tavab~aja
5: see 2.

vabajN vbj
vabajN The part between the kaAhil [app. here signifying the base of the neck] and the back: (S, A, Msb, K:) or the circuit of the upper part of the kAhl, extending to the breast; as is shown by the phrase A^avobaAju AlqaTaA: [see what follows:] (Aboo-Málik, TA:) or the part between the shoulderblades and the kAhl: and the main part of the back, and the part in which are the places of curvature of the ribs: or the part between the buttocks and the base of the neck: accord. to AO, the part from the rump-bone, or root of the tail, to the hair of the withers [of a horse]: (TA:) also the breast of the bird called AlqaTaA: (K:) or the middle part of that bird: pl. A^avobaAjN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The middle (S, K) of a thing, (K,) of anything: (S:) and the main part thereof; (K;) so of a heap, or tract, of sand: (A'Obeyd, S:) and the higher, or highest, part of a thing: pl. [of pauc.] A^avobaAjN and [of mult.] vubuwjN. (TA.) (tropical:) The middle of the sea: the main part thereof; and of the night: (A, * TA:) the height of the middle of the sea, where the waves meet one another: the higher, or highest, parts of the waves. (TA.) mino vabaji Almusolimiyna (assumed tropical:) Of the middle class of the Muslims: or of the higher, or highest, or chief, class of them. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- The quality denoted by the epithet A^avobaju, q. v.; as also vabajapN↓. (L.) ― -b2- Incongruity and confusion of speech, or language: and obscurity, or indistinctness, of handwriting. (K. [App. an inf. n.: see 2, last sentence.])

vabajapN vbj vbjh vbjp
vabajapN A thing of the middling sort, between good and bad: (K, TA:) the fem. p is affixed because the word is changed from a subst. to an epithet: it occurs in this sense applied to the contribution termed Sadaqap. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also vabajN.)

A^avobaju *
A^avobaju Broad, or wide, in the part called the vabaj; (S, K, Msb, TA;) and large in the jawof [i. e. chest, or belly]: (TA:) or protuberant, or prominent, in the vabaj: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or humpbacked: (TA in this art., and in art. Ejr on the authority of Fr:) and having a projecting, or prominent, breast, or chest: (L:) dim. A^uvayobiju↓, occurring in a trad. (S, Mgh, Msb, * K.)

A^uvayobiju *
A^uvayobiju: see what next precedes.

1 vabarahu vbr vbrh vbrp
1. vabarahu, (M, TA,) aor.
vabira
, (M,) or
vabura
, (TA,) inf. n. vaborN, (M, K,) He confined him; or restrained, withheld, hindered, or prevented, him; (M, K;) as also vb~rhu↓, (M,) inf. n. tavobiyrN. (K.) You say, vabarahu biAl$~aYo'i, aor.
vabura
, inf. n. as above, He confined, restricted, or limited, him (a man) to the thing. (Msb.) And vabarahu Eanohu, (T, S, M,) aor.
vabira
, (T,) or
vabura
, (S, M,) inf. n. as above; (S, K;) and vb~rhu↓; (IAar, TA;) He, or it, restrained, withheld, hindered, or prevented, him from it; (IAar, T, S, K;) turned him away, or back, from it, (AZ, IAar, T, M, K.) And maA vabaraka Eano HaAjatika What restrained, withhold, hindered, or prevented, thee, (T, * S, A,) or retarded thee, (A,) or diverted thee, (T, A,) from [accomplishing, or attaining,] thy want? (S, A.) And Aln~aAsi maA vab~ara↓ What hath turned the people away, or back, and withheld, or prevented, them, from obeying God? or what hath retarded them therefrom? (TA from a trad.) ― -b2- Also, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He denied him, or refused him, or prohibited him from attaining, or debarred him from, what he desired or sought; he disappointed him, or caused him to fail of attaining his desire; rendered him unsuccessful; disappointed, or frustrated, his desire, or hope. (K.) ― -b3- He drove him away, expelled him, or banished him. (K.) ― -b4- He cursed him. (K.) ― -b5- Also, (M, A, Msb,) aor.
vabura
, (Msb,) inf. n. vubuwrN, (Msb, K,) He (God, M, A, Msb) destroyed him (M, A, Msb, K *) with a destruction from which he should not rise again. (M, A.) ＝ -A2- vabara, aor.
vabura
, (Msb,) inf. n. vubuwrN, (S, Msb, K,) He perished: (S, Msb, K:) he suffered loss; erred, or went astray; or became lost. (S.) [See also vubuwrN below.] ― -b2- Also, (M,) inf. n. vaborN, (K,) It (the sea) ebbed. (M, K.)

2 vab~ara
2: see 1, in three places.

3 vAbr Ealayohi vAbr Elyh vAbr Elyp
3. vAbr Ealayohi, (T, M, A, K, *) inf. n. muvaAbarapN, (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to it, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K, *) namely, a thing, (S, M, Msb,) or an affair, (TA,) as, for instance, learning: (A:) he was eager to say it, or to do it, and kept to it constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously. (IAth.)

6 tavaAbaraA tvAbrA vAbr
6. tavaAbaraA, (K,) or tavaAbarati Alr~ijaAlu, (M,) They two, (K,) or the men, (M,) leaped, or sprang, (M, K,) each upon, or at, the other, (K,) or one upon, or at, another, in war, or fight. (M.)

11 AivobaArarotu Eanohu AvbArrt Enh AvbArrt Enp
11. AivobaArarotu Eanohu I was heavy, or sluggish, and held back from it. (K.)

vubuwrN vbwr
vubuwrN Perdition: (Katádeh, T, S, M, K:) loss; a going astray; or becoming lost: (S:) woe: (Katádeh, T, M, K:) destruction (M, A, K) from which there is no rising again. (M, A.) Hence it is said that the people of Hell will call out, waAvubuwraAho Alas for destruction from which there is no rising again! (M, A.) In the Kur xxv. 14 and 15, vubuwrFA is in the accus. case as an inf. n., as though they said, vabaronaA vubuwrFA; and, being an inf. n., it is used as a sing. and pl. (Fr, Zj, T.)

vaAbirN vAbr
vaAbirN Suffering loss; erring, or going astray; or becoming lost, or perishing; syn. xaAsirN: so in the saying of El-Kumeyt,
mino raA^oYa mavobuwrK wavaAbiro
waraA^ato quDaAEapu fiY AlA^ayaA
And Kudá'ah, in asserting their relationship to El-Yemen, formed the opinion of one who is made to suffer loss, or to err, &c., and one who is suffering loss, or erring, &c.; mvbwr here meaning maxosuwr. (S.)

mavobuwrN mvbwr
mavobuwrN, as used in the Kur xvii. 104, Overcome; withheld, or prevented, from attaining what is good: (Fr, T:) driven away; expelled; banished; outcast: punished; chastised: (IAar, T:) cursed; accursed: (Fr, IAar, T:) made to lose, or suffer loss; to err, or go astray; or to become lost, or to perish: so in the saying of El-Kumeyt cited above, voce vaAbirN: (S:) in a state of destruction. (Mujáhid, T.)

1 vabiTa vbT
1. vabiTa, aor.
vabaTa
, [inf. n., accord. to rule, vaboTN,] (K,) or, as Sgh says, [judging from the part. n. vabiTN,] thus analogy requires that it should be, (TA,) He was, or became, stupid in his work, or action; and weak: and he (a man, and a horse, K and TA, said of a horse with respect to covering,
TA) was, or became, heavy, sluggish, or slow. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2, in two places.

2 vb~Thu Eani AlA^amori *
2. vb~Thu Eani AlA^amori, (Lth, IDrd, S, Msb, K,) or Al$~aYo'i, (TA,) inf. n. tavobiyTN, (S, Msb,) He hindered him, withheld him, or prevented him, (IDrd, Msb, K, TA,) and retarded him, (IDrd, K, TA,) from doing the affair, or thing; (IDrd, Msb, K, TA;) as also vabaTahu↓: (IDrd, K:) he diverted him from it, by occupying him otherwise: (Lth, S, Msb:) or he prevented him from doing it by inducing him to be cowardly and weak-hearted: (Msb:) or tvbyT signifies one's turning a man back, or away, from a thing that he would do: (Aboo-Is- hák:) or one's intervening as an obstacle between a man and a thing that he desires. (TA.) The verb occurs in the Kur ix. 46. (TA.) ― -b2- vb~Thu EalaY AlA^amori, inf. n. as above, He made him to pause, or wait, at the thing, or affair; (TA;) as also Ealayohi vabaTahu↓, (K, * TA,) inf. n. vaboTN; (TA;) syn. waq~afahu Ealayohi [which here has the meaning assigned to it above, as is shown by the explanation of the quasi-pass. tavab~aTa immediately following in the K: in the CK, we find, erroneously, waqafa Elyh]. (K, TA.)

4 AvbThu AlmaraDu AvbTh AlmrD
4. AvbThu AlmaraDu The disease scarcely, or never, quitted him. (S, K.)

5 tvb~T tvbT vbT
5. tvb~T [quasi-pass. of 2, He became hindered, withheld, or prevented, &c.; Eani AlA^amori from the affair, or thing. This signification and that next following are well known. ― -b2- ] He paused, or waited; [EalaY AlA^amori at the thing, or affair; as is implied in the K and TA;] syn. tawaq~afa. (K, TA.)

Q. Q. 3 AivobaA^oTaTotu Eani AlA^amori *
Q. Q. 3. AivobaA^oTaTotu Eani AlA^amori I held back, or hung back, from the affair, or thing, relinquishing it. (TA.)

vabiTN vbT
vabiTN Stupid in his work, or action; and weak: heavy, sluggish, or slow; applied to a man, and to a horse; (K;) to the latter, with respect to covering: (TA:) and a man who will not move from his place: (TA:) fem. with p: (K:) and pl. [of pauc.] A^avobaATN and [of mult.] vibaATN, (K,) and, applied to men, vabiTuwna also. (TA.)

1 vabana Alv~awoba vbn Alvwb
1. vabana Alv~awoba, aor.
vabina
, inf. n. vabonN and vibaAnN, He folded the extremity of the garment, and sewed it; (S, K;) [he made a tuck in the garment, to shorten it;] like xabanahu: (S:) or, (K,) i. e. vabana, (TA,) he put a thing into the receptacle [thereof] and carried it before him; as also tvb~n↓: and in like manner, he folded and sewed over a thing the doubled upper border of his trousers in front: (K, * TA:) or $ayoy^FA tvb~n↓ has this last meaning; and signifies also he put a thing into a vibaAn [q. v.] and carried it before him: (S:) and vabana fiY vawobihi, aor. and inf. ns. as above; (M;) and fiyhi Avbn↓, (M, K, as in the CK,) accord. to [some of] the copies of the K Avtbn, but the former is the right reading; (TA;) and vb~n↓; (M;) he put a thing into the receptacle [thereof] and carried it before him [in his garment]: (M, K: *) [see also A^axobana:] or you say, fiY vawobihi vb~nhu↓ he made it a vibaAn (or thing carried [before him]) in his garment: (T:) and tvb~n↓ vibaAnFA he made a receptacle in which he [so] carried a thing before him. (T.)

2 vab~ana
2: see 1, in two places.

4 A^avobana
4: see 1.

5 tavab~ana
5: see 1, in three places.

vubonapN vAb vbn vbnh vbnnh vbnp
vubonapN: see what next follows, in four places.

vibaAnN vbAn vbnp
vibaAnN A receptacle, such as when one folds the skirt of his shirt and puts in it a thing and carries it before him: (S:) or the part, of the garment, which is the place wherein one carries, when he wraps it around his body, or puts a portion thereof under his right shoulder and another portion over his left shoulder, then folds before him a part of it, and puts a thing in it; as also vubonapN↓: (M:) or the part, of one's garment, which is the place wherein he carries; folding its extremity, and sewing it, before him, and then putting in it some dates or other things: as also vabiynN↓ and vubonapN↓: (K:) and the extremity of the [garment called] ridaA=' when one folds it before him and sews it [and puts a thing in it to carry]: (M:) or a receptacle in which one carries a thing before him; (T:) and vubonapN↓, of which the pl. is vubaAnN, (T,) or its pl. is vubanN, like as the pl of xubonapN [which has a similar meaning] is xubanN, (Har p. 427,) the doubled upper border of the trousers or waist-wrapper, in which one carries [before him] fruit and other things: [see also xubonapN:] or, as some say, vibaAnN does not signify a receptacle, but dates that are put and carried in a receptacle or some other thing: and sometimes what a man carries in his sleeve; and vubonapN↓ signifies only what one carries before him, that is little in quantity: and what is great is not called vibaAnN. (T.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, A_i*aA mar~a A^aHadukumo biHaAy^iTK faloyaA^okulo minohu walaA yat~axi*o vibaAnFA [When any one of you passes by a garden of palm-trees, let him eat thereof, but not take for himself, or make, a vbAn]: i. e., when a necessitous hungry person passes by a man's garden of palm-trees, he may eat of their dates what will repel his hunger. (T. [See also another reading voce xubonapN.]) And one says, qadima fulaAnN bivibaAnK fiY vawobihi maA A^adoriY maA huwa [Such a one came with a vbAn in his garment: I know not what it was]. (T.)

vabiynN vbyn
vabiynN: see vibaAnN.

mavobanapN mvbnh mvbnp
mavobanapN A bag in which a woman puts her mirror and apparatus: (M, K:) of the dial. of ElYemen. (M.)

superEntry.head: vbw or vbY
superEntry.entry:
1 vabawotu lahu xayorFA baEoda xayorK vbwt lh xyrA bEd xyr
1. vabawotu lahu xayorFA baEoda xayorK, or $ar~FA, I sent him good after good, or evil [after evil]. (TA.) [See also 2.]

2 tavobiyapN tvbyh tvbyp wvb
2. tavobiyapN, [inf. n. of vb~Y, mentioned in the T and K, in all its senses, in art. vbY, and so in the M, except in the first of the following senses, which is there mentioned in art. vbY and also in art. vbw,] The act of collecting (K, TA) in successive assemblages (vubapF vubapF↓). (TA.) You say, vb~Ahu He collected it, namely, a thing, (M,) and water: (M * and TA in art. vbw:) and he added to it, and collected it. (M, TA.) ― -b2- The collecting what is good: and also, what is bad, or evil: thus bearing two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b3- [And hence,] The praising a man in his life-time: (AA, S, K:) or praising him time after time in his life-time: (TA:) or praising him much; as though relating to him collections (vubaAt↓) of praise: (Z, TA;) or the mentioning of the sundry good qualities or actions: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and the magnifying [a person]; or honouring [him]. (T, * K.) You say, vb~Y Alr~ajula, (M,) or vb~Y EalaY Alr~ajuli, (T,) He praised the man in his life-time: (T, M:) because the doing so implies the collecting his good qualities or actions. (T, * M.) ― -b4- [Hence also the contr. signification,] The blaming, or censuring, much; collecting blame, or censure, from this and that source. (TA. [The act. part. n. is rendered in the M agreeably with this explanation.]) ― -b5- The act of completing [and augmenting a thing]. (K.) You say, vab~i maEoruwfaka Complete and augment [thy beneficence, or bounty, or favour]. (T.) And vb~Y A@ll~`hu laka Aln~iEama [May God complete and augment to thee benefits, or blessings: or] may God send to thee benefits, or blessings. (TA.) [See also 1.] ― -b6- The putting a thing into a good, right, or sound, state, and augmenting it. (T, K. *) ― -b7- vb~Y AlmaAla He kept, preserved, guarded, or took care of, the property. (Kr, M.) ＝ -A2- vab~ayotu EalaY Al$~aYo'i, (As, S,) inf. n. tavobiyapN, (As, T, S, M, K,) I kept constantly, or perseveringly, to the thing. (As, T, S, M, K.) ― -b2- The inf. n. signifies also The keeping, (T,) or pursuing, (K,) the way, course, mode of acting, or the like, of one's father: (T, K:) or the doing, or acting, like one's father. (M.) ― -b3- Also The complaining of one's state, or case, and of one's want; and asking aid, or assistance, and vengeance, or avengement. (K.) vaT~N and A^avaT~u↓, (Lth, S, K,) but the former is the more correct and the more common, (Lth,) or the former only, (IDrd, and IB on the authority of Ibn-El-Jawáleekee, and K,) the latter being vulgar, (IDrd, K,) but AZ asserted his having heard the latter, (AHát, cited in the Jm,) [and the latter only is mentioned in the Mgh,] A man (S, Mgh) having no hair upon the sides of his face, but only upon his chin; syn. kawosajN: (S, Mgh, K:) or having a scanty beard: (IDrd:) or the former signifies having little hair in the beard, and in the eyebrows: (K:) or [when you mean the latter] you say rajulN vaT~u AlHaAjibayoni, (K,) a man having thin, or scanty, eyebrows; as also AlHaAjibayoni A^avaT~u↓; (TA;) the mention of the eyebrows being indispensable; (IAar, K;) and AimoraA^apN vaT~apu AlHaAjibayoni [a woman having thin, or scanty, eyebrows]: (S TA:) pl. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The former also signifies Human excrement or ordure; or thin human excrement or ordure; syn. saloHN. (Sgh, K.) [See also valoTN.]

(A.) ― -b2- And [hence,] $ar~N A^uvoEuwbN↓ (tropical:) [Evil that takes its course like a stream]. (A.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

vaEabN, (so in the S, expressly said to be biAlt~aHoriyki,) or vaEobN↓, (so in the K,) in some copies of the K, erroneously, mavoEab, (TA,) A water-course of a valley; a channel in which water flows in a valley: (S, K:) accord. to Lth, the rubbish and scum that collect in the channel in which the rainwater flows; but Az disapproves of this explanation of the word, and says that it signifies, in his opinion, the channel itself: (TA:) the pl. is voEobaAnN. (S, K.) One says, saAlati Alv~uEobaAnu kamaA saAla Alv~uEobaAnu, i. e. The torrent [or rather the torrents ran like the serpent called vEbAn]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also vaEobN.

(S, Msb.) ― -b2- [ray^yisu Alv~aEaAbiyni The basilisk. (Golius, from a Glossary.)] ― -b3- damu Alv~uEobaAni: see damN.

mavoEabN mvEb
mavoEabN [The outlet, or place of outpouring, of the water of a watering-trough &c.;] the place of passage for the water, in the side of a wateringtrough or tank: and a channel, or conduit, for water: (KL:) pl. mavaAEibu. (S, A.) You say mavoEabu AlHawpa [The outlet for the water of the watering-trough or tank]: (S, A:) and mavoEabu Als~aToHi [the outlet for the water of the house-top]: (A:) and mavoEabu AlmaTari [the outlet, or channel, for the rain-water]: (TA:) from vaEaba AlmaA='a “he gave vent to the water,” or, “made it to flow forth,” &c. (A, TA.) And mavaAEibu Almadiynapi, meaning The channels, or places of flowing, of the water of the city: (K, TA:) whence it appears that MF has erred in saying that mavoEabN signifies [only] a mizoraAb [or spout for conveying away water from a housetop &c.]: not a channel, or place of flowing. (TA.) [See also SunobuwrN, and lawolabo.]

vaEodN vEd
vaEodN, as an epithet applied to a leguminous plant, or to an herb, Fresh, juicy, or sappy; (S, A, K;) soft, or tender. (S, A.) You say vaEodN maEodN in this sense; (S, A;) the latter word being an imitative sequent, not [generally] used alone; but some use it alone: (S:) and it is said to be syn. with the former. (TA.) You say also ruTabapN vaEodapN maEodapN, meaning A fresh, juicy, ripe date. (IAar, TA.) And varFY vaEodN Soft, moist earth; (S, K;) as also jaEodN. (Sudot;.) ― -b2- [As a coll. gen. n.,] Fresh ripe dates: or dates for the most part in a state of ripeness: (K:) or ripening dates when they have become soft: n. un. with p: (As, S:) that which is ripening, but as yet hard and indigestible, is termed jumosapN. (As, TA.) [See busorN.] ― -b3- Fresh butter: so accord. to Is-hák Ibn-Ibrá- heem El-Kurashee, in a trad. related by him. (IAth, TA.) ― -b4- maA lahu vaEodN walaA maEodN He possesses not little nor much. (K.) [Here, again,] the last word is an imitative sequent. (TA.)

Q. 1 vaEolaba vElb
Q. 1. vaEolaba He (a man) was cowardly, and eluded, or turned away, or went this way and that, or to the right and left, quickly, and deceitfully, or guilefully; as also tavaEolaba↓: his doing so being thus likened to the running of the vaEolab. (TA.) And vElb minohu faraqFA [He was cowardly, and eluded him, or turned away from him, &c., through fear]; i. e., from another man. (TA.)

Q. 2 tavaEolaba tvElb
Q. 2. tavaEolaba: see above.

vaEolabN vElb
vaEolabN [The fox; canis vulpes of Linn.: but in the dial. of Egypt, the jackal; canis aureus of Linn.: the former animal being there called A^abuw AlHuSayoni, as it often is by the Arabs of other countries:] a certain beast of prey; (TA;) well known: (S, K:) applied to the male and the female; so that one says vaEolabN *akarN and vaEolabN A^unovaY; but if one would designate the male by a single word applying to it only, he says vuEolubaAnN↓, with damm to the v and l: (IAmb, Msb:) or the former applies to the female: (K:) or the female is called vaEolabapN↓; (Ks, S, Msb, K;) and the male, vuEolubaAnN↓ (Ks, S, K) and vaEolabN, (K,) [accord. to some,] like as one says EaqorabapN [and EuqorubaAnN] and EaqorabN: (Msb:) or vaEolabN is the male; and the female is called vuEaAlapu↓: (Az, TA: [but see this word is art. vEl:]) the pl. of vElb is vaEaAlibu and vaEaAlK, (K,) accord. to Lh: but ISd disapproves of this [latter pl.]; and Sb does not allow it except in poetry. (TA.) F charges J with error in citing, as a proof that vuEolubaAnN↓ signifies the male, the following verse:
A^arab~N yabuwlu Alv~uEolubaAnu biraA^osihi
laqado *al~a mano baAlato Ealayohi Alv~aEaAlibu
[Is he a Lord, upon whose head the he-fox makes water? (the b in brA^sh being syn. with EalaY: so in the Mughnee, in art. b:) Vile indeed is he upon whom the foxes make water!] said by a man who was keeper of an idol, on seeing a he-fox make water upon it: but in this, F opposes also Ks and others; and it is asserted by several authorities that the correct reading of the word vElbAn in a trad. whereby F attempts to establish his charge against J is not vaEolabaAni, dual. of vaEolabN, as he pronounces it to be, but vuEolabaAni, which is said to be the masc. of vaEolabN, like as A^ufoEuwaAnN and EuqorubaAnN are mascs. of A^afoEFY and EaqorabN. (TA.) ― -b2- daA='u Alv~aEolabi [for which Golius seems to have found in a copy of the K dawaA='u Alv~aEolabi] A well-known disease, [namely, alopecia,] (S, K,) in consequence of which the hair falls off. (S.) ― -b3- Einabu Alv~aEolabi [Fox-grape: rendered by Golius “ uvæ vulpinæ, i. e. solanum: ” but now applied by some to the gooseberry: and the solanum nigrum, or gardennightshade, is now commonly called Einabu Al*~iy^obi:] a certain astringent, cooling plant: seven (or, as in one copy of the K, nine) Hab~aAt [which here seems to mean berries] thereof, swallowed, are a cure for the jaundice (AlyaraqaAn), and stop pregnancy, (K, TA,) like the berries of the xirowaE [or castor-oil-plant], for the year, or, as some say, absolutely. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A hole, or aperture, (juHor,) whence rain-water flows. (TA.) [And particularly,] The outlet, hole, or aperture, (maxoraj, S and Msb, or juHor, K, or vaqob, TA,) whence the rain-water flows from the place where dates are dried. (S, Msb, K, TA.) And The place whence the water flows forth (L, K) from, (L, TA,) or to, (K, [probably a mistake,]) a watering-trough or tank. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- The upper extremity of a spear-shaft that enters into the head thereof. (S, K.) ― -b2- The lowest part of a palm-shoot when it is cut from [the root of] the mother-tree: or the lowest part of a [shoot such as is termed] rAkuwb, on the trunk of a palm-tree. (AA, K.)

1. vagarahu, (T, A, K,) aor.
vagara
, (K,) inf. n. vagorN, (T,) He broke it; (T, A;) namely, a part of a wall; (A;) he demolished it: this is [said to be] the primary signification: he demolished it, or pulled it down; namely, a wall: (T:) and he broke it (namely, anything, [as a wall and a vessel, &c.,] A) so as to make a gap in it, or a hollow in its edge. (A, K.) ― -b2- Also, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (Msb, K,) He broke his vagor [or front teeth], (S, Msb, K,) or his teeth. (IAar, and TA as from the K.) And vugira, in the pass. form, inf. n. vuguwrN, He (a boy) had his vagor [or front teeth] broken. (Msb.) ― -b3- vagarotu sin~ahu I pulled out his tooth. (El-Hujeymee, TA.) And vugira He (a man) had a tooth, or teeth, pulled out. (As, TA.) ― -b4- Also vugira, (AZ, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. vagorN, (AZ, Msb,) He (a boy) shed his central milk-teeth, (AZ, S, Mgh, K,) or his vagor [or front teeth]: (AZ, Msb:) or A^avogara↓ has this latter meaning, (A, K,) or Ait~agara↓; (As, TA;) and vagira, (K,) or Ait~agara↓, (Sh, TA,) or Ait~agara↓, (Msb,) signifies he shed his teeth: (Sh, Msb, K:) vugira is said to have this last signification in the Kifáyet el-Mutahaffidh; and Av~gr↓ and At~gr↓ are there said to have the contr. signification, explained below [see 8]. (Msb.) ― -b5- vugira also signifies He had his mouth bruised; and so A^uvogira↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- vagara Alv~ulomapa, aor.
vagara
, He stopped up, or obstructed, the gap, or breach: thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (K.) And vagaronaAhumo We stopped up, or obstructed, against them the gaps, or passes of the mountain; (S, TA;) we stopped up, or obstructed, against them the place of exit, so that they knew not what way to take. (A.)

4: see 1, in two places: ― -b2- and 8 also, in two places.

8 Ait~agara Atgr
8. Ait~agara (AZ, Sh, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and Aiv~agara (AZ, Mgh, Msb) and Aid~agara, (K,) originally Aivotagara, (AZ, S, K,) He (a boy) bred his central milkteeth, (S,) or his vagor [or front teeth]; (Sh, * Msb, K;) as also A^avogara↓: (K:) or he bred his teeth after the former ones had fallen out: (AZ, Mgh:) and A^avogara↓, inf. n. A_ivogaArN, of the measure of A^akorama, inf. n. A_ikoraAmN, he grew his vagor [or front teeth] after the former ones had fallen out: by some, Av~gr and At~gr are used specially in relation to a beast: the Benoo-Kiláb thus used the former; not in relation to a boy. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 1, in five places.

vagorN vgr vgrp
vagorN The front teeth; (S, A, K;) syn. mabosimN; (Msb;) described by a poet as eight in number, four upper and four lower: (TA:) afterwards applied to the central incisors: (Msb:) or all the teeth (TA) while they remain in their places of growth, (K, TA,) before they fall out: (TA:) or the teeth, (K, TA,) all of them, whether in their places of growth or not: (TA:) or the mouth: (K:) pl. vuguwrN. (TA.) [Hence, DaHika vagoruhu He laughed so as to show his front teeth, or his teeth.] ― -b2- Any gap, opening, interstice, or open intervening space, (M, K,) in a mountain, or in the bottom of a valley, or in a road along which people pass; (TA;) as also vugorapN↓: (A, * TA:) or the latter signifies a gap, or breach, in a wall &c.; the hollow of the broken edge of a vessel &c.; and its pl. is vugarN. (S.) You say, h`*ihi madiynapN fiyhiA vugarN↓ This is a city in which are gaps, or breaches. (S.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A frontier-way of access to a country, [in the CK, quruwH is erroneously put for furuwj, the word occurring in its place in MSS. of the K and in the S,] such as is a place of fear; (S, K;) as also vugoruwrN↓: (K:) the part of a country from which the invasion of the enemy is feared; so that it is like a gap in a wall, from
which one fears the invasion of the robber: (Msb:) a place from, or through, which one fears the enemy's coming, in a mountain or fortress: (T, TA:) the frontier of a hostile country: (K:) a place that is a boundary between the countries of the Muslims and the unbelievers: (IAth, TA:) pl. vuguwrN. (Msb.) You say, fulaAnN yasud~u Alv~agora (tropical:) [Such a one stops up, or obstructs, the frontieraccess of the country by his bravery]. (Ham p. 772.) ― -b4- And both these words, A man thrust or pierced [with a spear or the like]. (Ham ibid.)

viq~iyfN: see vaqofN, in two places: ― -b2- and see vaqiyfN.

mavoquwfN: see vaqiyfN.

1. vaqula, aor.
vaqula
, inf. n. viqalN (S, Msb, K, &c.) and viqolN, a contraction of the former, (Msb,) and vaqaAlapN, (K, TA, in the CK viqAlap, but) like karaAmapN, (TA,) It (a thing, S, Msb) was, or became, heavy, weighty, or ponderous. (S, K.) [See viqalN, below.] ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- [(assumed tropical:) It was, or became, heavy, weighty, or preponderant, ideally.] faA^am~aA mano vaqulato mawaAziynuhu, in the Kur ci. 5, means (assumed tropical:) And as to him whose good deeds shall be preponderant. (Bd, Jel.) [See also Kur vii. 7 and xxiii. 104.] ― -b4- [(assumed tropical:) It was, or became, heavy, or weighty, as meaning onerous, burdensome, oppressive, afflictive, grievous, or troublesome.] You say, vaqula Alqawolu (tropical:) The saying was [heavy, or weighty, &c.; or] unpleasant to be heard. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur vii. 186, vaqulato fiY Als~am`waAti waAlA^aroDi (assumed tropical:) It (the time of the resurrection) will be momentous, or formidable, [in the heavens and on the earth, or] to the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth, (Bd, Jel,) to the angels and men and genii; app. alluding to the wisdom shown in concealing it: (Bd:) or it means the knowledge thereof [is difficult]: (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) or it is occult, or hidden. (Kt, TA.) [vaqula is also said of a word, and of a sound, meaning (assumed tropical:) It was heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: see 2. And of an affair, or action, meaning (assumed tropical:) It was afflictive, grievous, troublesome, or difficult. In these and similar senses, it is trans. by means of EalaY: you say, vaqula Ealayohi (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, heavy, weighty, onerous, &c., to him. In like manner also it is said of food, meaning (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, heavy to the stomach; difficult of digestion.] You say also, vaqula samoEuhu (tropical:) [His hearing was, or became, heavy; or] his hearing partially went. (K, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, heavy in sickness, or disease: [and in like manner, in his sleep:] the verb is thus, with damm to the q; though said in the K to be vaqila, like fariHa, as meaning his disease became violent; (Fet-h el-Báree, TA;) not improbably through error or inadvertence. (MF.) ― -b6- [(assumed tropical:) He was, or became, heavy, slow, sluggish, indolent, lazy, dull, torpid, or drowsy; wanting in alacrity, activity, agility, animation, spirit, or intelligence; stupid.] You say, yavoqulu Eano qubuwli maA yuloqaY A_ilayohi (assumed tropical:) [He is averse from receiving, or accepting, or admitting, or is
slow to receive, &c., what is said to him]. (TA.) ― -b7- Also, said of the Earofaj, and of the vumaAm, (tropical:) Its shoots became luxuriant, or succulent, or sappy. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- vaqalahu, (JK, S, K,) biyadihi, (K,) aor.
vaqula
, (TA,) inf. n. vaqolN, (K,) He tried the weight of it, (JK, S, K,) namely, a thing, (K,) or a sheep or goat, (S,) by lifting it [with his hand] to see if it were heavy or light. (S, TA.) ― -b2- vaqala Al$~aYo'u Al$~aYo'a fiY Alwazoni, aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) The thing surpassed the thing in weight; outweighed it. (PS.) ― -b3- See also 2.

2. vq~lhu, inf. n. tavoqiylN, He, or it, made it, or him, vaqiyl [i. e. heavy, properly and tropically]: (K:) tvqyl is the contr. of taxofiyfN; (S;) and signifies the making heavy in weight [&c.]; as also vaqolN [inf. n. of vaqalahu↓]. (KL.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) He made it (a word or a sound) heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: and particularly a word by uttering hemzeh with its true, or proper, sound, which is commonly termed taHoqiyqu Alhamozapi, and opposed to taxofiyfuhaA; and by making a single consonant double; and by making a quiescent consonant movent: often occurring in these senses in lexicons and grammars: opposed to xaf~afahu.]

4. Avqlhu He, or it, (a load, S, or a thing, Msb,) [burdened him: or] burdened him heavily: (K:) or beyond his power; overburdened him. (JK, Msb, TA. *) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) In the latter sense, said also of a debt: and of sickness, or a disease: (JK:) or, said of sickness, or a disease, and of sleep, and of meanness, or sordidness, (tropical:) it [burdened him,] overcame him, and rendered him heavy. (K, * TA, * TK.) ＝ -A2- Avqlt, said of a woman, She became gravid; her burden became heavy in her belly: (S:) or she had a burden, (Akh, S, and Bd in vii. 189,) by reason of the greatness of the child in her belly: (Bd, Jel:) or her pregnancy became apparent, or manifest; as also vaqulato↓. (K.)

(IDrd, K.) And tvAql A_ilaY AlA^aroDi, (S and K in art. ArD, &c.,) and Aiv~aAqala AlY AlrD, the former being the original form of the verb, (Bd and Jel in ix. 38,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, heavy, slow, or sluggish, (Bd, Jel,) averse from warring against the unbelievers, (Jel,) and inclining to the earth, or ground; (Bd, Jel;) or propending thereto. (Bd.) And Aiv~aAqala A_ilaY Ald~unoyaA (assumed tropical:) He propended to the present world. (TA.) And tvAql Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He was heavy, or sluggish, and held back from it. (K.)

10. Astvqlhu contr. of Aisotaxaf~ahu; (S and K and TA in art. xf;) He deemed it, or him, vaqiyl [i. e. heavy, properly and tropically]. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) He deemed it (a word or a sound) heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear: often occurring in this sense in lexicons and grammars.] ― -b3- Ausotuvoqila nawomFA (assumed tropical:) [He was overcome, and rendered heavy, by sleep: and in like manner, maraDFA, by sickness or disease: and luw^omFA, by meanness or sordidness: see its pass. part. n., below]. (JK.)

viqolN vql
viqolN Weight: or a weight: syn. wazonN: (S, Msb, KL:) pl. A^avoqaAlN. (S.) So in the phrase A^aEoTihi viqolahu [Give thou him his, or its, weight]. (S, Msb.) See also mivoqaAlN. You say also, A^aloqaY Ealayohi viqolahu or viqalahu↓ [He threw upon him his weight: see mivoqaAlN, last sentence: and see jiromN]. (S in art. Awq &c., accord. to different copies.) ― -b2- And A load, or burden: (KL:) or a heavy load or burden: pl. as above. (K.) wataHomilu A^avoqaAlakumo, in the Kur xvi. 7, means And they carry your loads, or burdens; (Bd;) or your heavy loads or burdens. (TA.) ― -b3- A^avoqaAlN (as pl. of viqolN, K, or of vaqalN↓, Bd) also signifies (tropical:) The treasures, or buried treasures, of the earth: and its dead, or corpses. (K, TA, and Bd and Jel in xcix. 2.) ― -b4- Also (as pl. of viqolN, K) (tropical:) Sins. (JK, K.) So in the saying in the Kur [xxix. 12], walayaHomilun~a A^avoqaAlahumo waA^avoqaAlFA maEa A^avoqaAlihimo (tropical:) [And they shall assuredly bear their sins, and sins (of others whom they have seduced) with their sins]. (TA.)

vaqalN vql
vaqalN A thing, or things, that a man has with him, of such things as burden him: (Ham p. 295:) [and particularly] the household-goods, or furniture and utensils, (El-Fárábee, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, Ham ubi suprà, and Bd in xcix. 2,) and (accord. to El-Fárábee, Msb) the household and kindred and party, or domestics, or servants, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, and Ham,) of a man, (Ham,) or of a traveller: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) [or the travelling-apparatus and baggage and train, of a man:] pl. A^avoqaAlN; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K; *) with which vaqilapN↓ is syn., (JK, S, K,) as are also vaqalapN↓ and viqolapN↓ and vaqolapN↓ and viqalapN↓; (K;) as meaning all the household-goods or furniture and utensils of persons going on a journey. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also viqolN. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The requisites and apparatus, instruments, tools, or the like, of a man: (Ham ubi suprà:) as, for instance, (tropical:) the books and writing-reeds of the learned man: every craftsman has what is thus termed. (TA.) By the saying
kilaA vaqalayonaA TaAmiEN biganiymapK
the author thereof, Iyás Et-Tá-ee, means Each of our two armies, the possessors of the vaqalaAni [or apparatus, or weapons, &c., of war, is longing for spoil]: or an army may be termed vaqalN because it is heavy in assault. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b4- Anything held in high estimation, in much request, and preserved with care. (K, TA.) Hence the trad., A_in~iY taArikN fiykumu Alv~aqalayoni kitaAba A@ll~`hi waEitoratiY [Verily I am leaving among you the two objects of high estimation and of care, the Book of God, and my kindred, or near kindred]: (K:) or they are thus called because of the heaviness of acting in the manner required by them: (Th, TA:) or as being likened to the requisites and apparatus, instruments, tools, or the like, of a man. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b5- Also Eggs of the ostrich; because he who takes them rejoices in them, and they are food. (TA.) ― -b6- Alv~aqalaAni Mankind and the jinn or genii; (S, Msb, K;) because, by the discrimination that they possess, they excel other animate beings. (TA.) It may also mean The Arabs and the foreigners: or mankind and other animate beings. (Ham ubi suprà.)

viqalN vql
viqalN Heaviness; weight, or weightiness; ponderousness; gravity; contr. of xif~apN: (S, K, and Er-Rághib:) and preponderance: in its primary acceptation, relating to corporeal objects: then, to ideal objects. (Er-Rághib, TA. [See vaqula, throughout.]) See also viqolN. ― -b2- fiY A^u*unihi viqalN (tropical:) [In his ear is a heaviness, or dulness,] is said of him whose hearing is not good; as though he were averse from receiving, or accepting, or admitting, or slow to receive, &c., what is said to him. (TA.)

vaqolapN vql vqlh vqlp
vaqolapN: see vaqalN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A fit of drowsiness, or of slumber, that overcomes one: (JK, M, K:) and (tropical:) a heaviness experienced in the chest, (K, TA,) or in the body, (TA,) from food: as also vaqalapN↓: (K, TA:) or the former, or ↓the latter, (accord. to different copies of the S,) (assumed tropical:) a heaviness and languor in the body: (S:) and ↓the latter, (assumed tropical:) a heaviness that is experienced on the heart. (JK.)

vaqalapN: see vaqalN: ― -b2- and see vaqolapN, in three places.

vuqaAlN vqAl vqyl
vuqaAlN: see vaqiylN.

vaqiylN vqyl
vaqiylN part. n. of vaqula; (S, Msb, K;) Heavy, weighty, or ponderous: (S, K, and Er-Rághib:) and so in relation to another thing; preponderant: primarily applied to a corporeal thing: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and vaqaAlN↓ and vuqaAlN↓ signify the same: (K:) pl. viqaAlN and vuqolN and vuqalaA='u [which last, however, seems to be applied only to rational beings, agreeably with analogy]. (K.) ― -b2- [Like its verb,] it is also applied to an ideal thing. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Thus it signifies (assumed tropical:) Heavy, or weighty, in the sense of onerous, burdensome, oppressive, afflictive, grievous, or troublesome: momentous, or formidable: difficult: heavy, or not easy, of utterance; or heavy to the ear; applied to a word and a sound; and particularly to a word in which a single consonant is made double, and to one in which a quiescent consonant is made movent, like muvaq~alN↓: heavy to the stomach; difficult of digestion: heavy applied to the hearing: see the verb.] qawolFA vaqiylFA, in the Kur [lxxiii. 5], means (assumed tropical:) A heavy, or weighty, saying. (TA.) Aln~uwnu Alv~aqiylapu means (assumed tropical:) [The heavy-sounding n; as in yafoEalan~a &c.;] the contr. of Alxafiyfapu. (TA in art. xf.) ― -b3- It is also applied to a man, (JK,) meaning (tropical:) [Heavy in sickness, or disease; or] suffering a violent disease: (K:) [and (assumed tropical:) heavy, slow, sluggish, indolent, lazy, dull, torpid, or drowsy; wanting in alacrity, activity, agility, animation, spirit,
or intelligence; stupid:] and so is musotavoqalN↓: (JK:) which also means, particularly, (assumed tropical:) overcome, and rendered heavy, by sleep (nawomFA), (JK, * K, * TK,) and by sickness or disease (maraDFA), and by meanness or sordidness (luw^omFA). (K.) viqaAlu Aln~aAsi [expressly said in the TA to be with kesr, but in the CK, erroneously, vuqAl,] and vuqalaA='u AlnAs mean (assumed tropical:) Those men whose company is disliked; (K;) whom others deem heavy: each is pl. of vaqiylN. (TA.) One says, A^anota vaqiylN EalaY julasaAy^ika (assumed tropical:) [Thou art heavy, or dull, or unwelcome, to thy companions with whom thou sittest]. (TA.) And (to him who is vaqiyl, TA in art. nsm,) maA A^anota A_il~aA vaqiylu AlZ~il~i baAridu Aln~asiymi (assumed tropical:) [Thou art no other than one who casts a gloom upon others, and chills them: lit., heavy of shade, or shadow; cold of breeze]. (TA.) vaqiylN, applied to a man, is mostly used in dispraise: but sometimes, in praise: (Er-Rághib, TA:) used in praise, it signifies (assumed tropical:) Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (Kull.) Applied to a horse, (assumed tropical:) Slow; (Kull;) and so vaqaAlN↓ applied to a camel; (K;) a meaning also assigned to vafaAlN, with f; (TA;) and muvoqalN↓, applied to a horse or the like. (JK.) AinofiruwA xifaAfFA waviqaAlFA, in the Kur [ix. 41], means (assumed tropical:) [Go ye forth to fight] prompt and not prompt: (Katádeh, Bd, Jel, TA:) or whether moving be easy to you or difficult: (Bd, * TA:) or riding and walking: or lightly armed and heavily armed: or healthy and sick: (Bd:) or strong and weak: (Jel:) or rich and poor: (Jel, TA:) or young and old. (TA.)

muvoqilN, applied to a woman, Gravid; whose burden has become heavy in her belly: (S:) or whose pregnancy has become apparent, or manifest. (K.)

(Bd in xxi. 48.) maA yaEozubu Eano rab~ika mino mivoqaAli *ar~apK, in the Kur x. 62, means There is not hidden from thy Lord aught of the weight of the smallest ant: (Jel:) or a thing equal in weight to a small ant; or to the motes that are seen in a ray of the sun that enters through an aperture. (Hidáyeh, TA.) ― -b4- [A certain coin;] i. q. diynaArN, q. v.; (Msb in art. dnr;) a mivoqaAl of gold: pl. mavaAqiylu. (S, K.) ― -b5- A^aloqaY Ealayohi mavaAqiylahu He threw upon him his weight, or burden; syn. maw^uwnatahu [perhaps meaning the burden of supporting him]. (Aboo-Nasr, S, K.) [See also viqolN.]

musotavoqalN: see vaqiylN.

, (Msb,) inf. n. vakalN, (S, Msb,) or vukolN, (Mgh,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and vakolN, (Mgh,) [or this last is also a simple subst.,] She (a mother) lost him, or became bereft of him; namely, her child, (S, Mgh, Msb,) by death: (Mgh:) and vakilahu, aor.

vakalN: see vukolN.

vulaAvu and mavolavu↓ (S, L, K) Three and three; three and three together; or three at a time and three at a time; (L;) imperfectly decl. [because] changed from the original form of valaAvapN valaAvapN; (K;) or because of their having the quality of epithets and deviating from the original form of valaAvapN: they are epithets; for you say, mararotu biqawomK mavonaY wavulaAva [I passed by a party of men two and two, and three and three, together]: (Sb, S:) or they are imperfectly decl. because they deviate from their original as to the letter and the meaning; the original word being changed as above stated, and the meaning being changed to valaAvapN valaAvapN: but the dim. is vulay~ivN↓, perfectly decl., like A^uHay~idN &c., because it is like Humay~irN [dim. of HimaArN], assuming the form of that which is perfectly decl., though it is not so in the cases of A^aHosanu and the like, as these words, in assuming the dim. form, do not deviate from the measure of a verb, for maA A^uHayosinahu [How goodly is he!] is sometimes said. Then marry ye such as please you, of women, two [and] two, and three [and] three, and four [and] four: [meaning, two at a time, &c.:] here mvnY &c. are imperfectly decl. because deviating from the original form of Aivonayoni Aivonayoni, &c., and from the fem. form. (Zj, T, L.) And one says mavolava mavolava↓, like vulaAva vulaAva. (T.) You say also, faEalotu Al$~aYo'a mavonaY wavulaAva warubaAEa, meaning I did the thing twice and twice, and thrice and thrice, and four times and four times. (L.) ― -b2- [vulaAvN is app. fem. of vulaAvapN, a dial, var. of valaAvapN, of which the fem. is valaAvN: and hence,] *uw vulaAvK, with damm [to the initial v], A camel's [girth of the kind called] waDiyn. (K.) You say, Ailotaqato EuraA *iY vulaAvihaA (tropical:) [lit., The loops of her girth met together]; (A, TA; [but in a copy of the former, *Y valaAvihaA↓;]) meaning, she was, or became, lean, or lank in the belly. (A. [See a similar saying voce biTaAnN.]) And a poet says,
waqado Damarato Hat~aY badaA *uw vulaAvihaA
[And she had become lean, or lank in the belly, so that her girth appeared]: but some say that *w vlAvhA [here] means her belly, and the two skins, [namely,] the upper, and that which is pared, or scraped off, after the flaying: (TA:) or, accord. to some, the phrase is Hat~aY A@rotaqaY *w vlAvhA, meaning, so that her fœtus rose to her back; the vlAv [here again in a copy of the A written with fet-h to the initial v, and in like manner vlAvhA,] being the saAbiyaA=' and the salaA and the womb. (A, TA.) You say also Ealayohi *uw valaAvK↓, [so I find it written, but perhaps it should be *w vulaAvK,] meaning, (tropical:) Upon him is a [garment of the kind called] kisaA=' made of the wool of three sheep. (A, TA. [In the latter without any syll. sign to show that vlAv here differs from the form in the exs. cited before.])

vilaAv vlAv
vilaAv: see vaAlivN.

valuwvN vlwv
valuwvN A she-camel that fills three vessels (S, M, A, L, K) such as are called A^aqodaAH, (M, L,) when she is milked, (S, K,) [i. e.,] at one milking. (A.) This is the utmost quantity that the camel yields at one milking. (IAar, M.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel three of whose teats dry up: (S, M, A, K: [accord. to the TA, it is said in the T that such is termed mavoluwvN↓; but I think that this is a mistranscription:]) or that has had one of her teats cut off (IAar, T, M, L, K) by cauterization, which becomes a mark to her, (IAar, M,) and [in some copies of the K “ or ”] is milked from three teats: (T, M, L, K:) or that has three teats; (IAar, TA;) [and] so muval~ivapN↓: (T, TA:) or a she-camel having one of her teats dried up in consequence of something that has happened to it. (ISk.)

valiyvN vlyv
valiyvN: see vuluvN.

valaAvapN vlAv vlAvh vlAvp
valaAvapN, also written val`vapN, a noun of number, [i. e. Three,] is masc., (S, M, Msb,) and is also written and pronounced vulaAvapN↓, with damm: (IAar, M, TA:) the fem. is valaAvN↓, also written val`vN; (S, M, Msb;) [and app. vulaAvN also, mentioned above, under the head of vulaAvu, but only as occurring with *uw prefixed to it.] You say vulaAvapu rijaAlK [Three men]: and nisowapK valaAvu↓ [three women]. (Msb.) In the saying of Mohammad, rufiEa Alqalamu Eano valaAvK↓ [The pen of the recording angel is withheld from three persons] vlAv is for valaAvi A^anofusK. (Msb. [See art. rfE.]) [In like manner, valaAvN↓ occurs in several trads. for valaAvu xiSaAlK; as, for instance, in the saying,] valaAvN mano kun~a fiyhi HaAsabahu A@ll~`hu HisaAbFA yasiyrFA [There are three qualities: in whomsoever they be, God will reckon with him with an easy reckoning]: these are, thy giving to him who denies thee, and forgiving him who wrongs thee, and being kind to him who cuts thee off from him. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer.) The people of El-Hijáz say, A^atawoniY valaAvatahumo [The three of them came to me], and A^arobaEatahumo, and so on to ten [inclusive], with nasb in every case; and in like manner in the fem., A^atayonaniY valaAvahun~a↓, and A^arobaEahun~a: but others decline the word with the three vowels, making it like kul~uhumo: after ten, however, only nasb is used; so that you say, A^atawoniY A^aHada Ea$arahumo [and valaAvapa Ea$arahumo], and A_iHodaY Ea$oratahun~a [and valaAva Ea$oratahun~a]. (S.) The saying waladu Alz~inaA $arN Alv~alaAvapi means [The offspring of adultery, or fornication, is the worst of the three] if he do the deeds of his parents. (Mgh.) [It is said that when vlAvp means the things numbered, not the amount of the number, it is imperfectly decl., being regarded as a proper name; and so are other ns. of number. (See vumaAniypN.) See also sit~apN.] ― -b2- valaAvapa Ea$ara [indecl. in every case, meaning Thirteen,] is pronounced by some of the Arabs valaAvapa Eo$ara: and [the fem.] Ea$orapa valaAva↓, thus in the dial. of El- Hijáz [and of most of the Arabs], is pronounced valaAva Ea$irapa in the dial. of Nejd. (S in art. E$r.)

vulaAvapN vlAv vlAvh vlAvp

Alv~alaAvaA='u AlvlAvA='
Alv~alaAvaA='u, also written Alv~al`vaA='u, (Lth, T, S, M,) or yawomu Alv~alaAvaA='i or Alv~al`vaA='i, (A, Msb, K,) and Alv~ulaAvaA='↓, with damm, (A, K,) [meaning The third day of the week, Tuesday,] has this form for the sake of distinction; for properly it should be Alv~aAlivu: (S, M:) or it has meddeh in the place of the p in the noun of number [valaAvapN] to distinguish it from the latter: (Lth, T:) [it is without tenween in every case; when indeterminate as well as when determinate; being fem.:] the pl. is valaAvaAwaAtN (S, M, Msb) and A^avaAlivu. (Th, M.) It has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.) Lh relates that Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaY Alv~alaAvaA='u bimaA fiyhi [Tuesday passed with what occurred in it]; making vlAvA' sing. and masc.; [but this he did because he meant thereby yawomu Alv~alaAvaA='i; ywm being masc.:] Th is related to have said, bimaA fiyhaA; making it fem.: and Abu-l-Jarráh used to say, maDati Alv~alaAvaA='u bimaA fiyhin~a, treating the word as a numeral. (M.)

(T, TA.) ― -b2- Three cubits in length, or height; applied in this sense to a garment, or piece of cloth; (T, A;) and to a boy. (T.) ― -b3- A word comprising, or composed of, three letters [radical only, or of three radical letters with one or more augmentative; i. e., of three radical letters with, or without, an augment]. (T, TA.)
