vaAlivN vAlv
vaAlivN [Third]: fem. with p. (T, &c.) The final v in Alv~aAlivu is sometimes changed into Y. (M.) You say, huwa vaAlivu valaAvapK [He, or it, is the third of three]: thus you say when the two [terms] agree, each with the other; but not vaAlivN valaAvapF; vAlv being regarded in the former case as though it were a subst.; for you do not mean to convey by it a verbal signification, but only mean that he, or it, is one of the three, or a portion of the three: (Fr, ISk, T, S:) and in like manner you say, hiYa vaAlivapu valaAva [She is the third of three]; but when there is among the females a male, you say, hiYa vaAlivapu valaAvapK, making the masc. to predominate over the fem. (T.) When the two [terms] are different, you may make the former to govern the gen. case or to govern as a verb; saying, huwa raAbiEu valaAvapK or huwa raAbiEN valaAvapF, like as you say DaAribu zayodK and DaAribN zayodFA; and thus you also say, h`*aA vaAlivu A@vonayoni and h`*aA vaAlivN A@vonayoni, meaning This makes two to be three, with himself, or itself. (ISk, T, * S. [In most copies of the S, for vaAlivN A@vonayoni is put vaAliva A@vonayoni; and, in the explanation of this phrase, val~ava A@vonayoni for valava A@vonayoni: IB has remarked that these are mistakes.]) vilaAv↓ occurs in the sense of vaAliv in a trad. cited voce vaAnK in art. vnY. (Sh, T in art. vnY.) ― -b2- vaAlivapu AlA^avaAfiY means A projecting portion of a mountain, by which are placed two pieces of rock, upon all which is placed the cooking-pot. (S, K.) Hence the saying, ramaAhu A@ll~`hu bivaAlivapi AlA^avaAfiY [explained in art. Avf]. (TA.) ― -b3- [vaAliva Ea$ara and vaAlivapa Ea$orapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Thirteenth, are generally held to be indecl. in every case without the art.; but with the art., most say in the nom. Alv~aAlivu Ea$ara, accus. Alv~aAliva Ea$ara, and gen. Alv~aAlivi Ea$ara; and in like manner in the fem. Accord. to some,] you say, huwa vaAlivu Ea$ara as well as huwa vaAliva Ea$ara [He, or it, is a thirteenth]: he who uses the former phrase says that he means huwa vaAlivu valaAvapa Ea$ara, (T, S,) i. e. He, or it, is one of thirteen, (T,) and that he suppresses vlAvh, and leaves vAlv decl. as it was; and he who uses the latter phrase says that he likewise means this, but that, suppressing vlAvp, he gives its final vowel to the word vAlv, (T, S,) to show that there is a suppression: (S:) but IB says that the former of these two phrases is wrong; that the Koofees allow it, but that the Basrees disallow it, and pronounce it a mistake. (L.) [And accord. to J, one says, h`*aA Alv~aAliva Ea$ara and h`*ihi Alv~aAlivapa Ea$orapa This is the thirteenth, or this thirteenth: for he adds,] and you say, h*aA AlHaAdiY Ea$ara and Alv~aAniYa Ea$ara and so on to twenty [exclusive]; all with fet-h; for the reason which we have mentioned: and in like manner in the fem., in which each of the two nouns is with p. (S.) You say also, vaAliva Ea$ara valaAvapa Ea$ara [The thirteenth of thirteen]; and so on to taAsiEa Ea$ara tisoEapa Ea$ara: and in like manner in the fem. (I' AK p. 316.)

muval~avN A thing having three angles or corners, triangular [or trilateral]; a triangle. (S, K.) You say muval~avN HaAd~N [An acute-angled triangle]: and muval~avN qaAy^imN [A right-angled triangle]. (TA.) And A^aroDN muval~avapN A three-sided piece of land. (TA.) ― -b2- A thing composed of three layers or strata, or of three distinct fascicles or the like; (M, TA;) [see also mavoluwvN;] and in like manner what are composed of four, and more, to ten [inclusive], are called by similar epithets: (TA:) or a thing of three folds. (Lth, T.) ― -b3- [As a conventional term in lexicology, A word having a letter which has any of the three vowels: ex. gr., badoA^apN is muval~avapu AlbaA='i; i. e., it is written badoA^apN and budoA^apN and bidoA^apN. As such also, A verb having its Eayon (or middle radical letter) movent by any of the three vowels: ex. gr., bahaA^a bihi is muval~avN; i. e., it is written bahaA^a and bahuw^a and bahiy^a. And as such, muval~avapN (not muvolavapN) signifies Three-pointed; having three diacritical points: it is an epithet added to vaA=', to prevent its being mistaken for baA=' or taA=' or yaA='.] ― -b4- Wine ($araAb) cooked until the quantity of two thirds of it has gone; (S, K;) the expressed juice of grapes so cooked. (Mgh.) ― -b5- And A certain electuary, or confection, of aromatics, or perfumes. (KL.)

muval~ivN mvlv
muval~ivN A calumniator, or slanderer, of his brother [or fellow] to his prince; because he destroys three; namely, himself and his brother and his prince: (Sh, T, M, * K:) as also muvolivN↓; (K;) or thus accord. to Aboo-'Owáneh. (Sh, T.) ― -b2- See also vilovN, last sentence: ― -b3- and see valuwvN.

(TA.) ― -b3- A rope composed of three strands (Lth, T, S, M, A, K) twisted together, (Lth, T, A,) and in like manner woven, or plaited: (Lth, T:) and ropes composed of four, five, six, seven, and nine, strands, but not of eight nor of ten, are similarly called. (M.) ― -b4- A garment of the kind called kisaA=' woven of wool and camels' hair (wabar) and goats' hair ($aEar). (Fr, T.) ― -b5- mazaAdapN mavolawvapN A mzAdp [or leathern water-bag] made of three skins. (T. S, A, K.) ― -b6- A^aroDN mavoluwvapN Land turned over three times for sowing or cultivating. (A.) ― -b7- See also valuwvN.

, (K,) inf. n. valajN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) His heart became cool, or refreshed, and relieved of a thing: (IAar:) and he rejoiced; or was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy: (IAar, K:) and he was, or became, at ease, at rest, tranquil, or free from disquietude. vam~a vm
vam~a There; syn. hunaAka; (Zj, S, M, K;) a noun of indication, (Zj, T, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) denoting a place that is remote (Zj, T, S, M, Mughnee, K) from the speaker, (Zj, T, M,) like as hunaA denotes that which is near; (Zj, T, S;) or denoting a place other than that of the speaker: (Msb:) it is an adverbial noun, not to be used otherwise
than as such; (Mughnee, K;) indecl. because of its vagueness, and with fet-h for its termination to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters. (Zj, T, M.) Thus in the saying [in the Kur xxvi. 64], waA^azolafonaA vam~a AlA=xariyna [And we brought near, there, the others]. (Mughnee.) He who makes it decl. as an objective complement (Mughnee, K) in this ex., (Mughnee,) and in the saying in the Kur [lxxvi. 20], waA_i*aA raA^ayota vam~a raA^ayota naEiymFA, is in error: (Mughnee, K: *) Zj says that the meaning is, And when thou castest thine eyes, or thy sight, there, thou shalt behold [scenes of] enjoyment: that Fr asserted the meaning to be, A_i*aA raA^ayota maA vam~a [when thou seest what is there]; but that this is an error; for mA, accord. to this interpretation, is a conjunct noun, and it is not allowable to suppress a conjunct noun and leave its complement. (T.) ― -b2- [mino vam~a is used by postclassical writers as meaning Therefore; for that reason; on that account.]

vum~a vm
vum~a, (T, S, M, &c.,) for which one also says fum~a, (M, Mughnee,) substituting f for the v, (M,) and vum~ata (T, S, M) and vum~ato, (M, TA,) but vum~ata is the more common, (Mughnee and K on the letter t,) and fum~ata and fum~ato, (M, TA,) [meaning Then, i. e., afterward, or afterwards,] a particle, (M, K,) or conjunction, (Zj, T, S, Msb, Mughnee,) denoting order (Zj, T, S, M, Msb, Mughnee) and a delay, (S, Msb,) or having three properties, namely, that of virtually associating in the same case [the latter of the two members which it conjoins with the former of them], and denoting order, and denoting a delay; but respecting all of these there is a difference of opinions. (Mughnee, K. *) As to the associating in the same case, Akh and the Koofees assert that it sometimes fails to have this property, by its occurring redundantly, so as not to be a conjunction at all; and they hold to accord with this assertion the saying in the Kur [ix. 119], Hat~aY A_i*aA DaAqato Ealayohimu A@loA^aroDu bimaA raHubato waDaAqato Ealayohimo A^anofusuhumo waZan~uwA A^ano laA malojaA^a mina A@ll~`hi A_il~aA A_ilayohi vum~a taAba Ealayohimo [Until, when the earth became strait to them, notwithstanding its amplitude, and their minds became straitened to them, and they knew that there was no repairing for refuge from God save unto Him, then He returned to forgiveness towards them]: (Mughnee, K: *) but this has been resolved by the subaudition of the complement [of what precedes vum~a, as though the meaning were, then (they betook themselves unto Him, begging forgiveness, and) He returned &c.]. (Mughnee.) And as to its denoting order, some hold that there are exs. of its not necessarily implying this; (Mughnee, K; *) one of which is the saying in the Kur [xxxix. 8], xalaqakumo mino nafosK waAHidapK vum~a jaEala minohaA zawojahaA: (Mughnee: [in which are added other similar exs., one of which is given in the K:]) but to this there are five replies: 1st, that this passage is elliptical; the meaning being, He created you from one person (which He originated); then He made therefrom its mate: 2nd, that the meaning is, He created you from a person that was alone; then &c.: 3rd, that the progeny of Adam were made to come forth from his back like little ants; then Eve was created from his [rib called the] quSayoraY: 4th, that the creation of Eve from Adam being unusual, vm~ is used to notify its order and posteriority in respect of wonderfulness and of the manifestation of power; not to denote order and posteriority of time: 5th, that vm~ is here used to denote the order of enunciation; not the virtual order: the replies preceding this last are better than it, inasmuch as they verify the order and the delay; whereas the last verifies the order only, as there is no delay between the two enunciations; but the last reply is of more common application, applying to the ex. given above and to others: (Mughnee:) Fr says that the meaning of the ex. given above is, He created you from a person (which He created) single; then &c.; and in like manner says Zj. (T.) And as to its denoting a delay, Fr asserts that sometimes this is not the case, as is shown by the saying, A^aEojabaniY maA SanaEota Alyawoma vum~a maA SanaEota A^amosi A^aEojabu [What thou didst to-day excited my wonder, or admiration, or pleasure; then (I tell thee) what thou didst yesterday was more wonderful, or admirable, or pleasing]; for vm~ is here used to denote the order of the enunciation; not a delay between the two enunciations. (Mughnee, K. *) ― -b2- [It is said that] it denotes order and a delay when it conjoins single words: but Akh says that it has the meaning of wa [And], because it is used in cases in which there is no order; as in waA@ll~`hi vum~a waA@ll~`hi laA^afoEalan~a [By God, and (I say again,) By God, I will assuredly do such a thing]: and when it conjoins propositions, it does not necessarily denote order, but has the meaning of wa: (Msb:) it has the meaning of wa, (S, Msb,) the conjunction, (S,) in the saying in the Kur [x. 47], vum~a A@ll~`hu $ahiydN EalaY maA yafoEaluwna [And God is witness of what they do]. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- The Koofees allow its being used in the manner of fa and wa so as that the aor. immediately following it after a conditional verb may be man- soob: and Ibn-Málik allows its being thus used so as that the aor. immediately following it after the expression of a desire that the thing shall not be done may be marfooa and mejzoom and man- soob. (Mughnee.)

(A.) ― -b8- (tropical:) The knot of the extremity, (A,) or of the extremities, (K,) of a whip; (A, K;) because like a fruit in its form and in its manner of hanging: (B, TA:) and vamarN, the knots of the extremities of whips: (S, Mj, Mgh:) or the former signifies the end, or extremity, of a whip: (T:) or, more correctly, the tail, which is [the appendage that forms] the end, or extremity, of a whip; its Ea*abap. (Mgh.) ― -b9- (tropical:) The extremity, (T, K,) or tip, (A,) of the tongue: (T, A, K:) or its lower extremity. (IAth, TA.) ― -b10- (tropical:) A man's prepuce: pl. vimaArN: so in the phrases quTiEato vamarapu fulaAnK, and quTiEato vimaAruhumo, meaning (tropical:) Such a one was circumcised, and they were circumcised. (A.) [Another meaning of the former of these phrases has been mentioned above.] ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) The skin of the head. (ISh, T, K.) ― -b12- vamarapu Alqalobi [of which one meaning has been given above] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The heart's core; or the black, or inner, part of the heart; syn. suwayodaAw^uhu, and Hab~atuhu. (S in art Hb.) [Hence,] xaS~aniY bivamarapi qalobihi (tropical:) [He distinguished me peculiarly, or specially,] by his love, or affection. (A, TA.) And A^aEoTaAhu Safoqapa yadihi wavamarapa qalobihi (tropical:) [He gave him his ratification of the bargain, and] his sincerest agreement. (A, TA.) ― -b13- fiY Als~imaA='i vamarapN and vamarN (tropical:) In the sky is a small portion, or quantity, of cloud. (A, TA.) ― -b14- vamaru AlHin~aA='i: see art. HnA^. ― -b15- See also vamiyrN.

vimonN The eighth young one or offspring. (A in art. vlv.) ＝ -A2- One of the periods between two drinkings, or waterings, of camels: (S:) [or the end of one of those periods; namely, the night of coming to water which is] the eighth night of
a period between two drinkings, or waterings, of camels, (K,) [counting the night of the next preceding drinking, or watering, as the first: see riboEN and ximosN &c.] See also 4.

vamanN vmn vmnn
vamanN The price of a thing; i. e. the thing that the seller receives in return for the thing sold, whether money or a commodity; (Er-Rághib, TA;) the vaman of a thing sold: (S:) and also (Er-Rághib, TA) a compensation, or substitute, (Mgh, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA,) whatever it be, for a thing, (Er-Rághib, TA,) i. e., for a thing that is sold; but in the sense commonly known, such as it is incumbent upon one to pay, of pieces of silver, and of gold [or other money]; not commodities and the like: (Mgh:) or the value, or worth, of a thing; (K;) its qiymap: (T:) or the estimated value, or worth, of a thing, by mutual consent, even though it be really excessive or deficient; whereas the qiymap is its real value or worth, its equivalent: (MF:) pl. A^avomaAnN (T, Mgh, Msb, K) and A^avomunN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter used only as a pl. of pauc., (Msb,) and [so] A^avominapN. (CK: not in the TA.) The saying in the Kur [ii. 38 and v. 48], walaA ta$otaruwA biA=yaAtiY vamanFA qaliylFA is metaphorical, meaning (tropical:) And take ye not in exchange for my signs a small substitute: [i. e. purchase not in exchange for belief in my word the happiness, or enjoyments, of the present life.] (Mgh.) With respect to this saying, Fr remarks, when vamanFA occurs in the Kur, with bi prefixed to the name of the thing sold or bought, in most cases it relates to two things whereof neither is a vmn in the sense commonly known, i. e., such as pieces of gold and of silver: and such is the case when you say, Ai$otarayotu vawobFA bikisaA='K [I purchased a garment with a ksA', q. v.]: either of these may be termed a vmn for the other: but in speaking of pieces of silver and of gold, you prefix the b to the vmn [only]; as is done in [the chapter of] Yoosuf, [i. e. ch. xii., v. 20, where it is said,] wa$arawohu bivamanK baxosK daraAhima maEoduwdapK [And they sold him for a deficient, or an insufficient, price: for pieces of silver not many, so as to require their being weighed, but few, and therefore counted]: for pieces of silver are always a vmn: and when you purchase pieces of silver and of gold with the like, you prefix the b to whichever of the two you will, because each of them in this case is a purchase and a price. (T.)

(Har p. 42.)

vamaAniyapN vmAny vmAnyh vmAnyp
vamaAniyapN a noun of number, well known; [meaning Eight;] as also vamaAnK↓, (M, TA,) which is like yamaAnK, (M, K,) in form: (M:) the former is the masc. form: the latter, the fem.: (Msb:) this is not a rel. n. [though likened above to yamaAnK]: (M, K:) or it is originally a rel. n. from Alv~umunu, because it is the part, or portion, that makes seven to be eight, so that it is its eighth: they make the first letter to be pronounced with fet-h, because they make changes [in some other cases] in the rel. n., (S, K,) as when they say suholiY~N and duhoriY~N, [which are rel. ns. of saholN and dahorN,] (S,) and they suppress one of the two Y which are characteristic of the rel. n., and compensate it by the insertion of A, as they do in the rel. n. of Alyamanu [when they say yamaAnK, originally yamaAniYN, for yamaniY~N]: (S, K: [and the like is said in the Mgh:]) El-Fárisee says that the A of vamaAnK is the characteristic of the rel. n., because this word is not a broken pl. like SaHaArK; and IF assents to this, and says that were it not so, the p would be inseparable, as it is in EabaAqiyapN &c. (M.) You say vamaAniyapu rijaAlK [Eight men], (T, S, Mgh,) and vamaAniyapu A^ay~aAmK [eight days]. (Msb.) And when vmAn is prefixed to another noun, its Y is retained, like the Y in AlqaADiY: (S, Msb, K:) and it is decl. in the same manner as words of the class to which this last belongs: (Msb:) you say vamaAniY nisowapK [Eight women], (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and vamaAniY miAy^apK [eight hundred], (S, Msb, K,) [in the nom. and gen. cases;] and raA^ayotu vamaAniYa nisowapK [I saw eight women], pronouncing the fet-hah [at the end, in this case]. (Msb.) When it is with tenween, the Y is dropped in the nom. and gen. cases, but it is retained in the accus. case: (S, K:) [i. e.,] when the fem. form is not prefixed to another noun, you say, EinodiY mina Aln~isaA='i vamaAnK [I have with me, of women, eight], and mararotu minohun~a bivamaAnK [I passed by, of them, eight], and raA^ayotu vamaAniyFA [I saw eight]. (Msb.) It sometimes occurs, in poetry, indecl.: (S, M:) this is because it is fancied to be a pl.; (S;) or because it is likened, as to the letter, but not as to the meaning, to jawaAriYa. (M.) The people of El-Hijáz pronounce the masc. and the fem. with nasb in every case, in phrases like A^atawoniY valaAvatahumo and A^atayonaniY valaAvahun~a; and so on to ten [inclusive]. (S voce valaAvapN, q. v.) Th mentions vamaAnN↓; (TA;) and some instances of its occurrence are cited; but As disallows it. (T, Mgh, TA.) kisaA='N *uw vamaAnK means A [garment of the kind called] ksA' made of eight fleeces. (T.) tuqobilu biA^arobaEK watudobiru bivamaAnK [She advances with four and goes back with eight] is a saying of one of the muxan~avuwn of El-Medeeneh; meaning, with four creases (Eukan) of the belly, and with eight extremities thereof; each crease having two extremities, towards the two sides of the woman spoken of. (Mgh in art. hyt.) The saying Alv~awobu saboEN fiY vamaAnK should properly be fiY vamaAniyapK, (S,) which means, The garment, or piece of cloth, is seven cubits in length by eight spans in breadth; (Msb;) because the length is measured by the *iraAE, which is fem., and the breadth by the $ibor, which is masc.; but they use the fem. when they do not mention things; as when they say, SumonaA mina Al$~ahori xamosFA [We fasted, of the month, five], though meaning days: (S:) or because *rAE is fem. in most instances, and $br is masc. (Msb.) [But it is said that when vmAnyp means the things numbered, not the amount of the number, it is imperfectly decl., being regarded as a proper name: thus] you say, tisoEapu A^akovaru mino vamaAniyapa [Nine things are more than eight things]. (TA voce tisoEapN, q. v.) [See also sit~apN.] ― -b2- When you make it a compound [with the number ten], you say, EinodaY vamaAniyapa Ea$ara rajulFA [I have with me eighteen men]: and in the case of the fem., you may either make the Y to be with fet-h or make it quiescent, saying, EinodiY mina Aln~isaA='i vamaAniYa Ea$orapa A@moraA^apF or vamaAniYoEa$orapa [I have with me, of women, eighteen women]; but the former is the more chaste; and in one dial., the Y is elided, on the condition of [saying vamaAna Ea$orapa,] making the n to be with fet-h; (Msb;) or in this case you say vamaAni Ea$orapa, with kesr. (T.) A poet says, (T, S,) namely, El-Aashà, (K,)
falaA^a$oraban~a vamaAniyFA wavamaAniyFA
wavamaAni Ea$orapa waA@vonatayoni waA^arobaEaA
[And I will assuredly drink eight cups of wine, (a pl. of kaA^os, which is fem., being understood,) and eight more, and eighteen, and two, and four]: (T, S, K: but in the S and K, walaqado $aribotu; and in the K, and in one copy of the S, wavamaAna:) he should properly have said vamaAniYa Ea$orapa or vamaAniYo Ea$orapa, (accord. to different copies of the T and S and K,) but he elides the Y after the dial. of him who says TiwaAlu AlA^ayodi [for AlA^ayodiY], (S, K,) and he makes the n to be with kesr in order to indicate the Y. (T.) ― -b3- The dim. of vamaAniyapN may be formed either by suppressing the A, which is the preferable way, so that you say vumayoniyapN↓, or by suppressing the Y, saying vumay~inapN↓, changing the A into Y and incorporating into it the Y that is the characteristic of the dim.; and you may compensate for both [of these suppressed letters by saying vumayoniy~apN↓ and vumay~iynapN↓]. (S.) ― -b4- Alv~amaAniY is also the name of A certain plant. (As, T, K.)

vamaAnuwna vmAnwn
vamaAnuwna a well-known noun of number; [meaning Eighty;] sometimes used as an epithet: ElAashà says,
lay^ino kunota fiY jub~K vamaAniyna qaAmapF
waruq~iyta A^asobaAba Als~imaA='i bisul~ami
[Assuredly if thou wert in a well eighty fathoms deep, and wert made to ascend the tracts of heaven by a ladder]: he uses it thus as meaning deep. (TA. [But in this verse, as cited in the present art in the TA, A^abowaAba is put in the place
of AsbAb, which is the reading commonly known, and given in the S and TA in art. sb, and in the TA in art rqY-]) A^aHomaqu mino SaAHabi DaA^onK vamaAniyna [More stupid than an owner of eighty sheep], (S, K,) or mino raAEiY DaA^onK vamaAniyna [than a pastor of eighty sheep], as in some of the copies of the S, or, as in the Proverbs of Aboo-'Obeyd, mino TaAlibi DaA^onK vamaAniyna [than a demander of eighty sheep], (TA,) is a saying that originated from the fact that an Arab of the desert announced to Kisrà an event that rejoiced him, whereupon he said, “ Ask of me what thou wilt; ” and he asked of him eighty sheep. (S, K.) ― -b2- [It also signifies Eightieth.]

vumayoniyapN vmyn vmynyh vmynyp
vumayoniyapN and vumay~inapN and vumayoniy~apN and vumay~aynapN: see vamaAniyapN, last sentence but one.

vaAminN vAmn
vaAminN [Eighth: fem. with p]. (S, K, &c.) ― -b2- [vaAmina Ea$ara and vaAminapa Ea$orapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Eighteenth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva Ea$ara and its fem., explained in art. vlv, q. v.] ― -b3- A_ibilN vawaAminu, [the latter word pl. of vaAminapN,] Camels that come to water on the eighth night [after the next preceding watering]: from vimonN. (TA.)

A^avomanu *
A^avomanu Of more [and of most] price or value. (S.)

muvomanN mvmn
muvomanN Sold for a price: (Msb:) or having a price named for it, and assigned to it. (Mgh.) [See also vamiynN.]

muvominN mvmn
muvominN: see vamiynN

mivomanapN mvmn mvmnh mvmnp
mivomanapN A mixolaAp [or nose-bag]: (IAar, T:) or the like thereof. (S.)

muvam~anN mvmn
muvam~anN Octangular. (S, K.) ― -b2- A verse composed of eight feet. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Collected together. (T, TA.) ＝ -A3- Poisoned; syn. masomuwmN. (K.) ― -b2- Fevered; syn. maHomuwmN. (K.)

2 vn~n vnn vnp
2. vn~n He (a horse) lifted his vun~ap [or fetlock] so that it did not touch the ground in his running, by reason of his briskness, or lightness: (M:) [or] his vun~ap touched the ground in consequence of his being ridden by a heavy person. (T.)

4 Avn~ A^vn A^vnY Avn vnY
4. Avn~ He (a weak old man) became wasted and worn out. (K.)

5 tvn~n tvnn
5. tvn~n He pastured, or fed, upon vin~ [q. v.]. (T.)

vin~N vn
vin~N Dry herbage: (S:) or dry herbage when it lies heaped together, one part upon another: (T:) or dry herbage, (K,) or what has become dried up of HaliY~ and buhomaY and HamoD, (M,) when it is much in quantity, and lies heaped together, one part upon another: or what has become black of any branches, or twigs; not consisting of baqol nor of Eu$ob: (M, K:) or dry herbage broken in pieces: (IDrd, M:) or [simply] herbage, or pasture: (Th, M:) or herbage that is weak, and soft, or easily broken. (IJ.)

vun~apN vnh vnp
vun~apN, of a human being, (Lth, T,) The part below the navel, (Lth, T, M,) above, (Lth, T,) or extending to, (M,) the hair of the pubes, (Lth, T, M,) in the lower part of the belly; (Lth, T;) the part between the navel and the hair of the pubes: (S:) or the thin skin (murayoTaA=') between the navel and the hair of the pubes: (M, K:) or the hair of the pubes, (T, M, K,) itself. (M.) ― -b2- And, of a horse (T, S, M, K) and the like, (T, S, K,) The fetlock; i. e. the hairs on the hinder part of the pastern-joint, (T, S, M, K,) hanging down (S, M) over the part called A^um~u AlqirodaAn so as nearly to reach the ground: (S:) pl. vunanN. (S, M.) ― -b3- kun~aA fiY vun~apK mina AlkalaAmi wagun~apK (tropical:) [app. meaning We were engaged in light and confused talk] is a metaphorical saying, borrowed from the vun~ap of the horse and the singing [or humming or buzzing of the flies and other insects] of the meadow or garden. (A, TA.)

vinaAnN vnAn
vinaAnN Numerous, or abundant, and tangled, or luxuriant, plants or herbage. (T, K.)

vinotaAni vnp vntAn
vinotaAni fem. of AivonaAni, which see in art. vnY.

superEntry.head: Quasi vnw
superEntry.entry:
vanowaY vnwY vnwy
vanowaY and vunowaY: vanawiY~N and vanawiy~apN: AivonawiY~N: mavonawiY~N: mavonawiy~apN: see art. vnY.

1 vanaAhu vnAh vnAp vnY
1. vanaAhu, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) said in the K to be like saEaY, implying that the aor. is
vanaYa
, but this is a mistake, (MF, TA,) [for it is well known that] the aor. is
vaniYa
, (Msb,) inf. n. vanoYN, (S, M, Msb, &c.,) He doubled it, or folded it; (T;) he turned one part of it upon another; (M, K;) he bent it; (T, S, Mgh, Msb, TA;) he drew, or contracted, one of its two extremities to [or towards] the other; or joined, or adjoined, one of them to the other; thus bending it; (Mgh;) namely, a stick, or branch, or twig, (Mgh,) or a thing, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of any kind. (T.) One says of a man with the mention of whom one begins, in relation to an honourable or a praiseworthy quality, or in relation to science or knowledge, bihi tuvonaY AlxanaASiru, (T,) meaning With [the mention of] him, (T, and Msb in art. xSr,) among others of his class, (Msb ib.,) the little fingers are bent. (T, and Msb ubi suprá. [For the Arabs, in counting with the fingers, first bend the tip of the little finger down to the palm of the hand; then, the tip of the next; and so on; bending the thumb down upon the other fingers for five; and then continue by extending the fingers, one after another, again commencing with the little finger.]) And a poet says,
faA_ino Eud~a majodN A^awo qadiymN limaEo$arK
faqawomiY bihimo tuvonaY hunaAka lA^aSaAbiEu
[And if glory, or any old ground of pretension to honour, be reckoned as belonging to a body of men, it is my people, with the mention of them, in that case, the fingers are bent]; meaning that they are reckoned as the best; (IAar, M;) for the best are not many. (M.) One says also, vanaY warikahu fanazala [lit. He bent his hip, and alighted], meaning he alighted from his beast. (T.) And vanaY rijolahu Eano daAb~atihi, meaning He drew up his leg to his thigh, and alighted. (M.) But qabola A^ano yavoniYa rijolahu, occurring in a trad., means Before he turned his leg from the position in which it was in the pronouncing of the testimony of the faith. (IAth.) vanaY Sadorahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, [lit. He folded his breast, or bosom,] means (assumed tropical:) he concealed enmity in his breast, or bosom: or he folded up what was in it, in concealment. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xi. 5], A^alaA A_in~ahumo yavonawna Suduwrahumo, meaning [Now surely] they infold and conceal [in their bosoms] enmity and hatred: (Fr, T:) or they bend their breasts, or bosoms, and fold up, and conceal, what is therein: (Zj, T:) I'Ab read, Suduwruhumo tavonawoniY↓: you say, AivonawonaY Sadoruhu EalaY AlbagoDaA='i, meaning his breast, or bosom, infolded, or concealed, vehement hatred: (T:) or the phrase in the Kur, accord. to the former reading, means they bend, or turn, their breasts, or bosoms, from the truth; they turn themselves away therefrom: or they incline their breasts, or bosoms, to unbelief, and enmity to the Prophet: or they turn their backs: (Bd:) [for] ― -b2- vanaAhu, (T, S, Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (T, Msb, TA,) also signifies He turned him, or it, away or back. (T, S, Msb, TA.) Also He turned him, or turned him away or back, (Lth, T, S,) from the course that he desired to pursue, (Lth, T,) or from the object of his want: (S:) or you say, vanaAhu Eano wajohihi, (Mgh,) and Eano HaAjatihi, (TA,) and Eano muraAdihi, (Msb,) he turned him, or turned him away or back, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) from his course, (Mgh,) and from the object of his want, (TA,) and from the object of his desire. (Msb.) One says also, fulaAnN laA yuvonaY Eano qironihi walaA Eano wajohihi [Such a one will not be turned, or turned away or back, from his antagonist, nor from his course]. (T.) ― -b3- Also He tied it; or tied it in a knot or knots; or tied it firmly, fast, or strongly. (TA.) You say, vanayotu AlbaEiyra bivinaAyayoni, meaning, accord. to As, as related by A'Obeyd, I bound both the fore legs of the camel with two bonds: but correctly, I bound the two fore legs of the camel with the two ends of a rope; the last word meaning a single rope: (T:) Eaqalotuhu bivanoyayoni means I bound one of his fore shanks to the arm with two ties, or tyings. (T, M.) ― -b4- vanoYN [as inf. n. of vanaY] also signifies The act of drawing, or joining, or adjoining, one [thing] to another; (Lth, T, Mgh;) and so tavoniyapN↓ [inf. n. of vn~Y]. (Mgh.) ― -b5- [As valavahumo signifies “ he took the third of their property, ” and “ he made them, with himself, three, ” and other verbs of number are used in similar senses, so] vanaAhu signifies He took the half of their property: or he drew, or adjoined, to him what became with him two: (TA:) or vanayotuhu, (S, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb,) signifies I became (S, Msb) to him, (S,)
or with him, (Msb,) a second; (S, Msb;) or I was a second to him, or it: (Er-Rághib:) or one should not say thus, but that AZ says, (M,) huwa waAHidN faA@vonihi (M, K [but in the latter, h`*aA in the place of huwa, and in the CK, fA^avonih↓,]) he is one, and be thou a second to him. (M, K.) ― -b6- vanaY, aor. as above, also signifies He made eleven to be twelve. (T in art. vlv.) ― -b7- vanaY AlA^aroDa, inf. n. as above, He turned over the land, or ground, twice for sowing, or cultivating: (Mgh, and A * and TA * in art. vlv:) and tavoniyapN↓ [inf. n. of vn~Y] and vunuyaAnN [app. another inf. n. of vanaY, and app. correctly written vunoyaAnN] are often used by [the Imám] Mohammad in the sense of vanoYN: he who explains tavoniyapN as signifying the turning over [the land, or ground,] for sowing, or cultivating, after the harvest, or as signifying the restoring land to its owner turned over for sowing, or cultivating, commits an inadvertence. (Mgh.) ― -b8- faA@voniniY, occurring in a poem of Kutheiyir 'Azzeh, is explained as meaning Then give thou to me a second time: (M, TA:) but this is strange: (TA:) [ISd says,] I have not seen it in any other instance. (M.) ― -b9- laA yavoniY walaA yavolivu, (a phrase mentioned by IAar, M,) or walaA yuval~ivu laA yuvan~iY↓, or walaA yuvolivu laA yuvoniY↓: see 1 in art. vlv.

2 vn~Ahu vnAh vnAp vnY
2. vn~Ahu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. tavoniyapN, (S, K,) He made it two; or called it two. (S, M, MS b, K.) [Hence,] van~aY means also He counted two; whence the saying, fulaAnN yuvan~iY walaA yuval~ivu; see art. vlv: (A and TA in art. vlv:) [and so, app., Aiv~anaY↓; for] a poet says,
badaA biA^abiY vum~a A@v~anaY biA^abiY A^abiY
[which seems plainly to mean He began with my father; then counted two with the father of my father]. (M.) ― -b2- [He dualized it, namely, a word; made it to have a dual. ― -b3- He marked it with two points, namely, a t or a Y.] ― -b4- He repeated it; iterated it. (Mgh.) See 1, in three places. ― -b5- vn~Y liA@moraA^atihi, or EinodahaA, He remained two nights with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA voce sab~aEa.) ― -b6- vn~Y biAlA^amori He did the thing immediately after another thing. (T.) ― -b7- tavoniyapN also signifies A man's requesting others [who are playing with him at the game called Almayosir] to return, for [a chance of] the stakes, his arrow, when it has been successful, and he has been secure, and has won. (Lh, M.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 A^avonato *
4. A^avonato, or Aivotanato↓, She brought forth her second offspring. (TA in art. bkr.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places. ― -b3- AvnY, (inf. n. A_ivonaA='N, TA,) He shed his tooth called the vaniy~ap; (S, Mgh, Msb;) he became what is termed vuniY~; said of a camel [&c.]: (M, K:) he shed his rawaADiE [pl. of raADiEap which is the same, in this case, as vaniy~ap]; said of a horse [&c.]. (IAar, T.) ＝ -A2- AvnY Ealayohi, (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. A_ivonaA='N; (T;) and vn~Y↓, inf. n. tavoniyapN, accord. to the K, but this is a mistake for vb~Y↓, inf. n. tavobiyapN; (TA;) He praised, eulogized, commended, or spoke well of, him: and he dispraised, censured, discommended, or spoke ill of, him: (T, * M, Msb, K:) the object is either God or a man: (T:) or it has the former meaning only: (M, K;) or the former meaning is the more common: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, AvnY signifies he spoke, or said, well, or good; and ill, or evil; and AnvY, “he defamed,” or “did so in the absence of the object;” and “he disdained, scorned, shunned, disliked, or hated,” a thing: (T:) and you say, AvnY Ealayohi xayorFA [He spoke, or said, well, or good, of him]; (S, and TA from a trad.;) and $ar~FA [ill, or evil], also. (TA from the same trad.) One says also, A^avonayotu fiEolahu [I praised his deed]; meaning EalaY fiEolihi; or because A^avonaY means madaHa. (Ham p. 696.)

5 tvn~Y A^vnY tvnY tvny vnY
5. tvn~Y: see 7. ― -b2- Also He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side; syn. tamaAyala: (Har pp. 269 and 271:) and he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side; or with a twisting of the back, and with extended steps; syn. tabaxotara. (Idem p. 271.) You say, tvn~Y fiY mi$oyatihi (S, and Har p. 269) He affected an inclining of his body, or a bending, or he inclined his body, or bent, from side to side, in his gait. (Har ib.) [And in like manner, and more commonly, one says of a woman.]

7 AnvnY A^nv A^nvnY A^nvny AnvnY Anvny {nvnY
7. AnvnY, (T, S, M, K,) and tvn~Y↓, and Aiv~anaY↓, of the measure AifotaEala, (M, K,) originally AivotanaY, (M,) and AivonawonaY↓, (T, S, K,) of the measure AifoEawoEala, (T, S,) It was, or became, doubled, or folded; (T;) it had one part turned upon another; (M, K;) it was, or became, bent. (T, S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AnvnY signifies also He turned, or turned away or back, (Har pp. 44 and 120,) Eano A^amorK from an affair, after having determined to do it. (Lth in TA art. zmE.)

8 A_ivotanaYa
8: see 7, and 4: ― -b2- and see also 2.

10 AstvnAhu AstvnAh AstvnAp {stvnAh {stvnY
10. AstvnAhu He set it aside as excluded; or he excluded it, or excepted it; mino $aYo'K from a thing; syn. HaA$aAhu: (M:) or he set it aside, or apart, for himself: and in the conventional language of the grammarians, [he excepted it; i. e.] he excluded it from the predicament in which another thing was included, or in which other things were included: (Mgh:) AlA@isotivonaA='u [in grammar] is the turning away the agent from reaching the object of the AisotivonaA=': (Msb:) in the case of an oath [and the like], it means the saying A_ino $aA='a A@ll~`hu [If God will]. (Mgh.) [See vunoyaA.]

12 AvnwnY A^vnY A^vnwny AvnwnY Avnwny
12. AvnwnY: see 7; and see also 1.

vinoYN vnY vny
vinoYN A duplication, or doubling, of a thing: (T, * S, Msb:) pl. A^avonaA='N; (S, Msb;) or the sing. may be vanFY↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- A folding: so in the saying, A^anofa*otu ka*aA vinoYa kitaAbiY, (S, TA,) or fiY vinoYi kitaAbiYi (so in a copy of the S,) i. e., fiY Tay~ihi [lit. I sent, or transmitted, such a thing within the folding of my writing, or letter; meaning infolded, or enclosed, in it; and included in it]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- A duplicature, or fold, of a garment, or piece of cloth: (TA:) or what is turned back of the extremities thereof: (T:) pl. as above: whence, in a trad. of Aboo-Hureyreh, kaAna yavoniyhi Ealayohi A^avonaA='F mino saEatihi [He used to fold it upon him in folds by reason of its width]; meaning the garment. (TA.) [Hence the saying,] wakaAna *`lika fiY A^avonaA='i ka*aA, i. e., fY guDuwnihi [lit And that was in the folds, meaning, in the midst, of such a thing, or such an affair, or event]. (TA.) And jaAw^uwA fiY A^avonaA='i AlA^amori They came in the midst of the affair, or event. (Msb.) [And hence, app.,] maDaY vinoYN mina All~ayol An hour, or a period, or a short portion, of the night passed; (M, K; *) syn. saAEapN, (Th, M, K,) or waqotN. (Lh, M, K.) [See also what is said below respecting its pl. in relation to a night.] ― -b4- Also sing. of A^avonaA='N meaning The parts of a thing that are laid together like the strands of a rope, or that are laid one upon another as layers or strata, or side by side as the things that compose a bundle; (quwaAhu, and TaAqaAtuhu; [rendered by Freytag “ virtutes, facultates rei; ”]) and mavaAnK↓, of which the sing. is mavonaApN↓ and mivonaApN↓, signifies the same. (M, K.) ― -b5- Also A bending of the neck of a sheep, or goat, not in consequence of disease: (K: but in the M, vanoYN [inf. n. of 1]:) and a serpent's bending, or folding, of itself: (M, K:) and also (thus in the M, but in the K “or”) a curved part of a serpent that has folded itself; (M, K;) pl. A^avonaA='N, (M,) i. e. the folds of a coiled serpent. (T.) The pl. is used metaphorically [as though meaning (tropical:) The turns] of a night. (M. [But see explanations of the sing. as used in relation to a night in what precedes.] ― -b6- A part that is bent, or folded, or doubled, of a wi$aAH [q. v.]; (TA;) pl. as above: (T, TA:) and so of a rope: (S:) or a portion of the extremity of a rope folded, or doubled, [so as to form a loop,] for binding therewith the pastern of the fore leg of a beast, to serve as a tether. (T.) Tarafeh says,
laEamoruka A_in~a Almawota maA A^axoTaA^a AlfataY
lakaAlT~iwali AlmuroxaY wavinoyaAhu biAloyadi
[By thy life, death, while missing the strong young man, is like the tether that is slackened while the two folded extremities thereof are upon the fore leg, or in the hand: see TiwalN]: (T, S:) he means that the young man must inevitably die, though his term of life be protracted; like as the beast, though his tether be lengthened and slackened, cannot escape, being withheld by its two extremities: (so in a copy of the T:) or by vnyAh he means its extremity; using the dual form because it is folded, or doubled, upon the pastern, and tied with a double tie: (so in another copy of the T:) or he means, while its two extremities are in the hand of its owner: (EM p. 91:) by mA AxTA^, he means fiY A_ixoTaAy^ihi, (S in art. Twl,) or mud~apa A_ixoTaAy^ihi: and the l [prefixed to the k of comparison] is for corroboration. (EM ubi suprá.) You say also, rab~aqa A^avonaA='a AlHaboli, meaning He made loops in the middle of the rope to put upon the necks of the young lambs or kids. (T.) ― -b7- Also A bend, or place of bending, of a valley, (S, M, * K,) and of a mountain: (S:) pl. as above: (M,
K:) and mavaAnK↓ [likewise] signifies the bends of a valley. (T, K.) ＝ -A2- A she-camel that has brought forth twice, (S,) or two, (M,) or a second time: (K:) or, as some say, that has brought forth once: but the former is more analogical: (M:) one does not say vilovN [as meaning “ that has brought forth thrice ”], nor use any similar epithet above this: (S, TA:) pl. vunaA='N, like Zuw^aArN pl. of Ziy^orN, accord. to Sb, (M, TA,) and A^avonaA='N accord. to others: (TA:) in like manner it is applied to a woman, (S, M,) metaphorically: (M:) and to the she-camel's second young one: (S, M:) accord. to As, as related by A'Obeyd, a she-camel that has brought forth once: also that has brought forth twice: [so says Az, but he adds,] but what I have heard from the Arabs is this; that they term a she-camel that has brought forth her first young one bikor; and her first young one, her bikor; and when she brought forth a second, she is termed vinoYN; and her young one, her vinoY: and this is what is correct. (T.) [Hence the saying,] maA h`*aA AlA^amoru minoka bikorFA walaA vinoyFA (tropical:) This thing, or affair, is not thy first nor thy second. (A and TA in art. bkr.) ― -b2- See also vunoyaAnN.

vanFY vnY vny
vanFY: see vinoYN, first sentence.

vunFY vnY vny
vunFY: see vinFY: ― -b2- and see also vunoyaAnN: ― -b3- and AivonaAni.

vinFY vnY vny
vinFY The repetition of a thing; doing it one time after another: (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA:) or a thing, or an affair, done twice: (S, Msb, TA:) this is the primary signification: (TA:) and vunFY↓ signifies the same. (IB, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA vinaY fiY AlS~adaqapi There shall be no repetition in the taking of the poor-rate; (IAth, TA;) [i. e.] the poor-rate shall not be taken twice in one year: (As, Ks, T, S, M, Mgh, K:) or two she-camels shall not be taken in the place of one for the poor-rate: (M, IAth, K: *) or there shall be no retracting of an alms; or no revoking it: (Mgh, K, * TA:) this last is the meaning accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, (Mgh, TA,) i. e. Ed-Dareeree, (Mgh,) who, in explaining this trad., as relating to the giving an alms to a man and then desiring to take it back, says he does not deny that vinFY has the meaning first assigned to it above in this paragraph. (TA.) ― -b2- See also vunoyAnN: ― -b3- and AivonaAni.

vanowaY vnwY vnwy
vanowaY and vunowaY: see vunoyaA, in four places.

vunoyapN vny vnyh vnyp
vunoyapN: see vunoyaA, in three places.

vinoyapN vny vnyh vnyp
vinoyapN The lowest, most ignoble, or meanest, of the people of his house; applied to a man. (S, TA.) ― -b2- Also pl. of vunoyaAnN, q. v. (S, K.)

vunoyaA vnY vny vnyA
vunoyaA a subst. from AisotivonaA='N; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also vanowaY↓; the former with damm, and the latter with fet-h: (S, Msb:) both are syn. with AisotivonaA='N [used as a subst., meaning An exception]; (T;) as also vaniy~apN↓, (T, K,) or vunoyapN↓, (accord. to one copy of the T,) and mavonawiy~apN↓: (T:) so in the saying, Halafa yamiynFA layosa fiyhaA vunoyaA and vunowaY↓ and vaniy~apN↓ or vunoyapN↓ and mavonawiy~apN↓ [he swore an oath in which there was not an exception]; for when the swearer says, “ By God I will not do such and such things unless God will otherwise, ” he reverses what he [first] says by God's willing otherwise: (T: [see 10:]) [and so in the saying,] HalofapN gayoru *aAti mavonawiy~apK↓ a swearing not made lawful [by an exception]: (M:) [so too in the saying,] bayoEN maA fiyhi mavonawiy~apN↓ [and vunoyaA &c.] (K in art. lHj) a sale in which there is not an exception: (TA in that art.:) or vunoyaA signifies a thing excepted, (M, Mgh, K,) whatever it be; (K) as also vanowaY↓, (M, K,) with w substituted for Y, (M,) or vunowaY↓, (so in the TA, [but probably through inadvertence,]) and vaniy~apN↓, (M, K,) or vunoyapN↓. (TA.) In a sale, it is unlawful when it is the exception of a thing unknown; and when one sells a slaughtered camel for a certain price and excepts the head and extremities: (T, TA:) or when an exception is made from things sold without measuring or weighting or numbering: and in a contract with another for labour upon land on the condition of sharing the produce, it is when one excepts a certain measure after the half or the third. (IAth, TA.) The saying of Mo- hammad, mani A@sotavonaY falahu vunoyaAhu means Whoso maketh an exception, his shall be what he excepteth: (M, TA: *) as, for instance, when one says, “ I divorce her thrice, save once: ” or “ I emancipate them, except such a one. ” (TA.) ― -b2- It also means particularly The head and legs of a slaughtered camel; (T, M, * K;) because the seller of the camel used, in the Time of Ignorance, to except them; (T;) and IF adds, but incorrectly, the back-bone: (Sgh, TA:) whence, applied to a she-camel, mu*ak~arapu Alv~unoyaA, (T, M,) meaning Resembling the make of the male in [the largeness of] her head and legs; (Th, M;) or jumaAliy~apu Alv~unoyaA, having thick legs, like those of the male camel in thickness. (T.) [Also, app., The exception, or omission, of a day, in irrigation: see 3 in art. vlv, and vilovN in the same art.] And vaniy~apN↓ signifies also A palm-tree that is excepted from a bargain. (M, K.) And The martyrs whom God has excepted from those who shall fall down dead or swooning: (M, K:) these, accord. to Kaab, are A@ll~`hi fiY AlA^aroDi vaniy~pu↓ [those whom God has excepted on the earth]; (T, M;) alluded to in the Kur [xxxix. 68], where it is said, “ And the horn shall be blown, and those who are in the heavens and those on the earth shall fall down dead, or swooning, except those whom God shall please [to except]. ” (T.)

vunoyaAnN vny vnyAn
vunoyaAnN The second chief; the person who comes second as a chief; (A'Obeyd, T;) the person who is [next] below the say~id, (S, M, K, [in some copies of the K, erroneously, syl,]) in rank; (S;) as also vinFY↓ (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) and vunFY↓ (A'Obeyd, T, S, K) and vinoYN↓: (K:) pl. (of the first, S) vinoyapN [which is also a sing., mentioned above]. (S, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce bado'N.] ― -b2- A man having no judgment nor intelligence, or understanding. (M, K.) ― -b3- Applied to judgment, or an opinion, (M, K,) (tropical:) Wrong, or having a wrong tendency; (M;) bad, corrupt, unsound, or wrong. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also a pl. of vaniY~N [q. v.]. (S, M, &c.)

vanawiY~N vnwY vnwy
vanawiY~N rel. n. of AivonaAni, and of AivonaA Ea$ara, when either or these is used as the proper name of a man; as also AivoniY~N↓ [with A@ when connected with a preceding word]; like binawiY~N and AiboniY~N as rel. ns. of AibonN. (S.) ― -b2- And Alv~anawiy~apu [The Dualists;] the sect who assert the doctrine of Dualism [AlA@ivonayoniy~ap]. (TA.)

vanaA='N vnA='
vanaA='N, [and accord. to the CK, vaniy~apN, but this is a mistranscription for tavoniyap, inf. n. of van~aY, and tavoniyap is a mistake for tavobiyap, inf. n. of vab~aY, (see 4,)] Praise, eulogy, or commendation, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) of a man, (T, M,) and of God: (T:) and dispraise, censure, or discommendation, (T, M, Msb, K,) of a man: (T, M:) or the former only: (M, K:) or more frequently the former: (Msb:) so termed because it is repeated: (Ham p. 696:) that it relates to good speech and evil is asserted by many. (TA.)

vunaA='u vnA='
vunaA='u and vunaA='a: see mavonaY.

vinaA='N vnA='
vinaA='N The cord, or rope, with which a camel's fore shank and his arm are bound together; (S, K;) and the like; consisting of a folded, or doubled, cord, or rope: each of the folds, or duplicatures, thereof would be thus termed if the word were used in the sing. form: (S:) Ibn-EsSeed [in the CK, erroneously, Ibn-Es-Seedeh] allows it; and therefore it is given as on his authority in the K: (TA:) and Lth allows it; but in this instance he allows what the Arabs do not allow: (T:) you say, Eaqalotu AlbaEiyra bivinaAyayoni, meaning I bound together the fore shanks and the arms of the camel with a rope, (S,) or with two ropes, (M, [but this is probably a mistake of a copyist,]) or with the two ends of a rope; (AZ, T, S, M;) without ' because the word has no sing.: (Kh, Sb, T, S:) Lth allows one's saying bivinaA='ayoni also; but the Basrees and Koofees [in general] agree that it is without ': (T:) IB says that it has no sing. because it is a single rope, with one end of which one fore leg is bound, and with the other end the other leg; and IAth says the like: (TA:) this rope is also called vinaAyapN↓; but a single rope for binding one fore shank and arm is not thus called. (T.) See also vinaAyapN. ― -b2- And see vaAnK. ＝ -A2- The finaA=' [or court, or open or wide space, in front, or extending from the sides,] (M, K,) of a house: (M:) [in the CK, AlginA'u is erroneously put for AlfinA'u:] accord. to IJ, from vanaY, aor. yavoniY, because there one is turned back, by its limits, from expatiating; but A'Obeyd holds the v to be a substitute for f. (M.)

vaniY~N vnY vny
vaniY~N Shedding his tooth called the vaniy~ap [q. v.]: (S, M, Msb:) or that has shed the tooth so called: (T, Mgh:) applied to a camel &c., as follows: (T, S, M, &c.:) or, as some say, to any animal that has shed that tooth, except man: (M:) fem. with p: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) a camel in the sixth year; (T, S, M, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K;) the least
age at which he may be sacrificed: (T:) and a horse in the fourth year; (IAar, T, Mgh, K;) or in the third year: (S, Msb:) and a cloven-hoofed animal, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or a sheep or goat and an animal of the bovine kind, [respecting which last see EaDobN,] (T, IAth, K,) in the third year: (T, S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K:) or a sheep and a goat, (M,) the latter accord. to the persuasion of Ahmad [Ibn-Hambal], (TA,) in the second year: (M:) and a gazelle after the age at which he is termed ja*aEN: (M: [see $aSarN:]) in all cases, after what is termed ja*aEN and before what is termed rabaAEK: (Mgh:) pl. (masc., S, TA) vunoyaAnN and vinaA='N (S, M, Mgh, Msb) and vunaA='N, and, accord. to Sb, vunK; (M;) and pl. fem. vaniy~aAtN. (S.)

Alv~unaY~u A^lvny AlvnY Alvny lAv vny
Alv~unaY~u, or Alv~uniY~u: see AivonaAni.

vaniy~apN vny vnyh vnyp
vaniy~apN I. q. EaqabapN: (AA, M, Mgh, K:) or the latter means a long mountain that lies across the road, and which the road traverses; and the former, any such mountain that is traversed: (T:) so called because it lies before the road, and crosses it; or because it turns away him who traverses it: (Mgh:) or the road of what is termed Eaqabap: (S; and so in copies of the K:) or a high road of what is thus termed: (K accord. to the TA:) or a road in, or upon, a mountain, (M, K,) like that which is termed naqobN [q. v.]: (M:) or a road to a mountain: (M, K:) or a mountain (M, K) itself: (M:) or a part of a mountain that requires one, in traversing it, to ascend and descend; as though it turned the course of journeying: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. vanaAyaA: (T, S:) which signifies also [such roads as are termed] madaArij. (T.) Hence the phrase, fulaAnN Tal~aAEu Alv~anaAyaA Such a one rises to eminences, or to lofty things or circumstances, or to the means of attaining such things; like the phrase Tal~aAEu A^anojudK [q. v.]: (S:) or, like the latter phrase, is accustomed to embark in, or undertake, or to surmount, or master, lofty and difficult things: (Mgh:) or is hardy, strong, or sturdy; one who embarks in, or undertakes, great affairs. (TA. [See an ex. under the heading of Aibonu jalaA, in art. jlw: and see also art. TlE.]) ― -b2- Also, (T, S, M, &c.,) pl. vanaAyaA (T, S, Mgh, Msb) and vaniy~aAtN, (Msb,) One of certain teeth, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) the foremost in the mouth, (M,) [namely, the central incisors,] four in number, (T, M, Mgh, Msb,) to man, and to the camel, (T, M, &c.,) and to the wild beast, (M,) in the fore part of the mouth, (T, Mgh, K,) two above and two below: (T, M, Mgh, K:) so called as being likened to the vaniy~ap of a mountain, in form and hardness; (TA;) or because each of them is placed next to its fellow. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- Also fem. of vaniY~N [q. v.]. (T, S, M, &c.) ＝ -A3- See also vunoyaA, in five places.

vinaAyapN vnAyh vnAyp
vinaAyapN A cord, or rope, of goats' hair ($aEar), or of wool, (S, K,) or of other material; (K;) as also vinaA='N↓ (K) and mivonaApN↓ and mavonaApN↓; (M, K;) which last is explained by IAar as signifying [simply] a cord, or rope: (M:) [or] the first has the meaning assigned to it above, voce vinaA='N; syn. with vinaAyaAni: and signifies also a long rope; whence the saying of Zuheyr, describing the [she-camel termed] saAniyap,
tamoTuw Alr~i$aA='a watujoriY fiY vinaAyatihaA
mina AlmaHaAlapi qab~FA raAy^idFA qaliqaA
(T,) meaning [She draws the well-rope, and causes to run,] with her vnAyp upon her, (ISk, T,) [a wabbling, unsteady, sheave (?) of the large pulley;] the vnAyp here being a rope of which the two ends are tied to the saddle (qatab) of the sAnyp; the [upper] end of the well-rope being tied to its mivonaAp↓ [which here means the folded middle part]: (T:) but Aboo-Sa'eed says that it [here] means a piece of wood by which are connected the two extremities of the cheeks, or side-pieces, (TrfA Almylyn, [the latter of which words I here render conjecturally, supposing it to be similar in meaning to AlqaEowi or AlqaEowayoni,]) above the mHAlp, and a similar piece below; the mHAlp and [qu. or] the sheave turning between the tow pieces thus called. (T, in a later portion of the art.)

vunaAy^iY~N *
vunaAy^iY~N [a rel. n. from AivonaAni, anomalously formed, but analogous with other rel. ns. from ns. of number, as rubaAEiY~N vulaAviY~N, &c., Of, or relating to, two things]. ― -b2- kalimapN vunaAy^iy~apN A word comprising, or composed of, two letters; as yadN, and dumo [or damN?]. (TA.)

vinotaAni vnp vntAn
vinotaAni a fem of AivonaAni, q. v.

vaAnK vAn vAny
vaAnK [act. part. n. of 1; Doubling, or folding; &c.]. Hence, huwa vaAnK rijolahu While he was bending his leg before rising, or standing up. (TA from a trad.) [And jaA='a vaAniYa EiTofihi: see art. ETf.] One says of a horseman who has bent the neck of his beast on the occasion of his vehement running, jaA='a vaAniYa AlEinaAni [He came bending the rein by pulling it with both hands a little apart]: (T:) or jaA='a vaAniyFA mino EinaAnihi [he came bending a part of his rein]. (S.) And of the horse himself, one says, jaA='a saAbiqFA vaAniyFA, i. e. He came outstripping, with bent neck, by reason of briskness; because when he is fatigued, he stretches out his neck; and when he is not fatigued nor jaded by running, but comes in his first run, he bends his neck: and hence the saying of the poet,
wamano yafoxaro bimivoli A^abiY wajad~iY
yajiy^o qabola Als~awaAbiqi wahuwa vaAniY
i. e. [And he who glories in the like of my father and my grandfather, let him come before the mares that outstrip,] he being like the horse that outstrips [all others], with bent neck; or it may mean, he bending the neck of his horse which has outstripped the others. (T.) [Hence also,] $aApN vaAniyapN A sheep, or goat, bending the neck, not in consequence of disease. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Also Second; the ordinal of two: fem. with p.] You say, h`*aA vaAniY h`*aA [This is the second of this]; i. e. this is what has made this a pair, or couple: (M:) and fulaAnN (T) or h`*aA (S) vaAniY A@vonayoni, (T, S,) i. e. Such a one, or this, is [the second of two, or] one of the two; (T, S;) like as you say vaAlitu valaAvapK; and so on to Ea$arap: but not with tenween: (S:) [i. e.,] you may not say vAnK A@vonayoni: (T: [see vaAlivN:]) but if the two [terms] disagree, you may use either mode; (S;) you may say, h`*aA (S) or huwa (Mgh) vaAniY waAHidK and vaAnK waAHidFA, (S, Mgh,) i. e. This has become a second to one, (S,) [or rather, becomes &c. (i. e. yavoniY rather than vanaY),] or he, or it, makes one, with himself, or itself, to be two. (Mgh.) vinaA='↓ also signifies the same in a trad. respecting the office of commander, or governor, or prince; where it is said, A^aw~aluhaA malaAmapN wavinaAw^uhaA nadaAmapN wavilaAvuhaA Ea*Abu yawomi AlqiyaAmapi A_il~aA mano Eadala, i. e. [The first result thereof is blame, and] the second [is regret, and] the third [is the punishment of the day of resurrection, except in the case of him who acts equitably]: so says Sh. (T.) ― -b3- And Alv~awaAniY [pl. of Alv~aAniyapu] signifies [The second horns;] the horns that are [next] after the A^awaAy^il. (M.) ― -b4- [vaAniYa Ea$ara and vaAniyapa Ea$orapa, the former masc. and the latter fem., meaning Twelfth, are subject to the same rules as vaAliva Ea$ara and its fem., explained in art. vlv.]

A^avonaA='N *
A^avonaA='N pl. of vinoYN and of AivonaAni: and also syn. with this latter, q. v.

AivoniY~N A^vnY A^vny AvnY Avny vnY {vnA {vny
AivoniY~N: see vanawiY~N.

AivonaAni AvnAn {vnAn
AivonaAni a noun of number; (S, Msb;) applied to the dual number; (Msb;) meaning [Two;] the double of waAHidN; (M, K;) with a conjunctive A [when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, written A@vonaAni]; (T, S, Msb;) but this is sometimes made disjunctive when connected with a preceding word by poetic license: (T, S:) of the masc. gender: (S:) fem. AivonataAni, (T, S, Msb,) in which, also, the A is conjunctive; (T, Msb;) and vinotaAni↓; (T S, M, Msb, K;) the latter sometimes used, (T,) [much less frequently than the former, though the only fem. form mentioned in the M and K,] and of the dial. of Temeem; (Msb;) like as one says, hiYa A@bonapu fulaAnK and hiYa binotuhu: (T:) the t in the dual is a substitute for the final radical, Y, (M, TA,) as it is in A^asonatuwA, the only other instance of this substitution except in words of the measure AifotaEala: (Sb, M, TA:) in AivonaAni, the final radical, Y is suppressed: (Msb:) it has no sing.: (Lth, T:) if it were allowable to assign to it a sing., it would be AivonN [for the masc.] and AivonapN [for the fem.], like AibonN and AibonapN: (S:) accord. to some, (Msb,) it is originally vinoYN; (T, Msb, CK;) and hence the dual vinotaAni: (Msb:) or it is originally vanaYN, (M, Msb, and so in a copy of the K,) the conjunctive A being then substituted for the Y whence the dual A@vonaAni, like A@bonaAni: (Msb:) this is shown by the form of its pl., which is A^avonaA='N, (M, K,) like A^abonaA='N [pl. of A@bonN, which is originally banaYN or banawN,] and A=xaA='N [pl. of A^axN, which is originally A^axawN]. (M.) In the saying in the Kur [xvi. 53], laA tat~axi*uwA A_i`lhayoni A@vonayoni [Take not to yourselves two gods], the last word is added as a corroborative. (M.) The phrase vinotaA HanoZalK occurs, by poetic license, for AivonataAni mino HanoZalK, meaning HanoZalataAni [Two colo-
cynths]. (S.) You say also, AlqadaHi $aribotu A^avonaA='a↓, and $aribotu A@vonaYo h`*aA AlqadaHi, meaning [I drank] twice as much as the bowl, and as this bowl: and in like manner, $aribotu A@vonaYo mud~i AlbaSorapi and A@vonayoni bimud~i AlbaSorapi [I drank twice the quantity of the mud~ of El-Basrah]. (M.) And a poet says,
famaA Hulibato A_il~aA Alv~alaAvapa waAlv~unaY↓
walaA quy~ilato A_il~aA qariybFA maqaAluhaA
meaning [And she was not milked save] three vessels and two, [nor was she given her middaydrink save when her midday-resting was near.] (IAar, M.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) yawomu AlA@ivonayoni, (S, Msb,) or AlA@ivonaAni alone, (M, K,) One of the days of the week; [the second; namely, Monday;] because the first, with the Arabs, is AlA^aHadu; (M;) as also Alv~inaY↓, like A_ilaY; (K;) so in the copies of the K; [or,] accord. to some, Alv~uniY~u↓, [originally Alv~unuwYu,] of the measure fuEuwl, like vudiY~N [pl. of vadoYN], is used in this sense; (TA;) or Alyawomu Alv~unaY~u↓, [so in the M, accord. to the TT,] mentioned by Sb, on the authority of certain of the Arabs: (M:) the pl. is A^avonaA='N and A^avaAniynu, (M, K,) the latter mentioned on the authority of Th: but it has no dual: and those who say A^avonaA='N form this pl. from AlA@ivonu, although this has not been in use: (M:) or it has neither dual nor pl., (S, Msb,) being itself a dual; (S;) but if you would form a pl. from it, you would regard it as itself a sing., and make its pl. A^avaAniynu: (S, Msb:) IB says that A^avaAniynu has not been heard [from the Arabs], and is only mentioned by Fr, on the ground of analogy; that it is far-fetched in respect of analogy; and that the pl. heard is A^avonaA='N: Seer and others mention, as heard from the Arabs, A_in~ahu layaSuwmu AlA^avonaA='a [Verily he fasts on the Mondays]. (TA.) Alvnyn in ywm Alvnyn has no dim. (Sb, S in art. Ams.) IJ says that the article Al in Alvnyn is not redundant, though the word is not an epithet: Abu-l-'Abbás says that the prefixing of the article in this case is allowable because the virtual meaning is Alyawomu Alv~aAniY [the second day]. (M.) The saying Alyawomu AlA@ivonaAni means The name of to-day [is AlAvnAn]; and is like the saying Alyawomu yawomaAni [to-day is two days] and Alyawomu xamosapa Ea$ara mina Al$~ahori [to-day is fifteen of the month]. (Sb, M.) Sometimes, yawomu A@vonayoni, without the article Al, occurs in poetry. (M, K.) When a pronoun refers to AlAvnAn [as meaning Monday], this word may be treated in two ways, [as a sing. and as a dual,] but the more chaste way is to treat it as a sing., as meaning the day: (Msb:) [thus,] Aboo-Ziyád used to say, maDaY AlA@ivonaAni bimaA fiyhi [Monday passed with what occurred in it]; making it sing. and masc.; and thus he did in the case of every day of the week, except that he made AljumoEap fem.: Abu-I-Jarráh used to say, maDaY AlA@ivonaAni bimaA fiyhimaA, treating the word as a numeral; and thus he treated the third and fourth and fifth days, saying in each of these cases bimaA fiyhin~a. (M.) ― -b3- [AivonaA Ea$ara, fem. AivonataA Ea$orapa; respectively, in a case of nasb and khafd, AivonaYo Ea$ara and AivonataYo Ea$orapa; and with A@ when not immediately preceded by a quiescence; mean Twelve: see Ea$arapN.]

AivonawiY~N AvnwY Avnwy
AivonawiY~N, [with A@ when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, in the CK erroneously written AavonawiY~,] One who fasts alone on the second day of the week. (IAar, Th, M, K.)

AlA@ivonayoniy~apu *
AlA@ivonayoniy~apu [The doctrine of dualism: see vanawiY~N]. (TA.)

mavonaY mvnY mvny mvnyy
mavonaY (S, Mgh) and vunaA='u↓ (T, S) [Two and two; two and two together; or two at a time and two at a time]: they are imperfectly decl., in like manner as [mavolavu and] vulaAvu, as explained in art. vlv; (S, TA;) [because] changed from the original form of AivonaAni A@vonaAni; (T, Mgh, TA;) or because of their having the quality of epithets and deviating from the original form of AivonaAni; (Sb, S in art. vlv, q. v.;) or because they deviate from their original as to the letter and the meaning; the original word being changed as above stated, and the meaning being changed to AivonaAni A@vonaAni. (S ibid.) You say, jaAw^uwA mavonaY and vunaA='a↓ (M, K) or mavonaY mavonaY, (S,) but this is a repetition of the word only, not of the meaning, (Mgh,) and in like manner one says of women, (M, K, *) i. e. They came two [and] two. (S, M, K.) And it is said in a trad., SalaApu All~ayoli mavonaY mavonaY, i. e. The prayer of night is two rek'ahs [and] two rek'ahs (rakoEataAni rakoEataAni). (TA.) [See also other exs. voce vulaAvu.] ― -b2- mavonaY AlA^ayaAdiY The repeating a benefit, or benefaction; or reiterating it; conferring it twice, or thrice; (As, T, K;) or twice, or more than twice: (K:) or the shares remaining of the slaughtered camel (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K) in the game called Almayosir, (A'Obeyd, T, S, K,) which shares a bountiful man used to purchase, and give for food to the A^aboraAm, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) i. e., those who took no part in the game, not contributing: (M:) or the taking a portion time after time. (AA, T, S, M.) ― -b3- mavaAnK [is pl. of mavonFY as signifying A place of doubling, or folding &c.: and hence means ― -b4- ] The knees and elbows of a horse or similar beast. (T, K.) ― -b5- And The bends of a valley. (T, K. See vinoYN.) ― -b6- And, as pl. of mavonFY, The chords of the lute that are after the first: (M, K:) or mvnY signifies a chord [of a lute] composed of two twists: or, as some say, the second chord. (Har p. 244. See mavolavN.) ― -b7- mavonFY also signifies The zimaAm [or noserein] of a she-camel: and Er-Rághib says that the mvnAp [i. e. mavonaAp↓ or mivonaAp↓] is the doubled, or folded, part of the extremity of the zimaAm. (TA.) ― -b8- AlmavaAniY as relating to the Kur-án is pl. of mavonFY, (Mgh,) or of mavonaApN↓: (AHeyth, T, Mgh:) it has three applications, accord. to A'Obeyd: (T, Mgh:) it signifies The Kur-án altogether; (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh, K;) so in the Kur xxxix 24; (A'Obeyd, T, Mgh;) meaning that the mention of reward and punishment is repeated, or reiterated, in it; (Fr, T;) or so called because the verse of mercy is conjoined with that of punishment; (S;) or because narratives and promises and threats are repeated in it; or because one peruses it repeatedly without being wearied: (Mgh:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (A'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh,) [the first chapter, called] the faAtiHap, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh,) or AlHamodu, (K,) which means the same; (TA;) so in the Kur xv. 87; (A'Obeyd, T, Mgh;) because it is repeated, or recited twice, in every [act of prayer termed a] rakoEap, (Fr, Zj, AHeyth, T, S,) or with every chapter, (Th, M,) or in every prayer; (Mgh;) or because containing praise of God: (Zj, T, Mgh:) [but see Als~aboEu AlmavaAniY voce saboEapN:] or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (A'Obeyd, T, S, Mgh,) the chapters that are less than those containing a hundred verses, (S, M, Mgh,) or that are less than the long ones (AlT~uwal, q. v.), and less than those containing a hundred verses, (A'Obeyd, T, K, but in [most of] the copies of the K duwna AlmiA^atayoni is put in the place of duwna Almiy^iyna, which is the right reading, TA,) and more than [those of the portion called] the mufaS~al, (A'Obeyd, T, Mgh, K,) as is related on the authority of the Prophet by Ibn-Mes'ood and 'Othmán and Ibn- 'Abbás; (AHeyth, T;) because, (Mgh,) or as though, (T,) occupying the second place after those containing a hundred verses: (T, Mgh:) or the chapters, (T, K,) six and twenty in number, (T,) entitled AlHaj~ and AlqaSaS and Aln~amol and Aln~uwr and AlA^anofaAl and maroyam and AlEanokabuwt and Alr~uwm and yaAsiyn and AlfuroqaAn and AlHijor and Alr~aEod and sabaA and AlmalaAy^ikap and A_iboraAhiym and SaAd and muHam~ad and luqom`n and Alguraf and Almuw^omin and Alz~uxoruf and Als~ajodap and AlA^aHoqaAf and AljaAviyap and Ald~uxaAn (T, K) and AlA^aHozaAb, (K,) which last has been omitted by the copyists of the T: (TA:) or the chapters of which the first is the baqarap, and the last is baraA='ap: or what is repeated, of the Kur-án, time after time. (M, K.)

mavonaApN mvnAh mvnAp mvnY
mavonaApN; pl. mavaAnK: see vinoYN: and vinaAyapN: and mavonFY; the last in two places. ― -b2- It is said in a trad. that one of the signs of the resurrection will be the public reading, or reciting, of the mavonaAp, (T, S,) which means That which has been desired to be transcribed from a source other than the Book of God: (T:) or a certain book, (T, K,) [the Mishna,] which the learned men, and the recluses, of the Children of Israel, after Moses, composed after their own desire, from a source other than the Book of God, as A'Obeyd says on the authority of a man learned in the books of the earlier times, (T,) containing the histories of the Children of Israel after Moses, in which they allowed and disallowed what they pleased: (K:) or what is sung: (K:) or what is called in Persian duw bayotiY, (S, K,) which means two verses, each composed of a pair of hemistichs; (TA;) i. e. what is sung; but A'Obeyd explains it otherwise than thus: (S:) it is what is known among the 'Ajam by the term mavonawiY~N↓, as though this were a rel. n. from mavonaApN: the vulgar say [erroneously] *uw bayot, with the pointed *. (TA.)

mivonaApN mvnAh mvnAp mvnY
mivonaApN; pl. mavaAnK: see vinoYN: and vinaAyapN; the latter in two places: and see also mavonFY.

muvan~FY mvnY mvny mvnyy
muvan~FY [pass. part. n. of 2. ― -b2- Dualized: a dual. ― -b3- muvan~aApN fawoqiy~apN Marked with two points above: an epithet added to tA=' to prevent its being mistaken for bA=' or vA=' or yA='. And muvan~aApN taHotiy~apN Marked with two points below: an epithet added to yA=' to prevent its being mistaken for bA=' or tA=' or vA='.] ― -b4- AlT~awylu Almuvan~aY (assumed tropical:) That which passes away [out of sight, or disappears,] by length; mostly used of a thing that is long without breadth. (TA.)

mavoniY~N mvnY mvny mvnyy
mavoniY~N [pass. part. n. of 1; Doubled or folded &c.] ― -b2- A^aroDN mavoniy~apN Land, or ground, turned over twice for sowing, or cultivating. (Mgh, and A and TA in art. vlv.)

mavonawiY~N mvnwY mvnwy
mavonawiY~N: see mavonaApN.

mavonawiy~apN mvnwyh mvnwyp
mavonawiy~apN: see vunoyaA, in four places.

vuw~apN vwh vwp
vuw~apN [mentioned in the M under the head of vw, as the radical letters, but in the T and K in art. vwY,] sing. of vuwFY, (IAar, T, K,) which latter, (IAar, T,) or the former, (K,) signifies The goods, or utensils and furniture, of a house or tent: (IAar, T, K:) or the former, pieces of rag made in the form of a ball of thread or string, upon a peg, or stake, upon which the skin of milk is agitated to make butter, lest it should become lacerated; as also vuwiY~N↓; (M, K;) which latter we hold to be from vww because syn. with vuw~apN, like quw~apN: (ISd in the M:) or a piece of rag, which is moistened, and put upon the skin of milk when it is agitated to make butter, lest it should become lacerated: (T:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) a piece of rag, (M, K,) or some wool wound upon the head of a peg, or stake, (IB, TA,) put beneath the skin of milk when it is agitated to make butter, in order to preserve it from being injured by the ground; (M, IB, K;) pl. vuwFY: (IB, TA:) or it signifies, (K,) or signifies also, (M,) an elevated and a rugged spot, upon which, sometimes, stones are set up in order that one may be directed thereby to the right way; (M, K;) like Suw~apN. (M. See also vaAyapN, in art. vwY.)

vuwY~N vwY vwp vwy
vuwY~N: see above.

4 A^avaA^otuhu bisahomK *
4. A^avaA^otuhu bisahomK, (S in art. vA^, [incorrectly there mentioned, as is said by IB and others and in the K,] and K in the present art. and in art. AvA^,) inf. n. A_ivaA='apN, (S,) I shot him, or shot at him, with an arrow; (S, K;) so says AA, and Ks says the like; (S;) as also A^avawotuhu, and, accord. to As, A^avayotuhu, (TA in art. vA^,) which is a strange word. (TA in the present art.) It is mentioned in the present art. by Sgh; (K in art. AvA^;) and this is its proper place; (TA in the present art.;) the verb, accord. to him, being like A^aqaAma: (TA in art. AvA^:) A 'Obeyd has mentioned it in art. AvA^, (K in that art.,) as also Az; holding the verb to be like SanaEa; and so IKtt and IKoot assert it to be. (TA.)

vaA='N vA='
vaA='N The name of the letter v, q. v.; as also vaA: pl. [of the former,] vaA='aAtN; and [of the latter,] A^avowaA='N and A^avoyaA='N. (TA in bAb AlAlf Ally~np.) ＝ -A2- It also stands for vanaA='N, and vawaAbN, and the like. (Idem ubi suprà.) ＝ -A3- Also The best of anything; as, for instance, of wheat, and of flesh-meat, and of sugar. (Kh, TA ubi suprà.)

vaAy^iY~N *
vaAy^iY~N and vaAwiY~N rel. ns. of vaA='N and vaA, the names of the letter v; as also vayawiY~N. (TA ubi suprà.)

1 vaAba vAb
1. vaAba, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yavuwbu, (S, Mgh, &c.,) inf. n. vawobN (S, M, Msb, K) and vawabaAnN (S) and vuw^uwbN, (M, K,) He, or it, (a thing, M,) returned; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also vw~b↓, inf. n. tavowiybN: (M, K:) he returned to a place to which he had come before; or it returned &c.: (T:) he (a man) returned, after he had gone away. (S.) You say, tafar~aquwA vum~a vaAbuwA i. e. [They became separated, or dispersed: then] they returned. (A.) ― -b2- vAb A_ilaY A@ll~`hi, like taAba, (assumed tropical:) He returned [from disobedience] to obedience to God; he repented; as also A^anaAba. (T.) ― -b3- vAb also signifies (assumed tropical:) He returned to a state of advertency, or vigilance; or he had his attention roused. (Th, T.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) He returned to a state of health, or soundness: (TA, from a trad.:) he became convalescent, and fat, after leanness. (Mgh.) And vAb jisomuhu, (M, A, K,) inf. n. vawabaAnN; (M, K;) and jisomuhu AvAb↓; (IKt, M;) and vAb A_ilayohi jisomuhu; (T, M, A;) and AvAb↓, alone; (S, M, A;) (tropical:) He became fat, after leanness; (A;) his good state of body returned to him; (S, M, K; *) his condition of body became good, after extenuation; and health, or soundness, thereof returned to him. (T.) ― -b5- vAb A_ilayohi Eaqoluhu (tropical:) [His reason, or intellect, returned to him]: and Hilomuhu [his forbearance, or clemency]. (A.) ― -b6- vAb AlmaA='u (assumed tropical:) The water of a well returned, or collected again: (T:) the water attained again its former state after some had been drawn: (M:) the water collected [again] in a wateringtrough, or tank. (S.) ― -b7- vAb Aln~aAsu (assumed tropical:) The people collected themselves together, and came. (S.) And vAb Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The company of men came following one another: the verb is not used in this sense in speaking of one person. (M.) ― -b8- vAb said of a man's property, (tropical:) It became abundant, and collected. (A.) ― -b9- Said of dust, (tropical:) It rose, or spread, or diffused itself, and became abundant. (A.) ― -b10- Said of a watering-trough, or tank, (T, M, A, K,) inf. n. vawobN (AZ, T, M, K) and vawabaAnN (AZ, T) and vuw^uwbN, (M, K,) (tropical:) It became full: (AZ, T, M, A, K:) or nearly full. (AZ, T, M, K.)

2 vw~ib vwb
2. vw~ib, inf. n. tavowiybN: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- vwab baEoda xaSaASapK (tropical:) [He returned to a state of richness, or competence, after poverty, or straitness, or being in an evil condition]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- tavowiybN meaning The calling, or summoning, (M, Mgh, K,) to prayer, (M, K,) and to other things, (M,) is said to be from vawobN “ a garment, ” (Mgh,) because a man, when he comes crying out for aid, makes a sign with his garment, (M, Mgh,) moving it about, raising his hand with it, in order that he to whom he calls may see it, (Mgh,) and this action is like a calling, or summoning, (M, Mgh,) and an announcing, to him; so the calling, or summoning, by reason to frequent usage of this word [as meaning the making a sign with a garment], came to be thus called; and one said of the caller, or summoner, vwab: (Mgh:) or it means the calling, or summoning, twice; (M, K;) or the repeating a call or summons; from vAb “ he returned: ” (Mgh:) you say, vw~b, inf. n. as above, (T, Msb,) meaning he called, or summoned, one time after another; (T;) he repeated his call, or cry: (Msb:) and hence tvwyb in the A^a*aAn; (T, Msb;) i. e., the saying of the muw^a*~in, after having, by the A*An, called the people to prayer, AlS~alaAho raHimakumu A@ll~`hu AlS~alaAho [Prayer: may God have mercy on you! Prayer!]; thus calling to it a second time: (T:) or his saying, (S, TA,) in the morning call to prayer, (S,) AlS~alaApu xayorN mina Aln~awomN [Prayer is better than sleep]; (S, TA;) for he resumes his call by saying this after he has said, HaY~a EalaY AlS~alaAho [and HaY~a EalaY AlfalaAHN]; desiring the people to hasten to prayer: (TA:) or his saying, in the morning call to prayer, AlSlAp xyrmn Alnwm twice, (T, K,) after having said, HaY~ Ely AlSlAh HY~ Ely AlflAH: (T:) or the old tvwyb was the saying of the muw^a*~in, in the morning call to prayer, AlSlAp xyr mn Alnwm: and the modern, AlS~alaAho AlS~alaAho; or qaAmato qaAmato. (Mgh.) It also signifies The A_iqaAmap; (Mgh, K, TA;) [meaning, the chanting, by the mubal~iguwn, in a mosque, not by the muw^a*~in, the common words of the A^a*aAn, with the addition of qado qaAmati AlS~alaAho (The time of prayer has come), pronounced twice after HY~ ElY AlflAH;] i. e. the AqAmp of prayer: (IAth, TA:) and this is what is meant by the phrase, in a trad., A_i*aA vuw~iba biAlS~alaApi [When the words of the AqAmp are chanted]. (IAth, Mgh, TA.) And The praying after the prayer divinely ordained. (Yoo, T, K.) You say, vw~b, meaning He performed a supererogatory prayer after the prescribed; tvwyb being only after the prescribed; being the praying after praying: (T:) and tvw~b↓ signifies the same. (K.) And v~wb birakoEatayoni He performed two rek'ahs as a supererogatory act. (A.) But this and the similar significations are said to be post-classical. (MF.) ― -b4- See also 4, in four places. ＝ -A2- vay~abato, (T, S, Mgh,) inf. n. tavoyiybN; (T, Mgh;) formed from vay~ibN, upon supposition [that the medial radical letter of this word is Y, whereas many hold that letter to be w]; (Mgh;) or tavay~abato↓; (K in art. vyb; [the author of which seems to have supposed that, for vay~abato, one should read vuy~ibato; and therefore he gives muvay~abN as syn. with vay~ibN;]) She (a woman) became what
is termed vay~ib. (T, Mgh, K.) ― -b2- [Accord. to my copy of the Mgh, it also signifies She (a camel) became what is termed naAb: but I think that, in this instance, it is a mistranscription, for nay~abato.] ＝ -A3- [See also the last sentence of the second paragraph of art. vrb; and compare, with what is there said by SM, meanings assigned below to mavaAbN and mavaAbapN.]

3 AlxuT~aAbu yuvaAwibuwnahaA AlxTAb yvAwbwnhA
3. AlxuT~aAbu yuvaAwibuwnahaA The suitors return to her (namely, a woman such as is termed vay~ib,) time after time. (A, Mgh.)

4 AvAb A^vAb AvAb
4. AvAb: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- It may also mean (assumed tropical:) It (a valley, or a well,) had a return of water after a stoppage thereof. (Ham p. 598.) ＝ -A2- AvAb A@ll~`hu jisomahu (tropical:) God restored him to fatness, after leanness; (A;) restored his body to a good state, or condition. (TA.) ― -b2- A_in~a Eamuwda Ald~iyni laA yuvaAbu biAln~isaA='a A_ino maAla (assumed tropical:) Verily the column of the religion cannot be set upright again by women, if it incline: said by Umm-Selemeh to 'Áïsheh, when the latter desired to go forth to El-Basrah. (T, L.) ― -b3- AvAbhu A@ll~`hu, (T, S, * M, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. A_ivaAbapN; (Mgh;) and A^avowabahu [dev. from rule]; (M, K;) and vw~bhu↓, (T, A,) inf. n. tvowiybN; (T, Mgh;) God recompensed, compensated, requited, or rewarded, him: (T, S, * M, A, Mgh, * Msb, K:) said in relation to good and to evil. (T.) And AvAbhu, (Lh, M,) and A^avowabahu, (T,) mavuwbapF HasanapF, (Lh, T, M,) and mavowabapF, (Lh, M,) He (God) gave him a good recompense, compensation, &c. (M.) And mavuwbatahu vw~bhu↓ He gave him his recompense, &c. (M, K.) It is said in a trad., A^aviybuwA A^axaAkumo, i. e. Recompense ye your brother for his good deed. (TA.) And in the Kur [lxxxiii. last verse], halo Alkuf~aAru maA kaAnuwA yafoEaluwna vuw~iba↓ Have the unbelievers been recompensed for what they did? (T, S, M.) And one says also, AvAbhu mino hibatihi, meaning He gave him a substitute, something instead or in exchange, or a compensation, for his gift. (Mgh, * and TA in art. jnb.) And mino ka*aA vw~bhu↓, (M,) inf. n. tavowiybN, (K,) He gave him a substitute, &c., for such a thing. (M, K. *) ― -b4- AvAb Alv~awoba, inf. n. A_ivaAbapN, He sewed the garment, or piece of cloth, the second time: when one sews it the first time, [in a slight manner,] you say of him mal~ahu [and $al~ahu, i. e. “ he sewed it in the manner termed ‘ running ’ ”]. (T.) ― -b5- AvAb AlHawoDa (tropical:) He filled the watering-trough, or tank: (K, TA:) or nearly filled it. (K.)

5 tvw~b tvwb vAb vwb
5. tvw~b: ― -b2- and tavay~abato: see 2, in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b3- The former also signifies He gained, or earned, a vawaAb [or recompense, &c.]. (K.) But this is said to be post-classical. (MF.)

6 tvAwb tvAwb
6. tvAwb: see vuy^iba, in art. vA^b.

10 AstvAb maAlFA AstvAb mAlA
10. AstvAb maAlFA He restored to himself, or repossessed himself of, property; syn. AisotarojaEahu; (T, A, K;) his property having gone away. (T, A.)
