And Aisotavabotu bimaAlika I restored to myself, or repossessed myself of, property, by means of that which thou gavest me; my property having gone away. (A.) El-Kumeyt says,
A_in~a AlEa$iyrapa tasotaviybu bimaAlihi
fayugiyru wahowa muwaf~irN A^amowaAlahaA
[Verily the tribe restore to themselves wealth by means of his property; and he makes incursions into hostile territories at his own expense, making their property abundant by the spoil that they gain with him]. (T, TA.) ― -b2- AstvAbhu He asked him to recompense, compensate, requite, or reward, him. (S, K.)

vawobN vwb
vawobN A garment, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) [or piece of cloth or stuff,] that is worn by men, composed of linen, cotton, wool, fur, xaz~ [q. v.], (Mgh, Msb,) silk, or the like; (Msb;) but [properly] not what is cut out of several pieces, such as the shirt, and trousers, or drawers, &c.; (Mgh;) [though often applied to a shirt or shift (qamiyS or diroE) and to a jub~ap &c.:] it seems to be so called because the wearer returns to it, or it to the wearer, time after time: (Mgh:) [also a garment worn by women and girls over the shift; (see A^uSodapN;) app., as in the present day, a long gown, reaching to the feet, with very wide sleeves:] pl. viyaAbN [the pl. of mult.] (T, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and A^avowaAbN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, M, Msb, K) and A^avowubN and A^avow^ubN, (S, M, K,) the last two being pls. of pauc., and the latter of them being thus pronounced with ' by some of the Arabs because the dammeh immediately after w is deemed difficult of utterance; for which reason they substitute ' for w in all instances like this. (S.) ― -b2- Curtains, and the like, are not [properly] called viyaAb; but A^amotiEapu Albayoti: (Mgh, Msb:) though Es-Sarakhsee uses the phrase viyaAbu Albayoti. (Mgh.) taEal~aqa biviyaAbi A@ll~`hi (tropical:) [He clung to the curtains of the House of God], i. e., to the curtains of the Kaabeh, is a tropical expression. (A.) ― -b3- Sometimes, vawobN is used metonymically to signify (tropical:) A thing [of any kind] that veils, covers, or protects: as in the saying of a poet,
kavawobi A@boni biyDK waqaAhumo bihi
fasad~a EalaY Als~aAlikiyna Als~abiylaA
[Like the means of protection adopted by Ibn-Beed: he protected them by it, and closed the way against the passengers]. (TA.) Ibn-Beed was a wealthy merchant of the tribe of 'Ád, who hamstrung his she-camel upon a mountain-road, and stopped the way [to his abode] with it. (K in art. byD.) ― -b4- In the same manner, also, viyaAbN is used to signify (tropical:) Weapons. (Ham p. 63.) ― -b5- And A^avowaAbN is sometimes employed to signify (assumed tropical:) The wearers of garments; the wearers' bodies. (R, TA.) Esh-Shemmákh says, (T,) or Leylà, describing camels, (TA,)
wamawohaA biA^avowaAbK xifaAfK falaA taraY
lahaA $abahFA A_il~aA Aln~aEaAma Almunaf~araA
i. e. They mounted them, namely, the travellingcamels, (T,) with their [light, or agile,] bodies: [and thou seest not anything like them, except ostriches scared away.] (T, TA.) And in like manner, also, the dual is employed to signify (assumed tropical:) The wearer's body, or self; or what the garments infold: and viyaAb is employed in the same manner. (TA.) You say, lil~hi vawobaAhu, i. e. (tropical:) To God be he [meaning his excellence] attributed! [for nothing but what is excellent is to be attributed to God:] (A:) or it means lil~hi dar~uhu [To God be attributed the good that hath proceeded from him! or his good deed! &c.: see arts. Alh and dr]. (K.) And fiY vawobaYo A^abiY A^ano A^afiyahu meaning (tropical:) [On me and on my father it rests, or lies, or be it, that I pay it: or] fiY*im~atiY wa*im~apiA^abiY [on my responsibility and the responsibility of my father]. (K, TA.) And Ausolulo viyaAbaka mino viyaAbiY (tropical:) Withdraw, or separate, thyself from me. (A.) ― -b6- [The following exs. are mostly, or all, tropical.] ― -b7- A_in~i Almay~ita layuboEavu fiY viyaAbihi Al~atiY yamuwtu fiyhaA, (K, * TA,) a saying of Mohammad, repeated by Aboo-Sa'eed El-Khudree, when, being about to die, he had called for new garments, and put them on: (TA:) it means Verily the dead will be raised in his garments in which he dies; accord. to some; and was used in this sense by Aboo-Sa'eed: (ElKhattábee, MF, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) [agreeably with] his works (K, TA) with which his life is closed: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) in the state in which he dies, according as it is good or evil. (TA.) ― -b8- waviyaAbaka faTah~iro, in the Kur [lxxiv. 4], means And purify thy garments: (Abu-l-'Abbás, T:) or shorten thy garments; for the shortening them is a means of purity: (T:) or (assumed tropical:) put not on thy garments in a state of disobedience or unrighteousness: (I'Ab, T:) or (assumed tropical:) be not perfidious; for [figuratively speaking,] he who is so pollutes his garments: (Fr, T:) or, as some say, (assumed tropical:) purify thy heart: (Abu-l-'Abbás, T, K:) or (assumed tropical:) purify thyself (IKt, T, TA) from sins, or offences: (IKt, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) rectify thine actions, or thy conduct. (TA.) ― -b9- You say, fulaAno naqiY~u Alv~awobi, meaning (tropical:) Such a one is free from vice, or fault: (A:) and TaAhiru Alv~awobi (tropical:) [the same; or pure in heart, or conduct, or reputation]. (TA in art. nSH.) And danisu Alv~iyaAbi (tropical:) Vicious, or faulty: (A:) or perfidious: (Fr, T:) or foul, or evil, in reputation, (T, TA,) in conduct, or actions, and in the way that he follows [with respect to religion and morality]. (TA.) ― -b10- kalaAbisi vawobaYo zuwrK: see muta$ab~iEN. ― -b11- A^aEoraDa vawobu Almalobasi and Almilobasi &c.: see EaruDa. ― -b12- vawobu AlmaA='i (assumed tropical:) [The membrane called] Als~alaY and Algirosu. (K. See these two words.)

viybN vyb
viybN: see vaAy^ibN, in two places.

vubapN vbh vbp
vubapN The place where the water collects in a valley or low ground; so called because the water returns to it: (Aboo-Kheyreh, T:) and the middle of a watering-trough or tank, (T, S, M,) to which the water returns when it has been emptied, (S,) or to which what remains of the water returns; (T;) as also mavaAbN↓: (S:) the p is a substitute for the w, the medial radical, which is suppressed; (S, L;) the word being from vaAba, aor. yavuwbu: (L:) Aboo-Is-hák infers that this is the case from its having for its dim. vuwayobapN↓: but it may be from vab~ayotu “ I collected together: ” (M:) it is
mentioned in the K in art. vbY or vbw, and not here. (TA.) See also art. vbw or vbY. ― -b2- Also A company of men; (T, M, L;) and so A^uvobiy~apN: (M:) or a company of men in a state of separation or dispersion; (T;) a distinct body, or company, of people: (Yoo, T:) and a troop of horsemen: (M:) pl. vubaAtN and vubuwna (T, M) and vibuwna: (S and M in art. vbY, and M in art. vbw also:) accord. to some, from vaAba, being originally vuwbapN; and its dim. is vuwayobapN↓: accord. to others, it is originally vuboyapN; (T, L;) and its pl. is vubFY. (L.) Hence, in the Kur [iv. 73], faA@nofiruwA vubaAtK, i. e. [And go ye forth to to war against the unbelievers] in troops, (Fr, T,) or in distinct bodies. (Yoo, T.) See, again, art. vbw or vbY.

vuwabaA='u vwbA='
vuwabaA='u: see vuw^abaA='u, in art. vA^b.

vawaAbN vwAb
vawaAbN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and mavaAbapN↓ (T, Msb) and mavuwbapN↓ (T, S, M, K) and mavowabapN↓, (EtTemeemee, T, M, K,) the last anomalous, (M,) and unknown to the Kilábees, who knew the second of these words, (T,) A recompense, compensation, requital, or reward, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of obedience [to God]: (S:) or absolutely; for good and for evil; as appears from the words of the Kur, halo vuw~iba Alkuf~aAru [cited above, see 4]; but more especially and frequently, for good. (IAth, L, MF, TA.) ― -b2- vawaAbN is also used as a quasi-inf. n., in the sense of A_ivaAbapN; and in this case, accord to the Koofees and Baghdádees, it may govern as a verb, [like the inf. n.,] as in the saying,
liA_an~a vawaAba A@ll~hi kul~a muwaH~idK
jinaAnN mina Alfirodawosi fiyhaA yuxal~adu
[For God's rewarding every believer in his unity will be the giving gardens of Paradise, wherein he will be made to abide for ever]. (Expos. of the Shudhoor edh-Dhahab.) ― -b3- It signifies also (tropical:) Honey; (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) the good that proceeds from bees. (A, TA.) ― -b4- And in like manner, (tropical:) [Rain; i. e.] the good that results from the winds. (A, TA. [See vaAy^ibN.]) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) Bees; (M, K;) because they return [to their hives]. (M.)

vay~ibN vyb
vay~ibN, [like say~idN; originally vawiybN, or vayowibN; i. e.] of the measure faEiylN, (Mgh,) or fayoEilN; (Msb;) A woman who has become separated from her husband (Lth, T, M, Mgh, K) in any manner: (Lth, T, M, Mgh:) or a woman whose husband has died, or who has been divorced, and has then returned to the marriage-state: (AHeyth, TA:) or one that is not a virgin: (IAth, TA:) or a woman to whom a man has gone in; and a man who has gone in to a woman: (Ks, ISk, S, Mgh, K:) or a person who has married: (Msb:) applied to a man and to a woman; (As, S, M, Msb;) like bikorN and A^ay~imN: (Mgh, Msb:) from vaAba; (IAth, Mgh, Msb;) because they generally return time after time to the marriage-state: (Mgh:) but mostly applied to a woman; because she returns to her family in a manner different from the first [state]; (Msb;) or because the suitors return to her time after time: (Mgh:) or it is not applied to a man (Lth, El-'Eyn, T, M, Mgh, K) except in the dual form, as when one says waladu Alv~ay~ibayoni: (Lth, El-'Eyn, T, M, K:) and a woman is also termed muvay~ibN↓; (M;) or muvay~abN↓, like muEaZamN: (K: [but see 2, last sentence but two:]) the pl. of vayibN applied to a woman is vay~ibaAtN, (T, Mgh, Msb,) and the post-classical writers say vuy~abN, which has not been heard as genuine Arabic: (Mgh, * Msb:) its pl. if applied to a man is vuy~ibuwna. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., Alv~ay~ibaAni yurojamaAni waAlbikoraAni yujoladaAni wayugar~abaAni [The two persons of whom each has previously had carnal intercourse in marriage with one of the other sex shall be stoned if they commit adultery together; and the two who have previously had no connubial intercourse with others shall be flogged and banished if they commit fornication together]. (T.) ― -b2- It is also applied to (assumed tropical:) A woman who has attained the age of puberty, though a a virgin; tropically, and by extension of its proper signification. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- This word is mentioned in the K [and M] in art. vyb; and its mention in art. vwb is said by the author of the K to be wrong: but IAth and many others decisively assert that it is from vaAba, aor. yavuwbu, “ he returned. ” (MF, TA.)

vuwayobapN vwybh vwybp
vuwayobapN: see vubapN, in two places.

viyAbapN vwb vyAbh vyAbp
viyAbapN and vuyuwbapN, as meaning The state of being a vay~ib, are not of the genuine language of the Arabs. (Mgh.)

viyaAbiY~N vwb vyAbY vyAby
viyaAbiY~N One who takes care of the clothes in the bath. (K.) [A post-classical word.]

vaw~aA=bN vwA=b
vaw~aA=bN i. q. taw~aAbN [One who repents, or returns from disobedience to obedience to God, much or often]. (T.) ＝ -A2- A seller of garments, or pieces of cloth: (AZ, T, L, K:) and a possessor thereof. (Sb, S, L, K.)

biy^orN lahaA vaAy^ibN *
biy^orN lahaA vaAy^ibN (tropical:) A well into which water returns after one has drawn from it; (A, TA;) see mavaAbN; and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense in the second of the following phrases,] biy^irN lahaA viybN↓, and waEiybK *iAtu viybK↓ [in which wEyb is an epithet]: (T, L, TA:) or the first of these three phrases means a well of which the water stops sometimes, and then returns. (Ham p. 598.) You say of a well (by^r), maA A^asoraEa vaAy^ibahaA (assumed tropical:) How quick is its returning supply of water! (T.) ― -b2- vaAy^ibu AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) The water of the sea when it flows after ebbing. (K.) Hence, kalaA^N mivolu vaAy^ibi AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) Fresh, sappy, [green,] herbage. (T, L.) ― -b3- qawomN lahumo vaAy^ibN (tropical:) A people, or number of men, who come company after company. (A, TA.) ― -b4- vaAy^ibN also signifies (tropical:) A violent wind that blows at the beginning of rain. (S, K, TA.)

mavaAbN mvAb
mavaAbN: see mavaAbapN, in four places: ― -b2- and see vubipN. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The place from which the water returns [to supply the place of that which has been drawn, in a well]: whence biy^orN lahaA vaAy^ibN↓ [see vaAy^ibN]. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The station of the water-drawer, (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) above the Euruw$ [which means the pieces of wood upon which he stands], (A 'Obeyd, T,) or at the brink, where is the Earo$ [sing. of Euruw$], (S,) or which forms part of the Euruw$, (M,) of a well: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, K:) or the middle of a well: (K:) or it has this meaning also: (M:) pl. mavaAbaAtN. (T, M.) [See also mavaAbpN.] ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The construction, or casing, of stones (TY~u AlHijaArapi) that succeed one another from top to bottom [round the interior of a well]. (IAar.) [See again mavaAbapN.]

mavaAbapN mvAb mvAbh mvAbp
mavaAbapN (accord. to Aboo-Is-hák originally mavowabapN↓, T) A place to which people return, (ISh, Aboo-Is-hák, T, S, Msb,) or to which one returns, (ISh, S, Msb,) time after time; (S;) and mavaAbN↓ signifies the same: (Aboo-Is-hák, T:) and the former, a place of assembly or congregation: (ISh:) or a place where people assemble, or congregate, after they have separated, or dispersed; as also ↓the latter word: (M, K:) and a place of alighting or abode; an abode; or a house; because the inhabitants thereof return to it (ISh, S) after having gone to their affairs: (S:) the pl. is mavaAbaAtN; [also mentioned above as pl. of mavaAbN;] (ISh;) or it is mavaAbN↓; (S;) [or this is a coll. gen. n.;] or, accord. to Fr and others, mavaAabapN and mavaAbN↓ are the same: Th says that a house, or tent, (bayot,) is called mavaAbapN; and some say mavowabapN↓; but no one reads thus [in the Kur]. (TA.) It has the first of all these meanings in the Kur ii. 119: (T, S, Bd, Jel, TA:) or it there means a place of recompense or reward for the pilgrimage to the Kaabeh and the visitation thereof. (Bd.) ― -b2- And, sometimes, The place where the hunter, or fowler, puts his snare. (S.) ― -b3- mavaAbapN Albiy^ori (tropical:) The place where the water of the well collects: (A, TA:) or the place reached by the water of the well when it returns and collects after one has drawn from it. (M, K.) [Hence,] jam~ato mavaAbapu jaholihi (tropical:) His ignorance became confirmed. (A, TA.) And kaAna yasotajim~u mavaAbapa safahihi (tropical:) [He used to wait for his lightwittedness, or silliness, to attain its full degree]: a metaphorical phrase, occurring in a trad. (Har p. 68.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) The stones that project, or overhang, around the well, (M, K,) upon which the man sometimes stands in order that the bucket (dalow or garob) may not strike against the side of the well: (M:) or the place where it is walled round within (mawoDiEu Tay~ihaA): (K:) or, accord. to IAar, it means TaY~u Albiy^ori; but [ISd says,] I know not whether he mean thereby mawoDiEu Tay~ihaA, or the building it [or walling it round within] with stones; though it is rarely that a word of the measure mafaEalapN [like mvAbp] is an inf. n. (M.) [See mavaAbN: and see what is said of tavowiybN in the last sentence of the second paragraph of art. vrb.] ― -b5- mavaAbaAtN [the pl.] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The foundations of a house. (IAar, T.) ＝ -A2- See also vawaAbN.

mavuwabapN mvwbh mvwbp
mavuwabapN: see vawaAbN.

mavowabapN mvwbh mvwbp
mavowabapN: see mavaAbapN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also vawaAbN.

muvay~ibN mvyb
muvay~ibN and muvay~ibN: see vay~ibN.

musotavaAbaAtu Alr~iyaAHi 1
musotavaAbaAtu Alr~iyaAHi (tropical:) Winds that are attended by prosperity and blessing; from which one hopes for a good result [i. e. rain]. (A, TA.)

1 vaAxa * and saAxa
1. vaAxa saAxa both signify He, or it, sank into the ground; and Yaakoob asserts that the v in the former is a substitute for the s in the latter. (L, TA.) You say, vaAxato qadamuhu biAlwaHoli, (S,) or fiY AlwaHoli, (L,) aor. tavuwxu and taviyxu, His foot sank, or entered, into the mire. (S, L.) And vaAxati AlA_iSobaEu, aor. as above, (L, K,) inf. n. vawoxN, (L,) The finger entered, or sank, into a swollen, or tumid, or a soft, or yielding, substance; (L, K;) as also saAxat, (L,) and taAxat: (Lth:) but this last is disapproved by IDrd, and J and others do not mention it. (TA in art. twx.)

1 vaAra mstvAbAt AlryAH
1. vaAra, aor. yavuwru, (M,) inf. n. vaworN and vuw^uwrN and vawaraAnN, (M, K,) It (a thing, M) became raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked; syn. haAja; (M;) syn. of the inf. n. hayajaAnN: (K:) as also tvw~r↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- Said of dust, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) and of smoke, (M, A,) and of other things, (M, TA,) inf. n. vaworN and vuw^uwrN (S, M, Msb, K) and vawaraAnN, (K,) (tropical:) It became raised, or stirred up; (Mgh, Msb;) and spread: (Mgh:) or rose, (S, M, A, K,) and appeared; (M;) as also tvw~r↓: (K:) also said of the redness in the sky after sunset, inf. n. vaworN and vawaraAnN, (tropical:) it spread upon the horizon, and rose: (TA: [see vaworN:]) and vAr, said of anything, means (assumed tropical:) it appeared and spread. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Said of a camel lying upon his breast, He became roused, or put in motion or action; as also tvw~r↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Said of the bird called AlqaT~A, (M, A,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (K,) or vaworN and vawaraAnN, (M,) It rose (M, A, K) from the place where it lay; (M, A;) as also tvw~r↓: (K:) and of a swarm of locusts, it rose; (M, K;) as also tvw~r↓: (K:) or appeared; as also AnvAr↓. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, (S, M,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (M, K,) He leaped, or sprang; (M, K;) as also tvw~r↓. (K.) You say, vAr A_ilayohi He leaped, or sprang, to, or towards, him, or it. (M.) And vArbihi Aln~aAsu The people leaped, or sprang, upon him. (S.) And vAr A_ilaY Al$~ar~i He rose, or hastened, to do evil, or mischief. (Msb.) ― -b6- vAr AlmaA='u The water flowed forth with force; gushed forth. (TA.) ― -b7- vAr bihi Ald~amu, (TA,) inf. ns. as first mentioned above, (K,) (tropical:) The blood appeared in him; as also tvw~r↓. (K, * TA.) And vAr Ald~amu fiY wajohahi (tropical:) The blood appeared in [or mantled in or mounted into] his face; as also AnvAr↓. (M.) ― -b8- vArt bihi AlHaSobapu, (S, M, A,) inf. n. vaworN and vuw^uwrN and vawaArN [or vuwaArN?] and vawaraAnN, (M,) (tropical:) The measles spread [or broke out] in him: (M:) and in like manner one says of anything that appears: (M:) one says, vAr, inf. n. vaworN and vawaraAnN, meaning (assumed tropical:) it appeared. (T.) And accord. to Lh, one says, vAr Alr~ajulu, inf. n. vawaraAnN, meaning (tropical:) The man had the measles appearing in him. (M.) ― -b9- vAr biAlmaHomuwmi Alv~aworu (tropical:) Pimples, or small pustules, breaking out in the mouth, appeared in the fevered man. (A.) ― -b10- vArt AlHum~aY (assumed tropical:) [The fever rose, or became excited]. (TA from a trad.) ― -b11- vArt nafosuhu (tropical:) His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. ja$aA^atN, (T, S,) i. e. AirotafaEato; (T;) or jaA$ato, (TA,) i. e. faAratN. (T.) ― -b12- vAr AlgaDabu, (Msb,) inf. n. vaworN, (M,) (assumed tropical:) [Anger became roused, or excited, or inflamed: or became roused, or excited in the utmost degree: or boiled: or spread: (see vaAy^rN, below:) or] became sharp. (M, Msb.) ― -b13- vArt bayonahumo fitonapN wa$ar~N (A, Msb *) (tropical:) Discord, or dissension, or the like, and evil, or mischief, became excited among them, or between them. (Msb.)

2 vaw~ara
2: see 4, in three places. ― -b2- You say also, vw~r AlA^amora, inf. n. tavowiyrN, (assumed tropical:) He searched, or sought, for, or after, the thing, or affair; inquired, or sought information, respecting it; searched, or inquired, into it; investigated, scrutinized, or examined, it. (M.) And vw~r AlquroA=na (assumed tropical:) He searched after a knowledge of the Kur-án, (S, K,) or its meanings: (M:) or he read it, and inquired of, or examined, diligently, those skilled in it, respecting its interpretation and meanings: (Sh:) or he scrutinized it, and meditated upon its meanings, and its interpretation, and the reading of it. (TA.)

3 vAwrhu vAwrh vAwrp
3. vAwrhu, (T, M, A, K,) inf. n. muvaAwarapN (S, M, K) and viwaArN, (Lh, M, K,) He leaped, or sprang, upon him, or at him; he assaulted, or assailed, him; syn. waAvabahu, (T, S, M, A, K,) and saAwarahu. (T, A.)

4 AvArhu A^vAr A^vArh A^vArp A^vr A_vArp AvArh AvArp |vArh
4. AvArhu, (T, S, M, A, Mgh, K,) and A^avarahu, and havarahu, (K,) [but in the M, I find A^avarotuhu and havarotuhu, (in the latter of which the h is substituted for the A^ of the former, as in haraAqa for A^araAqa,) and it is evident that the author of the K erroneously supposed them to be from A^avara and havara, whereas they are from A^avaAra and havaAra, and are originally A^avowarutuhu and havowarotuhu, but, for A^avarahu, SM appears to have read A=varahu, for he says that it is formed by transposition,] inf. n. A_ivaArapN and A_ivaArN; (Lh, M;) and vw~rhu↓; (M, K;) and AstvArhu↓; (T, M, A, K;) He raised, roused, excited, stirred up, or provoked, him or it; (S, M, A, Mgh, K;) [as, for instance,] an object of the chase or the like, (T, M, A,) a beast of prey, (T,) a lion, (M, A,) (assumed tropical:) dust, (M, Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) smoke, and any other thing: (M:) or he drew it forth: (M:) AstvArhu↓ is [often used in this last sense, or as meaning he disinterred it, exhumed it, or dug it up or out,] said of a thing buried. (K in art. swE.) You say, AvAr fulaAnFA He roused such a one for an affair. (T.) And AvAr AlbaEiyra He roused the camel lying upon his breast, or put him in motion or action. (T.) And Albaroka vw~r↓, and AstvArhA↓, He roused the camels lying upon their breasts, and made them to rise. (S.) ― -b2- AvAr Alt~uraAba biqawaAy^imihi He [a beast] scraped up the earth, or dust, with his legs. (T, M.) ― -b3- AvAr AlA^aroDa, (M, Mgh, Msb,) and A^avowarahaA, (M,) He tilled the ground, or land; cultivated it by ploughing and sowing: (Mgh, Msb:) he turned the ground over upon the grain after it had been once opened: (M, TA:) he ploughed and sowed the land, and educed its increase, and the increase of its seed. (TA.) And A^avaArati AlA^aroDa [She (a cow) tilled the ground]. (TA.) ― -b4- AvAr Alfitonapa (tropical:) He (an enemy) excited discord, or dissension, or the like. (Msb.) And Ealayohimu Al$~ar~a vw~r↓ (inf. n. tavowiyrN, Msb) (tropical:) He excited evil, or mischief, against them, (T, S, A, * Msb, *) and manifested it. (S.)

5 tavaw~ara
5: see 1, in seven places.

7 A_inovawara
7: see 1, in two places.

10 A_isotavowara
10: see 4, in three places.

vaArN vAr
vaArN: see vaA^orN.

vaworN vwr
vaworN A bull: (S, M, Msb, K:) and vaworapN↓ a cow: (S, M, Msb:) pl. [of pauc] A^avowaArN (M, Msb, K) and viyorapN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] viyraAnN and viyarapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and viwarapN (S, M, K) and viyaArN (M, K) and viyaArapN; (M, TA:) Sb says of the pl. viyarapN that w in it is changed into Y because of the kesreh before it, though this is not accordant to general rule: (S:) accord. to Mbr, they said viyarapN to distinguish it from the viwarap of A^aqT, and that it was originally of the measure fiEolapN: (S, M: * *) accord. to Aboo-'Alee, it is a contraction of viyaArapN. (M.) [Hence,] Alv~aworu (tropical:) [The constellation Taurus;] one of the signs of the Zodiac. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A lord, master, or chief, (M, A, K,) of a people. (A.) 'Othmán is called, in a trad., Alv~aworu AlA^aboyaDu; the epithet AlAbyD being added because he was hoary; or it may denote celebrity. (M.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (T, K:) a stupid, dull man, of little understanding. (T.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Possessed by a devil, or insane, or mad; syn. majonuwnN; so in copies of the K; but in some copies, [and in the CK,] junuwn [diabolical possession, or insanity, or madness]. (TA; and thus in Har p. 415.) ＝ -A2- A piece, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) or large piece, (M, K,) of A^aqiT, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e. milk which [has been churned and cooked and then left until it] has become congealed and hard like stone: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] viwarapN (T, S, M, K) and A^avowaArN. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- The green substance that overspreads stale water; (T, M, K;) this is called vaworu AlmaA='i; (S, Msb;) syn. TuHolubN, (AZ, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and EaromaDN, and galofaqN; (M;) and the like thereof: (T, M:) and small rubbish, or broken particles of things, (Msb, TA,) or anything, (K,) upon the surface of water, (Msb, K, TA,) which the pastor beats to make the water clear for the bulls or cows. (Msb.) Accord. to some, it has the first of these meanings in the following verse of Anas Ibn-Mudrik El-Khath'amee:
A_in~iY waqatoliY sulayokFA vum~a A^aEoqiluhu
kaAlv~awori yuDorabu lam~aA EaAfati Albaqaru
[Verily I, with respect to my slaying Suleyk and then paying the price of his blood, am like the green substance upon the surface of stale water, that is beaten when the cows loathe the water]: but accord. to others, by Alvwr the poet means the bull; for the cows follow him: (M, TA:) the cows are not beaten, because they have milk; but the bull is beaten that they may be frightened and therefore drink. (S.) [See a slightly-different reading, and remarks thereon, in Ham p. 416: and see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 330. The latter hemistich is used as a prov., applied to him who is punished for the offence of another.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Pimples, or small pustules, breaking out in the mouth, in a person who is fevered. (A.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The redness shining, (naAy^irapN, K,) or spreading and rising, (vaAy^irapN, M,) in the faint light that is seen above the horizon between sunset and nightfall: (M, K:) or vaworu Al$~afaqi the spreading appearance of the redness above the horizon after sunset. (S, A, Mgh.) You say, saqaTa vaworu Al$~afaqi [The spreading appearance of the redness above the horizon after sunset sank down, or set]. (S, A.) With its suquwT commences the time of the prayer of nightfall. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The whiteness in the lower part of the nail (M, K) of a man. (M, TA.)

(S.) ＝ -A3- (assumed tropical:) Many; a great number; much; or a large quantity; of men; (T, M, K;) and of wealth, or of camels or the like; (T, K;) like varowapN: (T, M:) or not of wealth; for of this one says vrwp only. vaw~aArapN The [part of the body called the] xaworaAn [q. v.]. (K.)

dabFY vaAy^irN [Locusts before they have wings] just coming forth from the dust, or earth. (T, S.) ― -b2- vaAy^iru Alr~aA^osi (tropical:) Having the hair of his head spreading out in disorder, and standing up: (As, T, * S, * TA:) or shaggy, or dishevelled. (T, A.) ― -b3- raA^ayotuhu vaAy^irFAfariySu raqabatihi (tropical:) [I saw him with his external jugular veins, or with the sinews and veins of his neck, swelling by reason of anger]. (A.) ― -b4- vaAy^irN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Angry. (T.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Anger: (S, A, K:) [or an ebullition of anger, rage, or passion: whence the phrase,] vaAra vaAy^iruhu, (T, S, M, A,) like faAra faAy^iruhu, (T, A,) (tropical:) He was angry: (T:) or his anger became roused, or excited, (S, M,) or inflamed: (A:) or became roused, or excited, in the utmost degree: (TA:) or boiled: (S in art. fwr:) or spread. (IAar, Th, T.) ― -b2- And vawila, (T, M, Msb, K,) aor. yavowalu, (T,) inf. n. vawalN, (T, M,) He (a man, and any animal,) was, or became, affected with confirmed madness or demoniacal possession: (T:) he (a sheep or goat) was, or became, affected with what is termed vawalN, explained below; (M, Msb, K;) as also, accord. to Sb, Avwl↓; (so in the TT, as from the M;) or Aivowal~a↓, inf. n. AivowilaAlN. (K.) ＝ -A2- vAl AlwiEaA='a, (Sgh, K,) aor. yavuwlu, inf. n. vawolN, (TA,) He poured forth what was in the receptacle. (Sgh, K.)

(S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AnvAl Ealayohi Aln~aAsu mino kul~i wajohK The people poured forth upon him, or against him, from every quarter: (S, TA:) or collected themselves together against him: (Msb:) [for] AnvAlwA also signifies they collected themselves together; and so tvw~lwA↓. vuwmN [Garlic; the allium sativum of Linn.;] a kind of baqol, (AHn, M,) well known, (S,) abundant in the country of the Arabs; (AHn, M;) of two sorts; wild, (AHn, M, K,) and growing in the cultivated tracts, (AHn, M,) or in gardens: (K:) the former sort is called vuwmu AlHay~api, and is the stronger, (K,) and is brought from Syria: (TA:) each of them is heating, expels flatulence and worms, and is strongly diuretic; and this is the most excellent [property] that is therein: it is good for obliviousness, and asthma, and chronic cough, and [pain in] the spleen and the flank, and colic, and sciatica, &c.: (K: [in which are added many other supposed uses:]) n. un. with p. Whence, A^um~u vuwomapa, said to be the name of a certain woman, may mean (tropical:) A sword. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] vuwomapu *akari rajulK (assumed tropical:) [The glans of a man's penis]. (Az, in TA voce TurovuwvN.) ― -b4- Alv~uwmapu also signifies The channel [or oblong depression] between the two mustaches, against the partition between the two nostrils; (IAar, TA;) i. q. AlxunoEubapu, &c. (TA in art. xnEb.) ＝ -A2- vuwmN is also a dial. var. of fuwmN, meaning Wheat. (Lh, T, M.) And the latter is used in the [ordinary] sense of the former. (T.)

; in the K, incorrectly, vw~Y↓, inf. n. tavowiyapN; (TA;) signifies also He was slain, (T, M,) and remained where he was: (M:) or he remained in his grave: (IB, TA:) or, as the latter verb is explained in the K, he died. vaAyapN, (S, M, K,) without ', (S,) formed by permutation from vwyp, though the author of the Kitáb [i. e. Sb] holds the A to be originally Y, (M,) The lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of camels, (ISk, S, M, K,) and of sheep or goats, (ISk, S,) when they have gone away to a distance in the pasture, or around the tents or houses; (ISk, S, M, K;) as also vawiy~apN↓ and vaAwapN↓: (K:) or the first and second, (AZ, T, S, M,) and the third also, (M,) signify the lodging-place, or nightly resting-place, of sheep or goats, (AZ, T, S, M,) and of oxen, or bulls and cows; (M;) and the last is app. formed by permutation from the first. (M.) ― -b2- Also A combination of two or three trees, upon which is thrown a piece of cloth, used for shade, or shelter from the sun. (IAar, M. [And in like manner vaA^oyapN is explained in the T, in art. vA^Y.]) ― -b3- Also, (AZ, T, S, M,) and vawiy~apN↓, (M,) Stones elevated for a sign of the way to direct the pastor when he returns by night: (AZ, T, S, M:) and the former, or latter, (M,) or both, and vuw~apN↓, (K,) with damm, (TA, [in the CK vaw~ap,]) the lowest sign of the way, of the height of a man in a sitting posture. (M in art. twY.) ― -b3- One who abides (mujaAwirN [generally meaning for the purpose of study]) in either of the two sacred cities or territories [of Mekkeh and El-Medeeneh]. (IAar, T, K.) ― -b4- One who is very patient in military and predatory expeditions, who is detained in the territory of the enemy, or on the frontier of the enemies' country. (IAar, T.) ― -b5- A captive. (Th, M, K.) ＝ -A2- A chamber, or house, or tent, prepared for a guest: (T, M, K:) and, (M,) accord. to Lth, (T,) a chamber within a chamber. (T, M.)

vaAwK part. n. of 1; (Msb;) [Remaining, &c.: or remaining, &c., long:] a stranger remaining, staying, dwelling, or abiding, in a country, or town: (T:) or vaAwiY balodapK a stranger who keeps to a country, or town. (M.) ― -b2- A man remaining in his grave. (IB, TA.)

mavowFY 2
mavowFY A place where one remains, stays, dwells, or abides; (T;) a place of alighting or abode, an abode, or a dwelling, (T, M, Mgh, Msb,) of a man: (T:) pl. mavaAwK (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) Hence, A^abuw AlmavowaY The master (M, K) of the house or tent, (M,) or of the place where one alights or abides, or of the abode or dwelling. (K.) And A^um~u AlmavowaY The mistress of the house or tent. (M.) And A^abuw mavowaY Alr~ajuli The master of the place of alighting, or of the abode, of the man: (S:) the host who entertains the man; to whom he betakes himself for lodging, and at whose abode he stays: (Har p. 595:) and the guest whom the man entertains. (M, K. * [See also vawiY~N.]) And A^um~u mavowaY Alr~ajuli The mistress of the place of alighting, or of the abode, of the man: (S:) the mistress of the man's place of alighting, or abode, in which he passes the night; occurring in this sense in a trad., not meaning his wife. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also an inf. n. of vawaY. (T, M.)

vayolN: see what next follows.

viylN vyl
viylN The sheath of the penis of a camel (Lth, * AZ, T, S, M, K) &c.; (K;) [i. e.,] of a he-goat also, and of a bull: (M:) or the penis itself: (Lth, T, M, K:) sometimes also used in relation to a man: (M:) and vayolN↓ signifies the same; (K;) mentioned by Ibn-'Abbád; and IAth adds vuwlN. (TA.) Hence the prov., A^axolafu mino viyli Aljamali [More contrary to what is usual than the sheath of the penis, or than the penis, of the camel]: for the camel, like the lion, is a retromingent. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A kind of plant; (S, K;) as also vay~ilN↓: (K:) a certain plant having a root and stem; when short, called najomN: and a certain herb, or, as some say, a plant, that is found on the banks, or sides, of rivers, in meadows: and, some say, a species of the [plants, or trees, called] janobap, which grows in the territory of [the tribe of] Temeem, and becomes large, so that the sheep, or goats, lie in its shelter: (M:) AHn says, (M,) in the “ Book of Plants, ” (Mgh,) the viyl, (M,) or vay~il↓, (Mgh,) [both appellations now applied to triticum repens, or dog's grass,] is the najomap; called in Persian ryzwPAdlh [?]; (Mgh;) its leaves are like those of wheat, but shorter, and it spreads upon the face of the ground, extending far, and becoming com-
plicated, or tangled, so as to be like felt (M, Mgh) upon the ground; (M;) it has many joints, or knots, and short internodal portions; and scarcely, or never, grows anywhere but over water, or in a place beneath which is water; (M, Mgh;) and it is one of the plants that are regarded as indicative of the existence of water: n. un. with p: (M:) Lth says that the viyl is a certain plant that tangles upon the ground: Th, on the authority of IAar, says that it is a kind of plant said to be that called liHoyapu Alt~ayosi: and Sh says that the viylap is a green small tree [or plant] resembling the first shoots that come forth from grain. (T.)
